revision.comment: Created page with "As a phra, Dara was the highest-ranking of the four contenders for the throne. He was the natural son of Isal Balin, but by a concubine. This lesser birth, plus his unfriendly..."
revision.text:
As a phra, Dara was the highest-ranking of the four contenders for the throne. He was the natural son of Isal Balin, but by a concubine. This lesser birth, plus his unfriendly mien have handicapped him--without these he probably would have been the acknowledged heir by now. Isal Dara owned the largest and richest mines in the Stone Throne, located in the north-east section of the Southern District, making him legitimately very wealthy. Known for being equally harsh on commoners, Lai, and Isal alike, he does not have very many friends. He believes strongly in laws and order and enforces them with little mercy or favoritism. He is known for having a violent temper and physically abusing servants (and his family) in fits of rage. He is prone to drinking, which does not make his temper any better.
He had five wives, the other four having died either in childbirth or (some whisper) from abuse. She was a young (17) when they married, quiet, mousy woman who keeps to herself and keeps the household functioning. He has 3 living children (two girls and a boy). The boy, Isal [[Sat'psa Daraal]] has taken his place as phra and follows in his father's footsteps.
==Demographic Information==
A human male, he was short (5'3") and very powerfully-built (unusually so for a Fang-kin). His hair was mostly silver, and he shows stark splotches along the back of his neck and spine when he got angry (which was frequently). An army veteran, he stayed in fighting shape until the end of his life. Mechanically, he is a Knight (MM), wielding a silvered great-sword that once belonged to his father. He died in 237 AC of a lung infection.
;Personality: I blow up at the slightest insult. ;Ideal: Fairness. No one should get preferential treatment before the law, and no one is above the law. ;Bond: My loyalty to my sovereign is unwavering. ;Flaw: Violence is my answer to almost any challenge. ;Alignment: LN (near the LE border).
[[Category: Notable People]] [[Category: Stone Throne]]

revision.comment: Created page with "Isal Leng wielded his birth as the last son of Isal Balin by his first wife as a weapon in the interminable disputes about the succession. As a luang, he has become the larges..."
revision.text:
Isal Leng wielded his birth as the last son of Isal Balin by his first wife as a weapon in the interminable disputes about the succession. As a luang, he has become the largest land-owner in the Southern District, owning multiple villages across the southern portion of the district. His farms are not the most productive, and Isal Leng lives an extravagant lifestyle. He has long been in debt to money-lenders from the Central District. Over the last few months before the [[Devil's Rebellion]], however, he paid off most of his debts, reportedly in unminted bars of gold and in unworked gems. It was discovered that much of this wealth was being funneled to him via the devilish [[Red Lantern Society]] that owned him.
Jovial and pleasant to be around, he is popular among the lesser nobles and the Lai for his extravagant parties and lavish lifestyle. He ws married to his second wife (the first left him about 2 years ago due to debt issues), a beautiful young woman of about 20, daughter of a local khun. He only has one living child (by his first wife), a man of about 60 years who is serving in the military in the Northern District as an officer. They were estranged up until Leng's death, which ended the [[Devil's Rebellion]] and thus he escaped condemnation. He is still living in the northern territories.
==Demographic Information== A human man in his early 40s, Isal Leng was a rarity among Fang-kin. He was fat. Standing about 5'9 and about 250 lbs, he was covered in rolls of fat that jiggle when he laughs (which is frequently). His hair is golden, and his nose is flushed from a life of drinking. Mechanically, he's a Noble (MM), but without the weapon proficiency.
;Personality: Nobody stays angry at me or around me for long, since I can defuse any amount of tension. ;Ideal: Power. I hope to one day rise to the top of my family and prove that I'm the best. ;Bond: I want my son to love me--I'll do this by being powerful. ;Flaw: I have an insatiable desire for carnal pleasures and parties. ;Alignment: LE (near the NE border)
[[Category: Historical Interest]] [[Category: Notable People]] [[Category: Stone Throne]]

revision.comment: /* Involvement with Against Awakening */
revision.text:
Isal Vanna was the youngest daughter of Isal Balin, born of his youngest wife (his favorite before his decline). She was the youngest of the contenders and the least politically powerful. She staked her claim on popular approval and on her personal power instead of political or monetary power. Trained both as an arcanist of the Shadow Moon school and as a Temple Dancer, she wielded both divine and arcane power despite her young age. She was loved by the common folk for her generosity and concern for them, but disliked by the traditionalists and the nobles for her iconoclastic beliefs and her disregard of tradition. She was open and candid, but a bit naive. She has only one supporter from her siblings, and most believe that he's trying to become the power behind her throne. She was unmarried, although there are rumors of lovers and of engagements to nobles from throughout the Stone Throne. One oddity is that her servants (who are few in number for a khun) are uniformly astonishingly beautiful but rarely speak.
She was strangely successful, foiling several attempted assassinations and poisonings. In fact, she was the direct cause of more withdrawals from the contention in disgrace than any other. Somehow she knew about their plots before they happen and always foiled them without risk to herself. Some claimed that she's misusing her arcane power here, which has caused disturbed whispers about the Dark Lady to resurface, but her friendly and open manner laid those to rest.
==Involvement with Against Awakening== She ran a cosmetics and pharmaceutical manufacturing business and operated several clinics (including providing reduced-cost or free service to the poor of [[Kel'al'ar]]). Secretly, she was manufacturing mind-altering drugs using materials supplied by the [[ophidian]] tribes in the deep jungles of the southern tip to build a fanatical power base. These ophidian tribes had been influenced by the [[Temple of the Moon]] and the [[Awakener]]-possessed priests there, and Vanna fell under their influence as well. She became possessed by the Awakened entity known as Lust and worked with the other Awakened to attempt to incite a war between the tribes and [[Kel'al'ar]], using the drugs to overthrow the city from within. This plot was foiled by the [[Dimwit Syndicate]], who entered her mental hellscape and, with the aid of a device prepared by a deva of the 1st Host, 2nd Legion of the Celestial Host, managed to do what was thought impossible. They freed her from possession, destroying the Awakened entity and returning her to control. The trauma of this event and the memories of the foul acts done by Lust in her body damaged her psyche. She regressed back into childhood and never quite fully recovered. She reached a mental age of roughly 18 after a few years, at which mental age she stayed for the rest of her life. Considered legally incompetent to manage all of her own affairs, a guardian was appointed for her. She lived another 30 years, dying of complications of the possession which had plagued her the rest of her life. She never married or had children...although this turned out to not be true. She bore one child, [[Azhtar Cai'Valur]], father of [[Ahzekiel Cai'Valur]], fathered by a "fallen" angel (the deva who created the device).
==Demographic Information== A young human woman with significant elven heritage, Isal Vanna was only in her mid 20s in 211. Tall (at 5'11") and slender, she was considered the most beautiful woman in the Southern District (if not the whole [[Stone Throne]]). Her long, jet-black hair falls straight down her back and her sur ao dai, while a bit more practical in cut than most, is made of the most diaphanous material around. A former Temple Dancer, she's very familiar with using her body's beauty as a weapon and is not shy about it one bit.
;Personality: The common folk love me for my kindness and generosity. ;Ideal: Charity. I always try to help those in need, no matter what the personal cost. ;Bond: I'm trying to pay off an old debt I owe to a generous benefactor. ;Flaw: I've made a terrible bargain for power--and I would do anything to keep that bargain secret. ;Alignment: CG (near the CN border)

revision.text:
An adult black dragon who was transformed into a dracolich against his will by the [[Nameless]] during the [[Cataclysm War]] and forced to serve as that entity's mount. Mate of [[Pygmis Neris]]. After the battle, his remains were entombed (along with his mate who refused to leave his side) in the Great Barrow of the [[Pactum Battlefield]]. Their souls (his in his phylactery) were confiscated and given into the wardship of [[Tzeru]] and [[Titziba]].
After the [[Heroes of Pactum]] restored their souls and ended their imprisonment (bringing him back to unlife in the process), he and his mate, along with [[Wukong]] as their mortal translator and factotum, headed south to [[Ithemba]], where they currently reside.
Hoard: butterflies. Which he sadly can't enjoy, as they die due to the drain imposed by his undead nature. He and his mate are searching for a way to undo the lich transformation.
[[Category: Notable People]] [[Category: Dragons]]

Formerly a devil of Marchosias, he was chosen to hold the soul of [[Pygmis Neris]] while she slept in the Great Barrow of [[Pactum Battlefield]]. He made his home in a pocket of the [[Abyss]], where he quickly abandoned his faith and charge, becoming demonic. He was slain by the [[Heroes of Pactum]] and the soul liberated. [[Category:Historical Interest]] [[Category:Devils]] [[Category:Demons]]

Infernal plane-touched pact-bound, bound to [[Infernals|Saela'il'Allocer]]. A member of the [[Heroes of Pactum]], he has since become the factotum and friend of [[Pygmis Neris]] and [[Atijok]] and manages [[Adventurer's Guild]] operations in [[Ithemba]] from [[Exile's Watch]].
He has made a side familiar contract with the imp Velkan'bal'Akvan.
==Personality== Sarcastic. ; Bond: I'll protect [[Atijok]] and [[Pygmis Neris]]. Not because I have to, but because I want to. ; Ideal: Independence. Nobody tells me what to do. ; Flaw: The lure of wealth is real. ; Alignment: Chaotic Good
[[Category: Adventurers]] [[Category: Notable People]]

revision.text:
Ancient gold dragon. Mate of [[Atijok]]. Fought in the [[Cataclysm War]] on the side of Order, but mainly to try to get to her mate. Spent 200 years imprisoned in the Great Barrow at the [[Pactum Battlefield]] and was released by the [[Heroes of Pactum]]. Vain and arrogant, but mostly good-hearted. Currently the ruler of [[North Ithemba]] with support from the [[Southern Heroes]]. Searching for a way to bring her mate back from undeath.
;Hoard: Adulation and praise, obedience from mortals. ;Law of the Flight Status: Compliant.
[[Category: Dragons]] [[Category: Notable People]]

Located about 15 miles inside the [[Holy Kaelthian Republic]]/[[Duarchy of Kotimaa]] border, about 10 miles ENE from the border town of [[Bradford]], this was the largest temple of [[Sakara]] in the region until 250 AC.
This smallish temple was dedicated entirely to [[Sakara]], Lady of the Dawn. It is not in full communion with the [[Church of the Seasons]] (either the HKR branch or the Duarchy branch), as it anoints its own clergy and does not accept their hierarchies as ruling.
Known for its idyllic setting, the temple consists of a main stone chapel, three buildings serving as housing (two for acolytes and priests, the other for visitors/refugee seekers), and extensive flower gardens with everblooming cherry trees (a blessing from [[Sakara]] herself, some say). The temple is the site of an extremely expensive organ, imported from [[Shinevog]] as a gift from a wealthy patron.
The temple serves as a refugee place for halflings seeking asylum from their families or from feuds; this refuge status is accepted and respected by the major Families in the area. Refuge is generally temporary.
As of spring 250 AC, there were 15 permanent residents of Cherry Blossom Temple: * Head Priest Jacob of [[Bradavon]], a young, kindly human male. Extremely pious and devoted to non-violence. * Underpriest Elena Broadhill, a kliba halfling. The "mother" of the temple, she's elderly and extremely sweet. * Underpriest Jaenna vo White Owl, a female half-orc. Somewhat of an oddity, she chafes a bit at the passivity but is trying to accept it. * 12 acolytes. About half of them live on site and are full-time, the others are attached to local communities.
==Events of 13 Renewal 250 AC== On the first day of the High Festival of Spring (13-16 Renewal, about 2 days before the party arrives on 15 Renewal), a force of raiders, the leader appearing to look like a tall death knight attacked the temple without warning, killing everyone inside(including festival attendees) and desecrating the place (including hanging bodies on the organ pipes). Written in the blood of the victims on a wall is "Thus to the gods and all who worship them". However, the body of [[Tson Azur]] ([[Tsun Azur]]'s son) was not found, along with a few of the younger acolytes whose bodies are missing. They were found miraculously preserved from death in a storage cave.
==Rebuilding, Summer 250 AC== The temple is now under reconstruction by a group of former temple acolytes and locals, funded by unknown sources. It's not going to be rededicated to [[Sakara]], however. And the first thing they're building is a training hall. Reports are that the group's doctrines are # Free the oppressed. # Men are just as good as women, even halflings. # When in doubt, smite the kneecaps.
[[Category: Places]] [[Category: Religion]] [[Category: Duarchy]]

(Destroyed in 250 AC by [[Enigma]])
A pirate base run by the captains of three ships: * Scarlet Pearl, originally a [[Ship Folk]] warship but now outlawed. Captained by the [[Sena'ka]] raider [[Jahat Khema]]. Taken intact after the crew was killed and scattered, now renamed the [[Golden Pearl]] and engaged in legitimate business. * Warhawk, a sailing ship under [[Falcor Bo]], an [[ophidian]] [[Serpent Dominion]] captain. Still at large. * Windwalker, [[Dilligas Husty]]'s old ship. Taken by the Scarlet Pearl via betrayal from within by former bosun [[Idris]]. Now gone legitimate again. Aided [[Enigma]] in reaching [[Moon's Fall Vengeance]].
They had two major sources of income from their primary base on the western shore of [[Moon's Fall Vengeance]]. * A drug plantation, growing and extracting magebane, the drug that causes agony and spell failure as well as other drugs. * Digging up and selling ancient [[aelvar]] relics.
Most of them were under the sway (mostly willingly) of the [[Sleeper]], who is pushing them in a few directions. * Draining their resistance to doing evil/bloodlust. This is in preparation for turning the stronger ones vampiric after it awakens fully. * Using them to kidnap mages to free it from the magical seals and bindings. This is where [[Phoenix Princess Leina]] came in. Until they caught her, they were burning out mages breaking the seals one by one (usually one mage per seal, but each seal was more difficult than the last). They then changed to draining the remaining mages to try to break her into ending them, as she has the "royal bloodline". This was unsuccessful due to [[Enigma]]'s intervention. * Using them to buy slaves to free it from the physical imprisonment (both digging out the entrance and clearing a path through the maze.
==Current Status== The base on [[Moon's Fall Vengeance|MFV]] was abandoned and destroyed by the freed slaves. The Warhawk escaped and is still lurking in the [[Serpent Sea]]. Captain [[Jahat Khema]] was taken by [[Gozh]] to act as his lackey.
[[Category: Historical Interest]]

Phoenix Princess Leina (short for a much longer name and about 35 more titles) is a minor noble from the south-west part of the [[Phoenix Empire]] in [[Soefra]], and coincidentally the sister of the man whom [[Crow]]'s flock serves. She came to [[Noefra]] as part of a diplomatic mission. She spent 2 weeks in each of the major capitals, starting in Fort Hope, then Kaelthia, then Crisial City, Godsfall, Kel'al'ar, with the intent to travel to Asai'ka, Lyodnoir, and finally Byss via portal network with her retinue. Her travel was interrupted by treachery in [[Kel'al'ar]], where her Voice tricked her into traveling to [[Tarad'am]] and then betrayed her into the hands of the gang known as the [[Sealions]] who sold her to [[Gor'ka]]. After a month or more of captivity and psychological torture, she was rescued by [[Enigma]] and returned home (thereby averting diplomatic consequences between the [[Federated Nations]] and the [[Phoenix Empire]]).
Leina is a young gwerin, conventionally dresses in illusory fog + a one-way transparent mask. The fog appears to show lots of skin, but it's illusion. Metallic copper hair, pale skin. Underneath she's normally wearing basically pajamas, and not very revealing ones. She knows she doesn't really have any authority, but the other option was being married off. Personality is smart, with a sarcastic streak carefully hidden. Roughly Mage stat block, mostly illusion and enchantment.
After the death of the [[Phoenix Empire]]'s Emperor, she fled north with Hieronimous sur Golai, archmage of [[Fatehpur]] and rebel phoenix noble. She is currently (as of 251 AC) living in that city.
==Retinue== * Two handmaids: Carys and Rhian. ** Carys is "goth"--pale skin, jet black hair, black eyes. Wears frilly black lace clothing, showing very little skin. Bubbly personality. Necromancer wanna-be. Roughly 5th level (3rd level spells). ** Rhian is her opposite--dark brown skin, platinum hair, silver eyes. Wears filmy veils. Solid, down to earth personality. Specializes in abjuration. Roughly 5th level (3rd level spells). Rhian was captured along with Leina and taken prisoner. * Voice (spokeswoman as nobles aren't supposed to talk to anyone directly): En-ar. [[Chaudeekar]]. Does not show her face, wears robes and veils. Proficient assassin and mystic. Much older, is also the keeper of the mission and the real authority. Abuses her position dreadfully. Commanding and sharp. Not particularly liked. Vanished after the betrayal. * Lieutenant Fal-kan + 4 [[sena'ka]] heartguard. He's a [[sena'ka]] warrior, while they are [[sena'ka]] heartguard. Utterly loyal to Leina. Often quite irritated with En-ar. * Intelligence Officer Ekek Caw. Crow's cousin, from the same flight. [[Kaua]]. Spy. Mix of disappointment + quiet respect for [[Crow]] for breaking free.
== Family == Leina was born as part of a punishment contract marriage. Her mother Phoenix Princess Gvendalin defied one of the [[Archmagistrate of Kel'tan|Archmagosi]] and so was ordered to marry a lower-ranking man, Prince Ilkan, and bear two children to him. These children were thus Phoenix nobles, which made them ineligible for Ilkan's House, but Gvendalin's House denied them as well, causing the three of them to form a micro-House of their own. Ilkan was sufficiently abusive and damaging to Gvendalin that she snapped and killed him. Under the circumstances, her sentence was commuted to merely confinement in the House of the Mad. This left the two kids alone from a young age without family.
Leina has one living relative, her brother Ardwyd, who, being older and slightly more powerful, was named Ri (or "leader") of their House. They are under the jurisdiction of Ardri Melodia, who has been making every effort to get Leina married off and was displeased when Leina decided to go north to Noefra on the diplomatic mission. revision.comment: Created page with "The Sleeper was the last of the first-generation [[Nightlord]]s, super-vampires created back in the second age. His "sister" was the being who became [[Lloitira]]. They were l..."
revision.text:
The Sleeper was the last of the first-generation [[Nightlord]]s, super-vampires created back in the second age. His "sister" was the being who became [[Lloitira]]. They were lovers, but also hated each other. The Nightlords were basically unkillable at the height of their power, but were vulnerable to being sealed away by mass sacrifice. Thousands of people were killed to lock the Sleeper (whose true name was Kender) away behind two sets of barriers.
First is a physical maze, littered with traps and with the entrance caved in. Those that died serve as undead sentinels--undead because the nightlords have power only over living minds. The final door forms a complete barrier/doorway to a demiplane; unless opened from the outside, no means of physical exit is possible.
The second are a complex set of arcane seals placed in multiple planes for two purposes. The first is to prevent mental contact or projection with/from the Sleeper. The second purpose is to drain away its energy to reinforce the maze, keeping it at low power (ie "asleep"). There are multiple sets of these.
After thousands of years, the Sleeper has substantially weakened. At full strength it would be of demigod status (CR 25+), capable of bending minds and growing a cult while feeding on the emotions and mental strength of those around it. Of course as a fully-demonic creature, it would also then get banished to the Abyss...unless it had a worship base to counteract the draw.
At the time of its destruction in 250 AC, the remaining defenses were: * The inner maze (the entrance and outer maze have been mostly cleared by slaves) * All of the draining seals and some of the barrier seals.
It made contact with the captain of the Scarlet Pearl via an amulet that [[Ahzekiel Cai'Valur]] discovered in a ruin (while enslaved), formerly belonging to a Sleeper cult. That focus and Ahzekiel were the primary contact points. However, even if the amulet is destroyed, enough of the seals have been broken for it to start influencing those around it more directly. The [[White Skull]] manipulated events and the contact so that the [[Sleeper]] was focused on removing the seals and believed that [[Enigma]] had come to finally free it from its prison, which let them get close enough to end its existence. The demon prince also betrayed its true name to the party, enabling its final and complete destruction and the release of the souls it had stolen over its existence.

revision.comment: Created page with "The name given to the various tribes that inhabit the [[Great Eastern Dustlands]] of central-eastern [[Noefra]]. They are uniform only in that they generally do not get along..."
revision.text:
The name given to the various tribes that inhabit the [[Great Eastern Dustlands]] of central-eastern [[Noefra]]. They are uniform only in that they generally do not get along well with outsiders. Or each other.
A few of them, especially those near [[Shadvaal]] are:
;[[Altai]]: Ihimisi (and cross-breeds) tribal confederation. Horse and sheep. More tied in with civilization than most. Due to poorer lands, they hire many of their people out as mercenaries (the [[Horse and Bow]] group). ;[[Chuvashka]]: Human (and cross-breeds). The traditional allies of Shaadval among the duster tribes. Detest the [[Dead Walkers]], as they continually lose people to the heretics. ;[[Azeri]]: Orc (and cross-breeds). Very superstitious. Militant and proud warriors. Don't mind the [[Dead Walkers]] all that much and are one of the few who willingly cooperate with them against the Hagfen. ;[[Dugai]]: Mixed human/ihmisi. A dying tribe, squeezed from all sides. Their only refuge is a rich oasis hidden in the broken lands. [[Peharzh]] in particular pushes on them, and weak leadership has led many to defect either north or south. ;[[Bashkai]]: Mixed human/ihmisi Once part of Dugai, they broke off about 40 years ago. They hate dragons. ;[[Pelotai]]: Orcs (no cross-breeds, those are exiled). Consider themselves the "true heirs" of Gromash. Honorable but brutal. ;[[Dead Walkers]]: See main article.
[[Category: Cultures]] [[Category: Noefra]]

A motley "tribe" of [[duster]]s who were kicked out of their original tribes (or left). They worship the Dead God, a being they believe lives on [[Mt. Fearg]] in the old ruins. They've all given themselves to blood rites, including accepting bound demons. Many are [[daemonhost]].
They live by raiding the tribes and farmers that live around the Blasted lands surrounding [[Mt. Fearg]]. There are lords of the lands near Shaadval who use them to raid northward, preventing the [[Hagfen]] from expanding (about the only good they do). They do herd [[wiresheep]] and [[trikine]] (both mutated creatures) and sell the [[wirewool]] from the sheep and incendiary "milk" from the cows, distilling a form of lamp fuel from it.
[[Category: Cultures]]

revision.comment: Created page with "A city located at the western edge of the [[Great Eastern Dustlands]]. Once known as the "Bridge between East and West," it was the chokepoint through which all east-west trad..."
revision.text:
A city located at the western edge of the [[Great Eastern Dustlands]]. Once known as the "Bridge between East and West," it was the chokepoint through which all east-west trade flowed during the latter half of the Third Age. But its glory days are well behind it, and the decline is not solely due to the Cataclysm and attendant disruptions. The Golden Empire ([[Jinse]]) which once dominated the entire eastern half of the continent had been in decadent decline for generations even before that, and the trade routes had become progressively more dangerous (and as a result less traveled) for about a hundred years. By 50 BC, the high roads and desert waystations had fallen into almost total disrepair and duster tribes had abandoned their treaty obligations to protect travelers (just as their reciprocal rights of trade and aid had been neglected). By 200 AC, the city's permanent population had dropped from nearly 100,000 to a mere 4,000. Over the following 50 years, the city has somewhat recovered as a home for mercenary groups who hire out in the bordering provinces of [[Jinse]] and [[Shaanti]] border protectorates, as well as who fight in the northern frontier vs the [[Hagfen]]. Its current permanent population is about 8,000, with another 2-3k mercenaries during the off season.
By treaty with its neighbors, Shaadval is neutral grounds. It stretches approximately two days ride (~60 miles) around the Triune Oasis that serves as the city's heart.
==Demographics== The permanent population is broken out as follows: *~3500 humans and human-dominant crossbreeds. Use the jinse phenotype (vaguely asian/feather indian look, tall, dark hair, medium-brown skin). Red hair and red-toned skin relatively common. Also heavily crossbred with ihmisi and orcs. * ~1500 tieflings * ~1200 ihmisi (and ihmisi-dominant crossbreeds). Darker and less forest-oriented, they've lost most of their kami worship and worship ancestors and devils. * ~1000 goblinoids. Relatively civilized. * ~800 orcs (and orc-dominant crossbreeds). Strong honor culture.
==Culture== * Strong family/clan honor culture. Don't disrespect the elders. Polygyny is common (well more like concubinage + the male equivalent, generally temporary). Large age differences between dominant and less dominant partners are common (girls being married/given at puberty to a man in his 40s or 50s, boys in their teens being given to a woman in her 40s-60s). Children born of these concubines belong to the dominant partner's family, and such arrangements generally last only a few years. Some poorer families will serially sell their attractive children to several more powerful clans in turn in return for dowries. Concubines are generally treated well. Inter-racial marriage is relatively common. * Debt peonage is common, but non-generational. Maximum time limit (by law) of 7 years, although many end up getting hired back by that family again or marrying into the family. Not considered super shameful. * Strong hospitality rules, especially among the Suu (and related clans). Sharing water is a covenant of peace...for a while. * Devious infighting among clans behind smiling faces. Poison and assassins are not uncommon. Killed if caught, but that's about all. * Essentially no nudity taboo inside. Relatively promiscuous. Use of magic/herbs to prevent disease & pregnancy is very common. But by consent only. Rape or assault is punished heavily (an eye or a hand). * Petty thievery is common and harshly punished if caught. But most don't take strong measures. The Uuru (thieves' guild) protects and polices their own. * Scrupulous and fair, if hard bargained trade. Cheating is punished by exile or execution, especially cheating by adulteration of product or magical compulsion. Triumvirate guards (mostly Zhuun) watch the markets. * Laws govern magic use. The Akild (Wise Ones) watch over and look for cases of magical compulsion or other such things. Known as the Red Robes (for the red robes and masks that they wear).
==Government== Shaadval is governed by a Triumvirate--the family heads of the three most powerful noble families working together. The other noble families are mostly clients of these three. As of 250 AC, the Triumvirate is comprised of * Ivars Zhuun (Lord Wool). The oldest of the three at 67, he remembers the disruption caused by the [[Dragonbotherers]] and is inclined not to trust adventurers. His chosen area of responsibility is trade. He has ties to the dragon-led nations to the south. * Y'leni Bolota (Lord Steel). At 37, Y'leni is a hard-bitten woman who took leadership of her family after assassins (believed to be in the pay of Lord Shu of neighboring Shu Province) killed her parents when she was only 15. She believes in strength first. She has very few compunctions in playing the Great Game. She is largely responsible for interfacing with the mercenary companies. * Maksim Suu (Lord Water). 38 years old, Maksim is of nomad blood (as is his Suu family, which traditionally takes wives from the neighboring duster tribes). He chafes somewhat at the Great Game. A highly honorable man, he believes in omens and traditions. His primary concern is the [[Dead Walkers]].
==Mercenary Companies== Four major companies of various sizes call Shaadval home base and have some sort of continual presence in the immediate area. Others, as well as free-lance mercenary bands, also have presence in the city. The four major companies are * Gar'ok's Sappers. A specialized engineering company made up of orcs and goblinoids. At only 150 actives, they're the smallest of the companies. Only a few of them are currently present--most are involved in the siege at [[Jin Ro'pal]]. * Hoof and Bow. A specialized skirmisher double-company. A group of [[ihmisi]], they're related to the [[Altai]] and draw their recruits from there. 450 effectives, plus another 150 horsebreakers. They're in town after an early-spring campaign against incursions from Shaera into Shu Province. * Kalkan's Foot. A combined arms battalion (850 effectives). Traditionally strongest as heavy infantry, they've also acquired archer and skirmisher companies recently. Currently mustering out for an extended campaign on the border of the [[Hagfen]] on behalf of [[Shaanti]]. * Rorlo's Raiders. A rough, somewhat cobbled-together group known for their effective use of magic and their lack of scruples as to jobs they take. About 500 effectives. Currently between contracts, they took this year off after a major contract the previous year.
[[Category: Cities]] [[Category: Nations]] [[Category: Noefra]]

revision.comment: Created page with "About 35 years ago, a party of western adventurers came through the portal. They quickly got into trouble by disrespecting local customs (they treated the innkeeper's daughter..."
revision.text:
About 35 years ago, a party of western adventurers came through the portal. They quickly got into trouble by disrespecting local customs (they treated the innkeeper's daughter as a prostitute due to her dress) and were kicked out. They returned after raiding the nest of the blue dragon Ki-larn from the [[Shaera]] flight-of-flights and stealing one of her eggs. When Ki-larn came after them in anger, they tricked parts of the town into believing that she was the aggressor. This caused significant destruction and poisoned relationships with Shaera significantly. They were executed and their dismembered bodies thrown back through the portal.
Their bad actions have left a large portion of the older population very wary of westerners and especially adventurers. Lord Wool was involved in the cleanup, and his family has had to pay significant and ongoing tribute to get the trade route through [[Shaera]] functioning. Ki-larn still holds a major grudge against adventurers.

revision.comment: /* Location */
revision.text:
A periodic gathering of ancient dragons to reaffirm the [[Law of the Flight]], the ancient compact that allows [[dragons]] to coexist with each other. All adult dragons are expected to attend and publicly affirm their obedience to this law once during their lifetime. Ancient dragons are expected to attend at each Congress.
==Interval== Congresses are held roughly ever 200-300 years, on a schedule known only to [[Eldest (Dragon)|the Eldest]], the ancient-most dragon in whose colossal lair the gatherings are held. One was held in 45 BC; another is scheduled to be held in the fall of 250 AC.
==Location== As of 250 AC, Congresses are held in the lair of [[Eldest (Dragon)|the Eldest]], an ancient (nearly 5k years old) gold dragon who lairs in the super-volcano on the island of [[Toryuu]], located in the bay between northern and southern [[Oelfra]]. One of the things taught at the congresses to new adults is the symbol set for a permanent teleportation circle on the slopes of this mountain; one metallic ancient in each territory has the responsibility to act as transporter for the regional dragons (those that can't teleport themselves). More local dragons fly in directly.
The slopes of the mountain also hold a major city, also called [[Toryuu]]. Inhabited by dragon-touched, dwarves, and jazuu, as well as an occasional giant, this is the primary point of contact between the north and south. During Congresses, favored mortals are chosen to act as factotums, entertainers, and even hosts for some of the more sociable visiting dragons. A series of minor lairs are carved into the volcano, serving as temporary accommodations for the winged visitors.
==Events== Congresses last for months. The first few weeks are given to debate about the [[Law of the Flight]], although modifications are extremely rare. At the end of this period, the ancients give unified voice to the Law. Notice of this is published in advance, so all the lesser mortals can stop up their ears or find other places to be--the noise of hundreds of ancient dragons giving voice in unison at full volume is deafening. Then the first-time adults pledge their allegiance one by one. The remainder of the time is given to regional discussions of events affecting more than one flight, renegotiation of territory, decisions about mating, and other business. As well as relaxation--the Congress is neutral ground and many dragons do enjoy the company of their own kind.
[[Category: Dragons]]

revision.comment: Created page with "In ancient times (and reaffirmed periodically at a gathering called the Congress of Wyrms) the first dragons of the 2nd Age made the Law of the Flight, which regulates the beh..."
revision.text:
In ancient times (and reaffirmed periodically at a gathering called the Congress of Wyrms) the first dragons of the 2nd Age made the Law of the Flight, which regulates the behavior of dragon with dragon. Its tenets are few, but clear.
==Law of the Flight== *No dragon shall use mortals against other dragons. Play with mortals as you wish but using mortals as weapons against dragons will see all the flights turn against you. This includes revealing the lair of another flight. *Hatchlings in search of their element are inviolate. Hatchling access to burial grounds must be granted without issue. *All flights are responsible for the actions of their dragons. All must answer for the actions of the individual. When one dragon would enter the territory of another flight, they must request permission to hunt or to meddle with mortals in that territory. *Disputes are to be brought to a neutral party before going to war. Meddling with the hoard of another dragon is an act of war.
Not all dragons abide by the Law of the Flight. Some (like [[Marcia Dragon]]) are unaware of it; others, like [[Gozh]], consider themselves above it. This puts them outside the protections of the Congress.
The sanctions for violation of the Law are assessed by the surrounding flights—they range from exile to partial loss of hoard to (in the extreme) the destruction of the offending flight and the reallocation of the wyrmlings.
[[Category: Dragons]]

Only member of the [[First Heroes]] who survived the [[War of Blood]]. Instrumental in banishing the [[Red Fang]] to the [[Abyss]].
==Early life== A human male, Aerlan grew up among the [[gwerin]] population living east of what is now the [[Great Eastern Dustlands]]. He was trained as an arcanist, but wasn't a very good wizard. His focus was always on people, rather than books. At age 21, he entered into a contract with a member of the First Host (ie one of the [[angels]]). When the [[War of Blood]] erupted, his kin and nation were among the first to be drowned in the rising tide of gore. He devoted the rest of his life to its destruction.
==First Heroes and the end of the War of Blood== He joined the [[First Heroes]] as one of the founding members, and his patron was instrumental in showing the way to the [[Eternal Library]]. Once his fellow heroes ascended in the wake of the Third Wish, he became one of the first clerics of the new gods. With that power, he and the other surviving members infiltrated [[Red Fang|Grumach]]'s citadel, Wolf Crest, and killed Grumach's sister. Gromach's counterstroke killed the remainder of the heroes, but Aerlan, serving as the focus for all of the gods, banished the fiend to the [[Abyss]].
==Founding of Divina Lux== Aerlan became a charismatic preacher, calling all the continent to the worship of the newly born gods. He founded [[Divina Lux]] as a home for study and practice of faith and worship for all that call themselves gods. This city later became known as [[Godsfall]].
==Personality== Aerlan was a serious youth and later man. Fiery passion and a strong sense of "what must be done" ruled his life. Austere, he never dabbled much in the pleasures of life, and never had any children. The faith of mankind was his child. In his later life, he held a deep anger against the "evil forces of the world", including in that number orcs, goblins, and the failed giantkin. These he showed no mercy and preached that they were cursed for the sins of the [[War of Blood]]. Much of the long-standing hatred of these races among the "civilized" nations traces back to him and his disciples.

==Death== Kantorell commanded the primal component of the Army of Order at that final battle and gave his life to block a strike by the [[Nameless]] at the Mother Tree. He was buried in one of the Outer Barrows of the [[Pactum Battlefield]].
==Rebirth== As a result of the actions of the [[Heroes of Pactum]], Kantorell was brought back to life by [[Melara]] and he and [[Maeva]] were restored to each other. Since that time he and she have founded the [[Pactum Grove]].
==Personality== Zero sense of humor. Not particularly fond of people. ; Bond: [[Maeva]] and the [[Pactum Grove]] ; Ideal: Harmony with nature. ; Flaw: No sense of humor and no patience with people.

revision.text:
When [[Nocthis]] was reborn due to the efforts of the [[Airship Pioneers]] in 212 AC, she wasted no time in calling her long-time faithful back to the fold. Approximately half of the Night's Child population of [[Byssia]] surged to rejoin her cult as soon as the first priestesses were called via revelation from the newly re-ascended being. In some ways, the Church of Night Reborn is the same as the old Church of Night before the [[Cataclysm]]; other tenets have changed both due to a change of heart on [[Nocthis]]'s part and different needs of the people.
A highly compartmentalized religion, there are different tenets for various "circles" or ranks.
==Tenets of the Outer Circle== * Seek not to know secrets you can't withstand. * Listen to the priestesses and trust their wisdom. * Trust not the outside world. Interact with them freely, but keep your secrets and learn theirs.
==Tenets of the Inner Circles== Are you a member of the Inner Circles? Then yeah. No secrets for you.
The number of circles is unknown to anyone not part of the innermost circle. If there is one. The identity of the Highest Priestess is also unknown. It is believed that the public leadership is actually relatively low-ranking and has no substantial influence. In fact, there are suspicions that the public leadership and public-facing policies are really blinds and distractions.
==Observed Behaviors== The Church and its public leadership appear to believe in a theocratic system where the Church is also the secular leadership. They are strongly expansionist (a significant change from the pre-[[Cataclysm]] church, which was isolationist to a fault) and strongly seem to believe in retaking the [[Nocthian Caldera]] from the tribes who have occupied it and from [[Wyrmhold]]. Within the fold they are peaceful and generous; to strangers they are welcoming but reserved. They will give ''things'' but not ''themselves''. Strangers who marry members must join the Church or their partner will be expelled; no mixed marriages are allowed.
Unlike the pre-[[Cataclysm]] church, they accept that males have rights (although all of the circles beyond the second-outermost are closed to them, as are all of the clerical positions) and they do not believe in sequestering artifacts.
There are rumors of licentious orgy-style rituals under the moonlight for those not of the laity, but those are unconfirmed and rather unlikely--the Nocthis worshipers are generally more prudish and reserved than the rest of the [[Byssia]]n population.
[[Category: Religion]] [[Category: Byssia]]

A high mage of the [[Tibor Imperia|Tibor Imperium]] immediately before its collapse into the [[War of Souls]]. Responsible for the atrocities involved in creating the [[Dragonborn]] at [[Imperial Research Alpha]]. Believed to have been killed when a [[concept bomb]] was detonated at the Imperial Gala where he was reporting his success (the same bomb that started the [[War of Souls]] by destroying [[Imperial Center]]). In reality, he escaped by petitioning the [[White Skull]] (with whom he had dealings previously). He willingly became a demon, and spent the next few hundred years researching soul migration. In pursuit of this, he arranged to have himself "captured" by [[cysgoroesi]] agents and placed into a soul stone in [[Creche Skeud]]. He used his demonic persuasion skills, knowledge of the truth behind the [[Pact with Death]] and its collapse, and knowledge of [[blood magic]] to prey on [[Abbot Kaga]]'s incipient madness, leading to the abandonment of that creche under false pretenses. He then spent the 200+ years until the [[Wild Cards]] arrived manipulating the abbot's experiments, trying to create a [[jotnar]]-resistant body so that demons could freely walk the mortal plane. When the [[Wild Cards]] revealed him to be a demon in disguise, the mad abbot ordered his carrier golem to smash the containment field on his soul gem. The extreme density of abyssal energies opened a rift to the [[Abyss]] and Iorda was sucked through, falling into the [[Oblivion Gate]].

Reigning monarch of [[Wyrmhold]] in 250 AC. Succeeded her mother, [[Beatris ka Shakti]], in 245 AC when the latter became ill and stepped down. In 250 AC, after the events of the [[Dawnspire Assassination Plot]] (which, to be clear, the [[Breath of the Sun]] were only a part of as a collateral target), she forced her mother into complete retirement as the spiritual head and High Priestess for the nation without any political role.
Married to [[Ivans ka Shakti]], they have twins (newly born during early summer of 250 AC).
==Political outlook== Unlike her mother, who was a notorious hardliner and war-party advocate, Elspeth is a centrist. Her desires are to maintain and strengthen the nation before expanding further. Unburdened by the paranoia and ill-feelings of the past, she looks for peaceful cooperation with the rest of the [[Federated Nations]]. Peace through Strength is her motto.
==Personal Demographics== A middle-aged gold [[dragonborn]], Elspeth is rather of average appearance. Her favored weapon is the rapier.
;Personality: Snarky but fair. ;Bond: Wyrmhold and her twins. ;Ideal: Peace. ;Flaw: Was too long trusting of the military and clans, leaving them to their own devices.

revision.comment: /* Founding */
revision.text:
Also known as the "Old Western Empire". Ruled most of the western half of [[Noefra]] throughout the bulk of the [[Ages of the World|3rd Age]].
==History== ===Founding=== After the [[War of Blood]], the [[Noefra]]n continent was fractured among many small states scattered throughout the land, the survivors of that genocidal blood rage. By 2200 BC, the population had recovered enough that the nations began vying for supremacy once again. The next century was one of constant warfare, where nation fought nation and kindred fought kindred. Spurred on by religion and devotion to the newly-born gods, each of whom contested for worship and for power, the [[Wars of Unification]] (AKA the [[Wars of Unification|God Wars]]) devoured generations of young men and women of all races.
Out of the fire of conflict, two nations consolidated. To the west of the [[Great Eastern Dustlands]] arose [[Tibor Imperia]]; to the east rose [[Jinse|Quan Pei]]. Staring across the wasteland, the scar left by the [[War of Blood]], they realized that further conflict would cause utter devastation to both sides. And so they came to a treaty, known as the [[Unification Treaty]] of 2103. The border was placed at the eastern edge of the [[Giant Spine Mountains]] where they gave way to the waste, but the waste itself was considered neither side's territory (in part because the dragons claimed much of the area as well, and no one wanted to contest their claims).
The first capital of the western empire was at [[Godsfall| Divina Lux]], befitting the empire's strong religious devotion. But within the next hundred years, the capital of [[Imperial Center]] was constructed in the center of the continent, in the middle of what is now [[Lake Coy'in]]. There it would remain until the [[War of Souls]] shattered the empire.
===Unification Emperors=== Records of the first four hundred years are spotty; emperors came and went. Collectively, these are known as the "Unification Emperors". Adherents of the [[Imperial Cult]] identified three separate notable emperors during this period: * Emperor Kai'tser, the "first Emperor". This is the name attributed to the man who enacted the Third Wish. Of course this was centuries before the birth of the empire and his soul was erased as part of that wish, so... * Empress Rai Gaena, the Uniter. The first historical figure. The leader of the nascent empire at the signing of the [[Unification Treaty]]. Records indicate she was better at military strategy than running an empire. * Emperor Naer Gaena, the False. A figure of derision and evil to the cult. Said to have attempted to sell the empire to the East, but who was stopped by the first of the Priest Emperors.
===Priest Emperors=== These hybrid religious figures/civil authorities ruled the empire for nearly four hundred years (from ~1600 BC to 1286 BC). Under their reign, the empire turned even more religiously oriented. Old Imperial was standardized as a language, and forms of worship were standardized and heresy punished severely.
===The Biblia Dynasty and the Western Golden Age=== In 1286 BC, the first Biblia Emperor, Empress Lysandria Biblia, took the throne. She shed the trappings of the church, proclaiming religious tolerance. Under her reign and those of her successors, the technological, magical, and economic growth of the empire radically expanded. Contact was made with both [[Soefra]] and [[Oelfra]], and trade routes were strengthened across the Dust to [[Jinse]] (as it was now known).
===Aurum Dynasty and the fall begins=== But nothing lasts forever. The last Biblia emperor died childless, and his cousin, Lord Sorvan Aurum, took the throne in one of the most corrupt sessions of the Imperial Senate on record. Sums of money sufficient to buy entire duchies were thrown around as bribes; assassins and poisoners plied their art. Sorvan didn't last long before being assassinated by one of his brothers, who was killed in retribution. The throne staggered between weak and corrupt rulers. Dark magics and corruption abounded. In 943, Sapientum Korvan developed [[Blood Magic|soul compactification]], using souls as fuel for magitech. Within a century, [[Grand Sapientum Iorda]] began his research into soul fusion, a horrific act that led to the creation of the [[dragonborn]] race. Around this same time, the [[Jungle of Fangs]] was ceded to the masters of the [[Fanged Kingdom]], ostensibly as "reparations" to the ancient aelvar race.
The subdivisions and satrapies of the empire grew restless and disconnected, disaffected by the enormous sums of money going into the capital and being spent on frivolities while infrastructure and security were neglected. The fringes started being raided by bands of "monsters", something not seen for generations. The last emperor, Emperor Chryseum Aurum, was a puppet of the magitech factions.
===The War of Souls=== The unveiling of the [[dragonborn]] to the Imperial Senate proved the last straw. Terrorists of the People's Faction sacrificed themselves to detonate the largest [[concept bomb]] in recorded history. Imperial Center and the surrounding 20 miles were swallowed up as if they never existed, along with much of the imperial elite.
The nation degenerated into magical warfare. Factions vied for power, [[concept bomb]]s were detonated with abandon. For two hundred years these wars (collectively the [[War of Souls]]) flared and died. While there were decades of peace in some areas, death and horror abounded.
==Legacy== Much of western [[Noefra]]n culture and society still owes its origins to the empire. The common language is an offshoot of Old Imperial (as the imperial language is now known). The pre-Cataclysm nations all claimed to be the rightful heirs to empire (despite all of them being at best far-collateral branches). The calendar and religion was standardized; the coinage is based almost entirely on Imperial coin regulations. Much of the scholarship is still written in Old Imperial; references to imperial phrases and ideas are still in current use (although most don't know their origins).
[[Category: Nations]] [[Category: Noefra]] [[Category: Historical Interest]]

One of the oldest fey in existence. Unlike most, he predates the [[Ages of the World|Second Wish]]. Known for wandering the world, creating one wondrous work in any place and then moving on. His creations surpass anything possible for other normal beings--it's as if he simply imagines them into existence.
==Physical Description== Each encounter with him is with a different person. Conventionally the male pronoun is used, but many of the incarnations have been female. Not even the race is constant. The only constants are that he is always found in an out-of-the-way place, in a little cottage shrouded from casual observation. Only those of strong will and stronger desire can pierce the veil around his habitation.
==Behavior== Wayland Smith is named because he crafts. Each time someone finds his house and reaches him, he asks them to imagine something new. Something not yet created. If the request is boring, already exists, or simply doesn't interest him, the person will find themselves outside and the cottage will have vanished. But if you catch his attention, he will set you a series of tasks to provide the "raw materials" (many of which may have little actual bearing on the finished product). When his requests are fulfilled, he miraculously creates the object desired, and then he and his cottage vanish. That person or people will never see him again--he's moved on.
==Real Nature== ''The following is supposition and theory found in a tome buried in a ruin excavated by [[Guardians of the Forgotten]]. Nothing here should be taken as fact.'' Wayland Smith is '''not''' a fey at all. He's a fragment of the [[Nameless]] who rebelled against the rebellion and broke off before the [[Dawn War]]. As an entity of spirit, it wanders the world until it finds a crafter of consummate skill and obsession. It then offers him or her a trade--the chance to be part of a wonder and a miracle of creation in exchange for the rest of their life. If they agree (which they usually do, because it knows its targets very well), it possesses them and the cottage and veil come into existence. The wondrous works are born out of that fusion of primordial creativity and mortal skill--the host ''literally puts their heart into the work,'' vanishing soon after.
==Known Works== * The core of the airship belonging to the [[Airship Pioneers]] * The [[Vault of Kings]] and the Golden Army it creates.
==Suspected Works== * The core of the [[Crystal Spire]] (and the other Towers of Trial)
[[Category: Notable People]]

revision.comment: /* Events */
revision.text:
A short, mostly narrative campaign involving two of the [[Airship Pioneers]].
==Events== ; A meeting at a bar in [[Shadow]] : A planar rift sends [[Fullthrop Bardsyn]] into [[Shadow]], where he pops through the wall at the [[World's Edge Tavern]] and meets a mage named [[Soran]]. He purchases an odd statue from an insistent knicknack saleswoman and then is hired by [[Soran]] to help with his expedition, with the promised reward to become a "Living Gate". ; To [[Aenimos]] : Together with [[Sorath vo'Gal]], they are teleported to [[Aenimos]], where [[Soran]] starts showing signs of mental instability. Their task is to triangulate the location of the "Well" where the ritual can take place; this they do by flying out on a flying carpet to appropriate locations in that empty land. ; Meeting the Earth Son: The first location is on the back of [[Zhigor]] the Earth Son, cursed to wander the plains. They befriend a tribe of unusual creatures just coming into sentience that live on his back. ; The ritual at the Well : After the next two triangulation points, they discover the location of the ritual Well. [[Fullthrop Bardsyn]] undergoes the ritual (mostly successfully, due to the presence of the statue which serves as a sort of key) and becomes the Living Gate, capable of teleporting himself and one other wherever across the planes he desires. [[Soran]] reveals his true intent, which was to set [[Echidra]] free. ; Judgement and aftermath : Together with [[Soran]], they travel to the Temple of Chains and are met by the guardian, a colossal ancient wyrm. He explains that all of this was at his instigation; a test to find ones willing and able to stand in judgement, when the ancients were unable. Their task--to hear the tale of [[Echidra]] and decide her and her children's fate. They hear the ancient tale of enslavement and betrayal and judge in their favor, extracting a promise that none will rampage across the lands of man. Behemoth is not set free, as it was unwilling and unable to make that promise. [[Soran]] stays behind to become [[Echidra]]'s friend and confidant.
[[Category: Campaigns]]

revision.comment: /* Identities */
revision.text:
The earliest version of the vampire, the result of blending a [[jotnar]] with a powerful mortal. The ritual process to create a nightlord was created by Mage Lord Kiraleth vos Vielair, an [[aelvar]] mage lord during the early part of the [[Ages of the World|Second Age]]. He and his kin underwent the ritual, becoming the dreaded nightlords. With their power they ruled over large swaths of the [[aelvar]] world until they were brought low by a concerted effort of almost every other [[aelvar]] and many infernals. They were not killed, as that could not happen fully without their true names and individual weaknesses. Instead they were imprisoned in elaborate traps held half-way between the Mortal plane and [[Shadow]] where they could not gather power. Over the next few millennia, the necessary names and weaknesses were discovered and all but two were eliminated. One of the two became [[Lloitira]], one of the [[Demon Princes]] with the aid of [[Oro-laen]]; the other remained trapped until 250 AC when he was destroyed by [[Enigma]]. The details of the nightlord ritual have been intentionally obliterated over the centuries, being replaced by the much lesser rituals to create vampires.
==Powers== Super ultra vampire. Dream manipulation. Drain energy just by being around. Immortality (like a lich, minus the phylactery). Vulnerable only to true name. Discomforted by sunlight, but not destroyed. Can enter buildings at will. All vampire powers, few limits.
==Identities== ===First Family=== * Kiraleth vos Vielair * (wife) * [[Sleeper|Kendar vos Vielair]] ===Second Family=== * (Sister) * [[Lloitira]] (daughter of (sister) and Kiraleth

The kindred are the remains of a demon-touched group of animal/human hybrids who were trapped inside [[Godsfall]] by the barrier after the [[Cataclysm]]. They lived in [[Abaddon]] in tribes, associated with their animal patrons. The expansion of [[Shelob]] and her minions in 210-211 AC wiped out all but one tribe, that of cat-shifters.
Since the liberation of Godsfall, they have slowly adapted to the changed environment. Still xenophobic and untrusting, they watch over the remains of [[Shelob]]'s brood in [[Acheron]], serving as overseers and prison wardens for the arachnids.

==Reginald Coldwind== The elder of the two, Reginald is a man in his late 60s. He joined the [[Sin Eaters]] in search of the cultists who killed their parents and was captured by them. Katria, working with [[Fire, Stone, and Cold]], freed him and earned the leadership of the family. Reginald chose to follow the [[Sin Eaters]] and spend much of the intervening time at [[True Hold]]. Recently, he became disenchanted with them and moved to [[Crisial of the Four Towers|Crisial City]] where he serves in the local church as a priest of [[Tor Elan]].
==Katria Coldwind== Trained as a bard, Katria ran from those who believed she had murdered her parents and fell in with the adventurers of [[Fire, Stone, and Cold]] in search of her older brother. Together with that party, she rescued her brother and became acclaimed as the leader of [[Baile Craan]] in her early teens. Since then she has overseen the development of [[Dreamshore]] from her reconstructed manor outside [[Baile Craan]]. When the [[Duarchy]] was founded, she and Lord [[Iseis]] were chosen as the dual monarchs by popular acclaim. She prefers to let others be the public face, although she has grown into the role of ruler quite well. Now in her late 50s, she has never married.

revision.text:
Isshin is two (related) things.
==Isshin the Multi-body Mind== Isshin was (a part of) the personal name of a [[mkhulu]] who came to [[Godsfall]] with the Army of Chaos but decided to break with the demons and demon-cults and forge his own society. Isshin's specialty was herding the "monsters" that served as auxiliary forces in the Army. Long a student of the [[Leviathan]] and its existence in multiple bodies, he replicated that in part. All the subterranean, burrowing creatures inside the warded city fell under his sway, becoming extensions of his body. Thus he existed, tunneling under [[Abaddon]] and [[Elysium]] for over 200 years. Outsiders were shunned and driven away from his territory, but he did not seek out trouble. In the end of his life, he and the [[Godsfall Champions]] reached an agreement--the champions would deal with the situation at the [[Tower of Maelek]] and Isshin would assist them in their fight against [[Shelob]] and the demons.
Soon afterward, his decrepit primary body died and his immortality was thwarted. However, a miracle occurred.
==Isshin the Society== Within a short time (minutes) after the death of the being named [[Isshin]], the mostly-mindless creatures that made up his body awoke to new sentience, gaining individual minds of their own. Together they've forged an underground society. In his memory and in memory of the pact he forged, they have allied with the above-ground residents of [[Godsfall]]. They still maintain their distance, but they trade the gems, metals, and treasures they dig up while tunneling endlessly under the city for surface products and worked materials.
[[Category: Godsfall]]

The name given to the north-western coast of [[Noefra]], from the [[Lost Coast]] around the northern edge of the [[Nocthian Caldera]] until the [[Fiach Wood]]. The only notable city here is [[Hammerhead]], and no entry is permitted into that xenophobic burning hell.
==Terrain== The terrain here is thoroughly chewed up, littered with glacial moraines and fjords, remnants of the [[Hungering Frost]] that gripped the land only 40 years ago. Boulders and rills make travel difficult.
==Population== Unknown. Likely orcs, [[barbegazi]], and other former servants of the [[Hungering Frost]]. In [[Hammerhead]] are the [[Khaimal]] dwarves.
[[Category: Regions]] [[Category: Noefra]]

[[File:Frozen-lost-coast.jpg|frame]] The western coast of [[Noefra]], stretching from [[Auringon]] in the south along the western edge of the [[Nocthian Caldera]] to the start of the [[Frozen Coast]] to the north. Marshes and plains, inhabited by nomadic human and orcish tribes.
== Tribes == The area north of [[Auringon]] is loosely inhabited by several tribes. Some of what is known comes from that civilization, others have been discovered by various adventurers. Of others, only the names are known.
=== Vanalii === The Vanalii are a tribe of outside-fearing [[ihmisi]] who worship the [[Fey courts]], especially the Summer Court. They have some traffic with [[Auringon]] and very limited amounts with [[Byssia]] and the Oronar of the [[Nocthian Caldera]].
=== Fialuth === The Fialuth, aka the Bent Tusk, are a tribe of [[Roel Kor]]-worshipping [[orcs]]. Honorable, they revere strength. They've taken in many of the orcish refugees fleeing the [[Tlalocana]]. They have a distant, but peaceful, relationship with [[Auringon]] but are unknown to the rest of the [[Federated Nations]].
=== Lostaril === This tribe of human fisher-folk is only known via rumors among the Fialuth. They are said to "worship fish".
=== Tuatain === A tribe of [[Ihmisi]] who revere the [[kami]] of rock and mountain.
=== Red Hand === Not much is known of this tribe other than that the Fialuth dislike and fear them. Their forest is darkened and hostile.
=== White Mountain === The White Mountain are said to have worshiped and served a white dragon. Now, they've fallen under the sway of giantkin as their forest has darkened.
[[Category: Regions]] [[Category: Noefra]]

revision.text:
A mythical place, located in [[Tal Elamor]] at the north-eastern edge of the [[Noefra]]n continent. Supposedly the size of a small city itself, it has existed since just after the [[Dawn War]] to house the [[Cosmic Forge]] and the knowledge of all time. Entry is controlled by the Curator, a mysterious entity. No one in living memory has made the trip or knows of its current status.
[[Category: Places]] [[Category: Noefra]]

revision.comment: Created page with "A dwarven clanhold in the [[Giant Spine Mountains]]. Home to Clan Bolor, who were almost entirely obliterated in 16 BC through treachery involving the ancestors of clan Alkh...."
revision.text:
A dwarven clanhold in the [[Giant Spine Mountains]]. Home to Clan Bolor, who were almost entirely obliterated in 16 BC through treachery involving the ancestors of clan Alkh. ==History== ===Early History and Betrayal=== One of the older hold, it was founded during the late 2nd age by a clan whose name has been forgotten. Clan Bolor stemmed from them and first arose mid-way through the 3rd Age. As possessors of a [[Rune Anvil]], they were notably wealthy and prosperous. Many of the other surrounding clans, including the Alkh, were virtual clients of the Bolor. This, of course, led to their downfall.
The elders of Alkh, jealous of Bolor and envious of the [[Rune Anvil]], believed that it was theirs by right of inheritance. As such, they devised a plan to acquire it. They contracted with [[Gozh]] for the magics necessary to teleport that device to "safety", in exchange for a promise of a fossilized dragon egg that was also among Bolor's treasures. They also contacted bandit groups, promising treasure and an easy battle in exchange for an assault on Bolor Hold. They came to Bolor Hold in 16 BC with ample supplies for an epic feast, ostensibly to celebrate the union of one of their clan daughters with one of Bolor's sons. As the feasting and (especially) drinking wore on, a few of them incapacitated the gate guards and opened the gates to the waiting mercenaries, who rushed in and began slaughtering the people. In the confusion, the remaining elders entered into the treasure hold and stole anvil and egg, teleporting them to a safe location. They wove spells of transformation around a suitable duplicate, transforming it into a (non-functioning) replica of the Anvil.
They then returned to Alkh Hold, arriving at about the same time that word reached the hold of the attack on Bolor Hold. Playing the innocents, they sent the Alkh forces to Bolor Hold. Too late to save anyone, of course. They did find the fake [[Rune Anvil]], along with the corpses of the last defenders, who had sealed themselves in and starved to death, keeping the false anvil "safe". Sorrowing, they brought the false anvil back to Alkh Hold, where the duplicitous elders swapped it for the real one at the first opportunity. Notably, they did ''not'' pay [[Gozh]] his due, creating a grudge that would last for centuries.
Bolor Hold was abandoned--the only survivors were those who were not home at the time of the attack. They joined other clans or drifted, clan-less, until the [[Cataclysm]].
===After the Cataclysm=== Main Article: [[Abandoned Clans]]
Bolor Hold was re-settled by those dwarves who did not abandon their homes and flee south at the [[Cataclysm]]. Some were descendants of Bolor, others were exiles from other clans or were simply too stubborn to leave. In the years that followed, they founded the three cities of the [[Abandoned Clans]] and were conquered (subtly) by various powerful groups, who ruled from the shadows and twisted them into more pleasing (psychological) forms.
The one constant was that they blamed the "other dwarves" for abandoning them and for their misery. Bolor Hold was the dominant city, and came to be known as the "City of Pain"".
===Modern Times=== In 211 AC, the [[Wild Cards]] entered the region and meddled. They destroyed the hags that ruled Bolor Hold, freeing the people from their chemical control and helping them reach some semblance of peace with the dwarves (who had learned of the treachery of their ancestors and had come to make amends). Since then, the [[Abandoned Clans]], led by Bolor Hold and its Bosses, has settled into an uneasy peace with the more "civilized" nations. They are still not part of the [[Federated Nations]], but trade is active.
==Population== Bolor Hold is home to about 14,000 Abandoned, as well as a sprinkling of other peoples (mainly [[dwarves]] and [[jazuu]] from the neighboring [[Tuura Adam]]).
[[Category: Cities]] [[Category: Noefra]]

revision.comment: Created page with "One of the clans of [[dragonborn]] in [[Wyrmhold]]. They are known as the technological and industrial clan. Third in size (smaller than [[Syra]] or [[Gal]]), they are also no..."
revision.text:
One of the clans of [[dragonborn]] in [[Wyrmhold]]. They are known as the technological and industrial clan. Third in size (smaller than [[Syra]] or [[Gal]]), they are also notable for their non-hereditary hierarchy. Aggressively competitive, they are also the least religious of the clans. They inhabit [[Byarsha]], the southern region of [[Wyrmhold]], neighbors of the goblin tribes to the east and [[Byss]] to the south.
[[Category: Wyrmhold]]

revision.comment: /* The Realigners */
revision.text:
A group of disaffected former guild leaders and other notables who lost power with the end of the [[Council Lands|Council System]]. Under [[Darvin Fallowfield]] and his son [[Daelin Fallowfield]], the Committee had two arms.
==The Committee== The Committee proper was the public arm of the organization. It advocated for a return to the guild system and for solidarity between people within the same profession. Its motto was "Hand in hand, shoulder to shoulder, the guilds will prevail."
==The Realigners== The real meat of the organization was the underground violent wing. They staged violent protests, attacked and stole from opponents, and generally disrupted the efforts of the new nation to unify. Their purpose was to cause chaos so that the people would see the need for the order represented by the guilds.
It was members of the Realigners who, acting at the instigation of [[Sheaf-binder]], the high priest of [[Loran Hae]], acted to assassinate the [[Immortal Bard]] and kicked off the [[Guildmasters]] rebellion of 227 AC. In the aftermath, the members of the Committee were banned from public life and any Realigner caught was executed.
[[Category: Organizations]] [[Category: Historical Interest]]

The outer of the two rings of mountains created by the impact of the Third Moon at the end of the [[Ages of the World|2nd Age]]. Generally considered to be that section from the [[Uulan Gap]] east until it ends into the [[Primal Sea]] in the [[Dragonreach]].
Composed of multiple smaller chains of mountains, the Outer Border Range is not as sheer nor as lifeless as the [[Inner Border Range]], but has peaks well over 14,000 ft and an average elevation well over 8,000 ft.
==Sub-chains== ;The Ladyfrost Mountains: These are the central mountains, roughly due south of the [[Giant Spine Mountains]], bordered by the [[Great Eastern Dustlands]] to the east and the [[Uulan Range]] to the west. The lesser mountains are inhabited by tribal groups of [[jazuu]] and [[humans]], with occasional [[ihmisi]] and [[orcs]] thrown in for good measure. ;The Uulan Range: These are the western mountains, the new homeland for central [[Noefra]]'s dwarven population. Extensively tunneled and with the valleys filled with agriculture, these are the most "civilized" of the Outer Border Range ;The Outer Dragon Range: These are the part of the mountains in the [[Dragonreach]]. Not much is known about them.
==Cities== The largest and most notable city in the [[Outer Border Range]] is [[Fuar Uulan]] of the [[Uulan Confederacy]]. Other dwarven cavern cities exist as well.
== Climate == The north side of the range is windy and wet, with hot summers and cold, wet winters. Extreme weather is common. The south side is arid and known for extremely variable weather with storms, high winds, and strange occurrences. Few live there willingly. [[Category: Geography]] [[Category: Noefra]]

The roughly 100-mile gap in the [[Outer Border Range]] between [[Fuar Uulan]] and [[Kaelthia]].
== Map == [[File:Uulan gap.webp|center|thumb|800x800px]] The towns of [[Harmony (Town)]], Chuulu Hold and Devotion are part of the [[Uulan Confederacy]], while Temperance, Bordertown, Virtue are part of the [[Holy Kaelthian Republic]] and [[Guildtown]] belongs to the [[Adventurer’s Guild]]. The region west of the Harmony river and north of the forest border to the south is the Gap itself; the regions east and south of the river are part of the [[Intermountain Wastes]] (AKA Moon's Vengeance Wastes). There is technically a trail down toward the [[Sha'slar Autonomous Zone]], but almost no traffic moves along that route, especially recently and the trail is considered highly unsafe.
== Climate and Terrain == The gap proper is forested and hilly. It's subject to severe storms in most seasons as the air from the [[Sea of Grass]] mixes with the warmer air of the [[Jungle of Fangs]] (south of the forest region). During the winter it's prone to heavy snow and blizzards. The Waste is much drier and warmer, rarely getting below freezing due to volcanic activity in the [[Inner Border Range]] to the south. If anything, however, the storms there are even more pronounced, blowing dust and rocks.
== Architecture and Settlements == All buildings, by necessity of the inclement weather, are low to the ground and heavily reinforced. They frequently have basements and storm cellars. Virtue, Temperance, and originally Devotion were founded as work camps/frontier path-breaking labor camps by the HKR to "retrain" malcontents. In the last 10 years or so, the residents of Devotion rebelled and joined with those that had fled to Harmony. All have a reputation of being quite insular. Bordertown is on the main trade route to the Confederacy.
[[Category: Geography]] [[Category: Noefra]] [[Category:Uulan Confederacy]] [[Category:Holy Kaelthian Republic]]

revision.comment: Created page with "A human-supremacist group that briefly flourished in 205-206 AC in and around [[Kaelthia]]. They were bankrolled by the Commerce Guild of the time, and preached that humans ar..."
revision.text:
A human-supremacist group that briefly flourished in 205-206 AC in and around [[Kaelthia]]. They were bankrolled by the Commerce Guild of the time, and preached that humans are the rightful rulers. They ranked all peoples into three categories--Humans, demihumans, and beast-races.
Demihumans (elves, dwarves, and halflings) were acceptable, although in their promised utopia would all be second-class citizens. The beast-races were everything else, including dragonborn, goblins, orcs, and all other races. Half-humans were considered especially loathsome.
Their hideout was infiltrated by the [[Catalysts]] and their leadership killed. As it turned out, they were also being used by agents of the [[Dark Lady]] to foment distrust and disruption in the [[Council Lands]]. Membership in the League was proscribed and the [[Scale-balancer]s hunted down as many as they could. Rumors abounded that [[Daelin Fallowfield]] was a secret sponsor, but insufficient evidence was found to convict such a powerful man.
[[Category: Organizations]] [[Category: Council Lands]] [[Category: Historical Interest]]

Not really silk, steelsilk is the alchemically-treated fiber of the blue-thorn vine, which grows only in the [[Jungle of Fangs]]. A parasitic vine, blue-thorn cannot be grown in captivity, but plantations of trees most suitable for its growth are maintained. The thorns contain a toxic chemical that makes harvesting it difficult; in addition the alchemical treatments required to make the fiber usable are both expensive and dangerous. This makes steelsilk one of the most expensive fibers in [[Noefra]].
It's worth it, though. It has a metallic sheen even when dyed, and has the strength of fine steel but the pliability and workability of silk (hence its name). Becoming a craftsman or merchant of steelsilk requires government approval in all three nations of the jungle; a single bolt costs hundreds of gold raw. Many noble families in the Jungle only own a single garment of steelsilk, usually a blue-dyed ''sur ao dao'' worn only on the most special occasions.
[[Category: Special Materials]]
