revision.comment: Created page with "A small city, located on the [[Rabbiton Road]] between the [[Sea of Grass]] and [[Godsfall]] where the [[True Fire Road]] branches off toward [[True Hold]]. This is the tradit..."
revision.text:
A small city, located on the [[Rabbiton Road]] between the [[Sea of Grass]] and [[Godsfall]] where the [[True Fire Road]] branches off toward [[True Hold]]. This is the traditional seat of the [[Green Lady]], the spiritual leader for the [[ihmisi]] tribes of [[Kotimaa]].
==Population== Roughly 2,000, but strongly seasonal. Swells to 6,000 during the winter as local tribes arrive.
* 60% [[ihmisi]] (but mostly seasonal) * 35% human/half-elf (mostly permanent) * 5% others, with a significant orcish population
Permanent [[ihmisi]] settlers are mostly elderly, crafters, and invalids (pregnant, injured, very young children and mothers, etc). The seasonal residents live in the woods during the late spring and summer and come back for the harvest and the winter. The human population carries the weight of the farming.
==History== For much of the [[Council Lands]] history, this was the northernmost "official" settlement, and was much smaller. The rediscovery and repopulation of [[Godsfall]] brought significantly increased trade. With the end of the council system and the formation of the [[Successor States]], the population has mushroomed and become much more permanent.
==Leadership== This is the Pilvi tribe center and so is governed by a two-person council composed of Chief Shaman Ukko il Pilvi and Warleader Ahti il Pilvi.
;Chief Shaman Ukko: an ancient woman, Chief Shaman Ukko has been part of the Green Lady’s court in the past and also worked with the Council as part of the Forestry Guild representation before the breakup of the [[Council Lands]]. She is a calming influence on the hotheaded tribesmen (and women), and is personally dedicated to the [[Duarchy]]. She can cast 1st level spells from the Healer list and cantrips, 1st, and 2nd level spells from the Spiritualist list.
;Warleader Ahti: the grandson of the Chief Shaman, Ahti is new to his role and chafes under the restraint of his grandmother. He craves adventure and is quite a bit of a hothead.
[[Category: Cities]] [[Category: Duarchy]]

revision.comment: Created page with "The road that links [[Rabbiton]] and [[Godsfall]], passing through [[Pilvin Koti]] along the way. Ranging from a well-maintained cobbled road (near [[Rabbiton]]) to a cart tra..."
revision.text:
The road that links [[Rabbiton]] and [[Godsfall]], passing through [[Pilvin Koti]] along the way. Ranging from a well-maintained cobbled road (near [[Rabbiton]]) to a cart track barely wide enough for a full wagon (in the stretch after leaving the [[Sea of Grass]] but before reaching [[Pilvin Koti]]), it's the arterial route for almost all the trade to and from [[Godsfall]]. As such, it is relatively well patrolled and considered "safe" for caravans. The local orcish and [[ihmisi]] tribes have joined agreements to eliminate bandit groups in exchange for payments and guarantees of sovereignty. The [[Godsfall]] branch of the [[Sin Eaters]] also patrol the northern stretch heavily.
[[Category: Duarchy]]

revision.comment: Created page with "The road spur that connects the [[Rabbiton Road]] to [[True Hold]], with a junction near [[Pilvin Koti]]. Winding through the Northern [[Dreamwall Mountains]], it has been imp..."
revision.text:
The road spur that connects the [[Rabbiton Road]] to [[True Hold]], with a junction near [[Pilvin Koti]]. Winding through the Northern [[Dreamwall Mountains]], it has been improved significantly since its creation. The [[Sin Eaters]] patrol it heavily, rousting out bandits and hostile groups. They also prey on "unclean" merchant groups, so only those groups run by humans, elves, or dwarves take that run. Since the founding of [[Honedaxe]] and the creation of the port there in 250 AC, the True Fire Road has seen a precipitous drop in traffic as trade diverts away from [[True Hold]].
[[Category: Duarchy]]

revision.comment: Created page with "The Green Lady and her court are the spiritual center of the northern [[ihmisi]] tribes living in the [[Kotimaa]] region of [[Noefra]]. Chosen from among the tribes by the sha..."
revision.text:
The Green Lady and her court are the spiritual center of the northern [[ihmisi]] tribes living in the [[Kotimaa]] region of [[Noefra]]. Chosen from among the tribes by the shamans, she mediates disputes and is considered a living link to the [[kami]] of the forests. Her court consists of the elder shamans of the tribes.
[[Category: Religion]] [[Category: Duarchy]]

The racial name for the "humanoid" natives of the [[Astral]] Plane. They have two major divisions--angels and devils, based on their primary source of energy. All of the elven races are (distantly) related; the [[lightborn]] were those [[lucians]] who gave up their immortality to settle in the mortal plane after the [[Dawn War]].
Unlike mortals, lucians don't have sparks. Instead, their core is one or more [[True Word]]s that form a true name, surrounded by a nimbus and body of relatively diffuse anima. Made of fragments of the [[True Word]]s of creation, these words describe and constrain the lucian. The name can change based on experiences, but lucians (like all true immortals) are unable to create fundamentally new things themselves. As a result, there is an intense hunger for creative acts of mortals. They all depend on anima produced by mortals for their existence.
The true names, however, also give them a semblance of eternal life--even when discorporated, the words persist unless captured (eg by a [[demon]]). After a time, the words will reform a nimbus and the person will be reborn with a very similar personality; how much of the memory survives depends on how much there was originally (effectively on the "rank" of the lucian). However, having a true name means one can be predicted and bound by that name.
==Angels== Angels are those who have dedicated themselves to the [[Great Mechanism]], serving as a sort of immune system for the universe. For this they gain endless rebirth and eternal youth with a steady stream of anima from the [[Great Mechanism]] itself; they pay with their (eternal) lives. Angels live for nothing but the exercise of their duty; even when relaxing they do so that they may be ready to return to the battlefields.
Their true names tend to reflect concepts such as duty, honor, service, obedience, order, guardianship, stoicism, etc.
==Devils== Devils are those who have chosen (or been forced) to join one of the [[Diabolical Families]]. They chose not to devote themselves such; instead they receive payments for services rendered to the [[Congregation]] or other [[ascendant]]s or for services to mortals as part of contracts.
Their true names tend to reflect the contracts they've made; one who can read the words can tell most of the history of an individual from their name. More powerful devils have longer, more elaborate names.
The forms that devils take on while in the Mortal plane are set by tradition--when acting on the orders of the gods, they tend to take on "angelic" (winged humanoid, emphasis on light and majesty) shapes; when summoned by mortals they take the shape set by the spell. In principle it is possible to summon a high-ranking devil in the form of an imp...but highly not advised. It is difficult and constraining to pour one's essence into such a tiny container. Since devils are frequently summoned for combat, most of their traditional summoned forms are rather martial in nature, designed to frighten and tear apart their foes.
==Chosen== The vast majority of the humanoid population of lucians are neither angels nor devils; they are simply lucians. Vaguely elf-like in appearance (to mortal eyes, anyway), they tend to the angels and devils and get paid their necessary energy for that service.
==Non-humanoid== Most lucians aggregate into non-humanoid shapes ranging all over the spectrum from small "rabbits" and even plants to the colossal Astral Dragons (which aren't really dragons) that dominate the skies of [[Naga Padoha]]. These consume each other, tearing apart the nimbus for the stored energy within. When they die, they reform in a different shape. Rarely, one will decide to leave this life and swear to a [[Diabolical Families|infernal family]] or to an [[angels|angelic host]] or even to an [[ascendant]] or member of the [[Congregation]]. In doing so, they gain a measure of stability and often a humanoid shape, becoming Chosen.
[[Category: Races]] [[Category: Planes]]

An elderly halfling woman (born 30 Summer Dawning, 195 AC), Rakel is the reigning Duke of the [[Farthingale Duchy]] as well as yarl of [[Bradavon]].
==Politics== An arch traditionalist and extremely devout in the [[Church of the Seasons]] (Dreamshore branch), Rakel strongly believes that everyone should follow the will of the gods. She maintains a small coterie of priests as her most influential advisors. She is also strongly expansionist, although she focuses mostly on increasing the population of her duchy. She is distrustful of outsiders, arcane magic, and "innovation". Adventurers and adventuring are highly disfavored. She strongly favors women, both politically and personally. While she has children, she currently does not have a husband.
===Relationships with other dukes=== ; Eastmountain : Strongly antagonistic. ; Eastwalk : Allies. ; Pactum : Dislike, but not open hatred. ; Rabbit Lake : Despises, considers her a "loose hussy with no sense of propriety." ; Westmountain : Disdain. Barely considers him (or his duchy) a real place.
===Relationships with other nations=== ; [[Rauviz]] : Likes the trade. Hates the "loose morals." ; [[Holy Kaelthian Republic]] : Strong approval, although not as much the socio-political as the cultural aspect. ; [[Crisial Kingdom]] : Distrust. Especially of elves and goblins. ; [[Kotimaa]] : Tolerates, but not very well.
==Children== She has only one matriarch daughter, [[Sarah Bradavon Farthingale]] and no sons. She adopted [[Nyx Astra]] into the Bradavon Farthingales, but has had to disavow her after she fled in the wake of the destruction of the [[Cherry Blossom Temple]]. While she gave birth to several [[halflings|kliba]], they are not counted as her daughters, by longstanding [[halflings|halfling]] custom. She has no living sons.
==Heir== At the current time, her heir is her daughter [[Sarah Bradavon Farthingale]], although Rakel does not particularly like Sarah, nor does she trust her to carry on her legacy. She's looking for a new "foster daughter" to carry on her name, if not her line.
==Personality and appearance== Rakel is elderly and somewhat infirm, walking with a cane. She always wears a visible holy symbol of the Four around her neck. Wears high-necked wool gowns, usually in fairly drab colors. Does not wear notable jewelry. Her personality is acerbic and she peppers her conversation with invocations of the Four, especially [[Melara]] and [[Loran Hae]] and only very rarely [[Sakara]], who she thinks is a bit silly.
;Ideal: Tradition. The old ways are the best ways. ;Bond: I do the will of the gods. ;Flaw: I lose out on a lot of good talent by disregarding the contributions of males. ;Alignment: Lawful Neutral
[[Category: Halflings]] [[Category: Duarchy]]

revision.comment: /* Children */
revision.text:
Daughter and heir to [[Rakel Farthingale]]. Born 26 Autumn Dawning 210 AC, she never really had much connection to the [[Council Lands]] system and has always been wealthy and influential. Her primary motivations are money and adulation. She wears only the finest gowns, spends lavishly on parties, makeup, and "boys", and generally acts as if she has no care for anything.
==Children== She has two matriarch daughters, Leni (age 28) and Vica (age 25) and one son. The daughters take after their mother, although Vica is quite religious. Although her religious bent does not comfort her grandmother--she's a temple courtesan and priest of the [[Aerielara|Jeweled Lady]] in [[Baile Craan]]. The son was married off to an Eastwalk clan.
[[Category: Duarchy]] [[Category: Halflings]]

revision.comment: Added banners
revision.text:
[[File:Farthingale banner.png|thumb|Banner of the dukes of Farthingale]] The central, most heavily populated Duchy of [[Dreamshore]]. It covers the area from the [[Craan River]] along the foot of the [[Dreamwall Mountains]] west to the [[Cragholm River]] and includes most of the major cities and towns of [[Dreamshore]]. It is ruled by Duke [[Rakel Farthingale]] from [[Bradavon]].
==Counties== The counties are named after their seats, which are the largest town or city within the boundaries and the residence of the ruling yarl.
; [[Baile Craan]] : The capital county of [[Dreamshore]]. Ruled by Lady [[Coldwind]], it is only technically part of the duchy and does not actually pay any tribute. Borders are from the [[Craan River]] and running west until the [[Westmont River]] and one day's journey into the [[Dreamwall Mountains]], making an overall triangular shape roughly 62 miles north/south by 50 miles east west at the widest point. Total land area: 1550 sq. mi. Total population: ~50k (~20k in the city itself). ; [[Montavon]] : [[File:Farthingale heir banner.png|thumb|Banner of the Farthingale heir]]Ruled by the [[ihmisi]] Piela il Koa, this northern border county is the least well-connected of the counties of Farthingale, as well as the most rural. Montavon itself is a small city of only 3,000 people, and the northern lands are sparsely populated. It extends roughly along the mountain line from the [[Westmont River]] until the [[Cragholm Range]] and stretches south roughly half-way to [[Bradavon]]. Its people are hardy sheepfarmers and some of the most insular and backward people of the [[Duarchy]]. It's said that their family trees are more like family thorn bushes. ; [[Northaven]] : Anchored by the large trading town of [[Northaven]], this county has grown wealthy off of trade coming down from [[Cragholm]] and along the [[North Sheep Road]]. Ruled by [[Dorothea Northaven Farthingale]], it's the least traditional and hidebound of the counties. ; [[Bradavon]] : The seat of the duchy, Bradavon is dominated by [[halflings]] and apiaries, making it the sugar capital of the [[Sea of Grass]], as well as a significant source of mead for the region. Ruled by Duke [[Rakel Farthingale]] as her personal fief, it is hyper traditional and one of the worst places to be a male, especially if you're a halfling. It's also intensely religious, rivaling the [[Holy Kaelthian Republic]] in that respect. ; [[Bradford]] : The smallest county, it's the only one that borders another country (the [[Holy Kaelthian Republic]]). Noted for wool production. Located at the juncture of the [[Eastwalk River]] and [[Cragholm River]] as well as the joining of the [[North Sheep Road]] and the [[Bee Road]], it commands much of the trade through the region and is one of the wealthier counties. Currently without a permanent jarl after the death of the former jarl (who was killed in the destruction of the [[Cherry Blossom Temple]], which stood nearby) and the flight of [[Nyx Astra]] after being implicated in that destruction. The acting ruler is Rachael Bradford Farthingale, the daughter of the former yarl. She is not eligible for the post for health reasons.
==Demographics== * ~50% halfling (especially Bradavon & Bradford counties) * ~30% human and [[half-elves|earth-kin]]. * ~10% [[ihmisi]] * ~10% [[dwarves]]

The city of Bradavon is the among the largest in [[Dreamshore]], and the center of [[halfling]] life in the [[Duarchy]]. Ruled by Duke [[Rakel Farthingale]], it is the working capital of [[Farthingale Duchy]].
==Population== Home to roughly 6,000 people, Bradavon is a sprawling city that is more akin to a cluster of large villages. Each of the halfling families that reside has their own section of the city, while the non-halfling population shares one section and the central core.
* ~70% halfling * ~30% [[half-elves|earth-kin]]. Humans are rare due to the prevalent wall-builder human allergy to bee venom.
==Economy== Bradavon is the honey capital of Western Noefra, and its apiaries keep the city buzzing. Large fields of clover and other flowers around and outside of town make it one of the more lively and attractive towns. If you can fit into the buildings, most of which are halfling-size. Significant amounts of mead are also produced here. Trade upriver with [[Montavon]], [[Baile Craan]], and [[Eastavon]], as well as downstream with [[Bradford]] produces significant wealth as well.

revision.comment: /* Lasting Changes */
revision.text:
The [[Vault Seekers]], drawn by the lure of treasure, the mystery of the [[mysterium magicii]], and guided by the duplicitous [[Rikhards Freiborgs]], sought out the other orbs and entered the [[Vault of Kings]]. Cleansing the [[Awakener]] corruption at the heart, they engaged the self-destruct mechanism and escaped, leading the remaining uncorrupted [[peiriant gnome]]s, also known as mecha-gnomes to freedom and a new home in the [[Crisial Kingdom]]. They then turned the tables on [[Rikhards Freiborgs]] and his [[Imperial Sons]] goons, ending that threat.
==Notable events== # Assisting [[Englathyn]] from the forces harassing that village. ## Defeated the evil alchemist [[Saerev of Godsfall]] whose altered grubs were inducing madness and rage in the local wildlife. ## Defeated the bandit forces hired by the [[Imperial Sons]] to draw attention away from their search for the [[mysterium magicii]]. ## Explored the [[Markov Crypt]], recovering the first of the [[mysterium magicii]] from the grasp of the undead guardians. # Return to [[Godsfall]] ## Meeting [[Rikhards Freiborgs]], posing as a researcher with the [[Guardians of the Forgotten]] and learning of the [[Vault of Kings]] ## Divining the locations of the other [[mysterium magicii]] ## Joining [[Imperial Legacy]] # Exploring [[Novaestium]] ## Gaining passage from [[Rabbiton]] from lady [[Kati Rabbit Lake]], daughter of Duke [[Kella Rabbit Lake]], and a notable freebooter on [[Lake Coy'in]]. ## Entering the Falcon Tower, dealing with hazards such as hostile [[ika-ika]] and morey eels ## Exploring the memories of [[Broken Trust]] ## Defeating the Remnant of Broken Trust ## Retrieving the second [[mysterium magicii]] from the vaults ## Freeing 20 time-lost children from stasis # Back to [[Godsfall]], this time to buy a farm for (barbarian)'s family in [[Elysium]] ## Dealing with unwelcome attention ## Dealing with the [[Landlord]], placing [[Novaestium]] and the family farm in his control in exchange for protection # Exploring [[Tsagaz]] ## Travel to [[True Hold]], negotiations for a ship ## Befriending the [[Yavakh]] ## Bamboozling the [[Uldekh]] ## Defeating [[Morlan Metalbender]] and retrieving the third of the [[mysterium magicii]] ## Betraying the [[Uldekh]] and destroying the memory machine ## Encounter on the high seas, helping [[Morgan]] and his crew escape to [[Honedaxe]] # Return to [[Godsfall]], growing suspicions about [[Rikhards Freiborgs]] # Side trip to the [[Lost Gods' Reliquary]] under [[Abaddon]]. # To [[Talvi]] ## Working with [[Kati Rabbit Lake]] again ## Meeting the Guardian ## Delving through that cursed place ## Showdown with [[Juubokai]] ## Escaping the crumbling ruin with the final [[mysterium magicii]] # Detour to [[Crisial of the Four Towers]], meeting [[Queen Raanee]]. # Into the Vault ## Entrance and uncorrupted [[peiriant gnome]]s. ## Fighting through the corruption with [[Adam of the Golden Army]]'s help ## Showdown at the core with the [[Awakener]] corruption ## End of the Vault # Showdown on the North Shore, [[Rikhards Freiborgs]] tricked into trying to open the (now destroyed) Vault with (fake) [[mysterium magicii]] after much blood magic. Bad things happen, ritual backfires and converts him into undead/demon thing. He gets punked. Players drop a direball (fireball, except it's a giant stone soccer ball) on his compound.
==Lasting Changes== * Destruction of [[Talvi]] forces [[Vetal]]'s hand. She tries to crack down on the [[Horse Clans]], but ends up sparking rebellion and refugees. * Introduction of the [[peiriant gnome]]s * Biomagical augmentations (not done yet) * The [[Sons of Air]] (the party, plus some other willing souls) start hunting for the [[Imperial Sons]], killing them wherever they find them. This causes political messes.
==Timeline== ; Start : Mid spring, 250 AC ; End : Mid summer, 250 AC

revision.text:
Four orbs, each about large softball sized, metal, made of layers of wire. Around equator is a ring with many symbols, one serving as a direction arrow. When the direction arrow is brought to point in particular directions, one of the symbols starts to glow. Each of the three special directions corresponds to a different symbol, indicating the direction to another orb. When brought together and placed in a special framework, the four of them serve as the key to open the portal to the [[Vault of Kings]].
In reality, they are massive arcane batteries, refilling over centuries from ambient magic. The [[Vault of Kings]] can be opened without them, given enough energy (requiring mass [[blood magic]] to accomplish).
==Current Location== Drained of their power by opening the [[Vault of Kings]] for the [[Vault Seekers]] as well as 4 days of "firework shows" over [[Lake Coy'in]], they have been split up and sent to various parts of the [[Crisial Kingdom]] and other locations around western [[Noefra]]. By intent, no single person knows where all four are located.
[[Category: Artifacts]]

A pre-cataclysm dwarven ruin, located on what is now an island in the [[Sea of Dreams]]. Once owned by the [[Bargachin]] clan (a thoroughly heterodox clan). Not a clan hold, but a research facility into construct-based immortality. They built humanoid-ish constructs (like the soul-forged bodies, except more mechanistic). Tried to bring them to life by transferring minds into them, mostly failed (transferred memories and fragmentary personalities, but not the soul or the will). Some have now, post [[Fourth Wish]], come to life of their own.
Previously populated by three factions of constructs--the [[Yavakh]], the [[Uldekh]], and the Unawoken. The Unawoken were unthinking constructs that cannibalized the awoken ones, controlled by [[Morlan Metalbender]]. With his destruction, their threat is ended.
Explored by the [[Vault Seekers]] in summer 250 AC, after which only a few of the [[Uldekh]] remain. The majority were slain in combat with the Unawoken and the [[Vault Seekers]]. The [[Yavakh]] have decamped to [[Honedaxe]].

Five awakened, dwarven constructs imbued with memories and personalities copied from dwarves of the [[Bargachin]] clan, now dead for centuries. Philosophical and harmless, they originated in [[Tsagaz]] but have taken up residence in [[Honedaxe]] after the intervention of the [[Vault Seekers]] in 250 AC.
==Dramatis Personae== ; Yavakh Raz : leader. Prone to wax philosophical about the nature of existence. ; Yavakh Dva : Underling. Likes word games. ; Yavakh Tri : Underling. Artist. ; Yavakh Quat : Underling. Neurotic. ; Yavakh Pyat : Youngest. Most prone to actually doing things.

A "tribe" of awakened dwarven mechanicals that lived in [[Tsagaz]] from ~248 - 250 AC. Most were killed by the [[Vault Seekers]] as part of their search for the third of the [[mysterium magicii]]; the remainder still haunt the ruins.
They were made before the [[Cataclysm]] by the dwarven engineers, but awakened only a few years ago. They possess memory fragments (more fragmentary than the [[Yavakh]]) of those dwarves. They worship the Machine God, as exemplified by the memory-transfer machine that was used in their creation. After that was destroyed in 250 AC, the survivors have become quite aimless.

revision.comment: Created page with "Daemonhost are mortals (usually humans or orcs) who have been bound to a [[jotnar]] while still alive. Unlike one of the true [[demons]], they do not have control of this para..."
revision.text:
Daemonhost are mortals (usually humans or orcs) who have been bound to a [[jotnar]] while still alive. Unlike one of the true [[demons]], they do not have control of this parasite. Creation of daemonhost is taboo in most cultures; only the [[Dead Walker]]s of the [[Great Eastern Dustlands]] perform this ritual en masse.
Two main groupings exist--those that have formed a reciprocal bond and those for whom the parasite merely provides power until it erupts from them as a full demon on their death. The first gain increased strength, demonic weapons and powerful abilities, but merely die when killed. The second are little better than walking carriers, apt to burst into demon form when slain.
Different types of daemonhosts exist, but the most common are the "raging" ones, those created by cultists of the [[Red Fang]]. They emphasize brute strength and acid claws, along with insane ferocity.
[[Category: Monsters]]

A group of nihilistic demon worshippers who prowl the most blasted parts of the [[Great Eastern Dustlands]] immediately surrounding [[Mt. Fearg]]. Most of them were dusters who were kicked out of their original tribes (or left). They worship the Dead God, a being they believe lives on [[Mt. Fearg]] in the old ruins. They've all given themselves to blood rites, including accepting bound demons. Many are [[daemonhost]].
They live by raiding the tribes and farmers that live around the blasted lands surrounding [[Mt. Fearg]], especially the [[Dugai]] tribe. There are lords of the lands near [[Shaadval]] who use them to raid northward, preventing the [[Hagfen]] from expanding (about the only good they do). They do herd [[wiresheep]] and [[trikine]] (both mutated creatures) and sell the [[wirewool]] from the sheep and incendiary "milk" from the cows, distilling a form of lamp fuel from it.
Their leader is the dread warlord [[Gorrosh]], thought to be immortal (since he's been killed many times, yet has always resurfaced). He is a gigantic (~8' tall), purple-eyed orc who wields the greataxe [[Bloodstorm]], said to have belonged to the [[Red Fang]] before his demonic transformation.

They also raise sheep in the western reaches of the [[Great Eastern Dustlands]].

revision.comment: Created page with "One of the relics of the Creator, supposedly. Legends paint it as a quill pen the size of a tall man's outstretched arm, said to be a feather of the Creator itself. When you p..."
revision.text:
One of the relics of the Creator, supposedly. Legends paint it as a quill pen the size of a tall man's outstretched arm, said to be a feather of the Creator itself. When you pick it up, spectral tendrils reach out and latch onto your arm; you write in the ink of your own existence.
What is known is the following: * Under appropriate conditions (which are not generally known), this artifact draws in candidates from all over the world to the [[Eternal Library]] in [[Tal Elamor]]. * From those candidates, one gains the chance to wield the pen and write a Wish. * In doing so, they cease to ever have existed. Everything that they did and said was done by someone else; all memory of them is erased as if it never existed. Only the Wish remains. * Writers can fail; if they do, they cease from existence but the Wish is malformed and rejected, of no effect. * The Wishes so written change the fundamental rules by which the [[Great Mechanism]] orders creation. Wishes that conflict with other directives or would leave the world in an inconsistent state are rejected; the writer and Wish has failed. * Four such wishes have been successfully written throughout the ages (see [[Ages of the World]] for details). * Once used, the Cosmic Forge becomes inert until its activation time looms again.

; Headwaters : NW of [[Cragholm]] in the [[Dreamwall Mountains]]. ; Mouth : empties into the [[Craan River]] near [[Bradford]]
Entirely within the [[Duarchy of Kotimaa]], it is a significant vector of trade, second to the [[Craan River]]. Mostly wood products heading downstream and other goods flowing upstream. Navigable all the way to just below [[Cragholm]] itself, the river is wide and placid for much of its length.

revision.text:
Located in the north-eastern portion of [[Noefra]], south of the [[Northern Frostlands]], NE of the [[Great Eastern Dustlands]], N of [[Shaanti]], and east of [[Nirda]], the Hagfen is an aggressive region of swamps, moors, and wild vegetation. It seems to act as a single lifeform, always trying to expand its borders. Outsiders are very not welcome--the land itself rises against them with strangling vines, moving swamp channels, and relentless attacks from both the residents and the wildlife (acting in concert).
It gets its name because the [[Mother Tree]] at the center of the fen is the patron of all [[hags]] and [[witchlings]], trading long life and power in exchange for their hearts, replaced by a parasitic fruit that feeds on particular emotions, transmitting them to the tree. Most hags, however, have never been to the fen itself; they contact the tree via rituals and dreams and the exchange is made via mystic means.

Second largest "landmass" in the [[Astral]] Plane. An irregular plate roughly 100 million times the surface area of [[Quartus]], it is home to millions of [[lucian]]s as well as beasts. Harsh and desert-like wherever it isn't untamed jungle, there are only a few "cities". The largest of which, [[Tsabalamak]], is centered around the [[Grand Arena]].
It is home to [[Tor-Elan]], [[Roel Kor]], [[Korokonolkom]], and the [[Hollow King]]. Here is found the headquarters of the fiendish territory of [[Chou]].

revision.comment: /* Neighbors */
revision.text:
A city located at the western edge of the [[Great Eastern Dustlands]]. Once known as the "Bridge between East and West," it was the chokepoint through which all east-west trade flowed during the latter half of the [[Ages of the World|Third Age]]. But its glory days are well behind it, and the decline is not solely due to the Cataclysm and attendant disruptions. [[Quan Pei]] which once dominated the entire eastern half of the continent had been in decadent decline for generations even before that, and the trade routes had become progressively more dangerous (and as a result less traveled) for about a hundred years. By 50 BC, the high roads and desert waystations had fallen into almost total disrepair and duster tribes had abandoned their treaty obligations to protect travelers (just as their reciprocal rights of trade and aid had been neglected). By 200 AC, the city's permanent population had dropped from nearly 100,000 to a mere 4,000. Over the following 50 years, the city has somewhat recovered as a home for mercenary groups who hire out in the bordering provinces of the [[Jinse Empire]] and [[Shaanti]] border protectorates, as well as who fight in the northern frontier vs the [[Hagfen]]. Its current permanent population is about 8,000, with another 2-3k mercenaries during the off season.
By treaty with its neighbors, Shaadval is neutral grounds. It stretches approximately two days ride (~60 miles) around the Triune Oasis that serves as the city's heart.
==Demographics== The permanent population is broken out as follows: * ~3500 humans and human-dominant crossbreeds. Use the Jinse phenotype (vaguely asian/feather indian look, tall, dark hair, medium-brown skin). Red hair and red-toned skin relatively common. Also heavily crossbred with ihmisi and orcs. * ~1500 tieflings * ~1200 ihmisi (and ihmisi-dominant crossbreeds). Darker and less forest-oriented, they've lost most of their kami worship and worship ancestors and devils. * ~1000 goblinoids. Relatively civilized. * ~800 orcs (and orc-dominant crossbreeds). Strong honor culture.
==Culture== * Strong family/clan honor culture. Don't disrespect the elders. Polygyny is common (well more like concubinage + the male equivalent, generally temporary). Large age differences between dominant and less dominant partners are common (girls being married/given at puberty to a man in his 40s or 50s, boys in their teens being given to a woman in her 40s-60s). Children born of these concubines belong to the dominant partner's family, and such arrangements generally last only a few years. Some poorer families will serially sell their attractive children to several more powerful clans in turn in return for dowries. Concubines are generally treated well. * Debt peonage is common, but non-generational. Maximum time limit (by law) of 7 years, although many end up getting hired back by that family again or marrying into the family. Not considered super shameful. * Strong hospitality rules, especially among the Suu (and related clans). Sharing water is a covenant of peace…for a while. * Devious infighting among clans behind smiling faces. Poison and assassins are not uncommon. Killed if caught, but that's about all. * Essentially no nudity taboo inside. Relatively promiscuous. Use of magic/herbs to prevent disease & pregnancy is very common. But by consent only. Rape or assault is punished heavily (an eye or a hand) * Petty thievery is common and harshly punished if caught. But most don't take strong measures. The [[Uuru]] (thieves' guild) protects and polices their own. * Scrupulous and fair, if hard bargained trade. Cheating is punished by exile or execution, especially cheating by adulteration of product or magical compulsion. Triumvirate guards (mostly Zhuun) watch the markets. * Laws govern magic use. The Akild (Wise Ones) watch over and look for cases of magical compulsion or other such things. Known as the Red Robes (for the red robes and masks that they wear).
==Government== Shaadval is governed by a Triumvirate--the family heads of the three most powerful noble families working together. The other noble families are mostly clients of these three. As of 250 AC, the Triumvirate is comprised of * Ivars Zhuun (Lord Wool). The oldest of the three at 67, he remembers the disruption caused by the Dragonbotherers and is inclined not to trust adventurers. His chosen area of responsibility is trade. He has ties to the dragon-led nations to the south. * Y'leni Bolota (Lord Steel). At 37, Y'leni is a hard-bitten woman who took leadership of her family after assassins (believed to be in the pay of Lord Shu of neighboring Shu Province) killed her parents when she was only 15. She believes in strength first. She has very few compunctions in playing the Great Game. She is largely responsible for interfacing with the mercenary companies. * Maksim Suu (Lord Water). 38 years old, Maksim is of nomad blood (as is his Suu family, which traditionally takes wives from the neighboring duster tribes). He chafes somewhat at the Great Game. A highly honorable man, he believes in omens and traditions. His primary concern is the [[Dead Walkers]].
==Mercenary Companies== Four major companies of various sizes call Shaadval home base and have some sort of continual presence in the immediate area. Others, as well as free-lance mercenary bands, also have presence in the city. The four major companies are * Gar'ok's Sappers. A specialized engineering company made up of orcs and goblinoids. At only 150 actives, they're the smallest of the companies. Only a few of them are currently present--most are involved in the siege at [[Jin Ro'pal]]. A brass gear on black, with a lit fuse * [[Hoof and Bow]]. A specialized skirmisher double-company. A group of [[ihmisi]], they're related to the Altai and draw their recruits from there. 450 effectives, plus another 150 horsebreakers. They're in town after an early-spring campaign against incursions from [[Shaera]] into [[Shu Province]]. A hoof and a bow. * Kalkan's Foot. A combined arms battalion (850 effectives). Traditionally strongest as heavy infantry, they've also acquired archer and skirmisher companies recently. Currently mustering out for an extended campaign on the border of the [[Hagfen]] on behalf of [[Shaanti]]. Iron cross, black on red. * Rorlo's Raiders. A rough, somewhat cobbled-together group known for their effective use of magic and their lack of scruples as to jobs they take. About 500 effectives. Currently between contracts, they took this year off after a major contract the previous year. A key, white on black. Usually wear a tattoo.
==Neighbors== * [[Shu Province]]. While technically part of the [[Jinse Empire]], they only pay token respect to the capital. One common property they have is their ready acceptance of diabolical aid. Constantly involved in border squabbles with the neighboring Shaanti Zhao Protectorate. Currently in possession of [[Jin Ro'pal]], a fortress city surrounded by [[Shaanti]] territory. * [[Zhao Protectorate]] . Formerly part of Jinse, the Zhao rebelled and went over to [[Shaanti]] about 30 years ago. Not entirely cohesive, but backed by some very wealthy individuals. Continual struggles with Shu Province. They are allies with the [[Azeri]] and both contribute men and equipment in the containment efforts against the [[Hagfen]] to the north. * [[Altai]]. [[Ihmisi]] tribal confederation. Horse and sheep. More tied in with civilization than most. Due to poorer lands, they hire many of their people out as mercenaries. * [[Chuvashka]]. The traditional allies of Shaadval among the duster tribes. Detest the Dead Walkers, as they continually lose people to the heretics. * [[Azeri]]. Orcs. Very superstitious. Militant and proud warriors. Don't mind the Dead Walkers all that much and are one of the few who willingly cooperate with them against the Hagfen. * [[Dugai]]. A dying tribe, squeezed from all sides. Their only refuge is a rich oasis hidden in the broken lands. [[Peharzh]] in particular pushes on them, and weak leadership in the past has led many to defect either north or south. * [[Bashkai]]. Once part of Dugai, they broke off about 40 years ago. They hate dragons. * [[Pelotai]]. Orcs. Consider themselves the "true heirs" of [[Red Fang|Gromash]]. Honorable but brutal. * [[Peharzh]]. Ruled by two dragon flights under the leadership of Pehar (an ancient Copper), the Peharzh tribes are aggressive and uncompromising. They'll take anyone that is willing to fight. * [[Shaera]]. A pair of flights led by two ancients ([[Shar]], an ancient blue and [[Erai]], an adult Gold), they've actually made somewhat of a civilization out of local goblinoid and human tribes. After the idiotic behavior of the [[Dragonbotherers]], they have lost trust in outsiders. This trust was mostly restored by [[Enigma]] in late summer 250 AC. They regularly raid their neighbors and demand tribute (which Shaadval pays). * [[Dead Walkers]]. Not direct neighbors, but their presence warps local politics.

==Southern lair== Location: in the desert * [[Shar]] (ancient blue male) ** Hoard: Silver ** Personality: Lazy, but ferocious when roused. ;Numbers: 300 effectives. About 600 women and children and elderly. ;Culture: Value strength above all. Brutal raiders, preferring direct physical combat. Status within the tribe by surviving/winning brawls. Not particularly underhanded. Women and children are non-persons and possessions, to be used by any who can. And if you can't protect your possessions, they belong to those who can take them.
As of late summer 250 AC, they were much more scarce than usual, as is their master, the adult black dragon [[Peharzh|Iruk]].

revision.text:
Ascended heroes are those (former) mortals who have become resident in the [[Astral]] by trading their mortality for a dependence on worship. They serve as "gods" to many of the cultures.
==Rules== # Ascended heroes can only be in one place at a time; they cannot create avatars. Thus, if they are destroyed anywhere, they are destroyed everywhere. # Ascended heroes can only interact across planar boundaries with mortals that worship them--there must be a pre-existing tie, voluntarily established by the mortal. # Ascended heroes cannot annoint clerics, they can only teach spells and enter into pacts. # The power of an ascended hero is directly proportional to the worship. Without worship, they must find another source of power to continue existence (ie become a devil or an angel or a demon). # Ascended heroes *can* be proactive and *can* discriminate based on style of worship # Ascended heroes are influenced by their worship and become the thing that their worshipers believe they are.
==Notable Heroes== * The [[Queen Ascendant]] * [[Nocthis]]
[[Category:Ascended Heroes]]

A tribal confederation of [[Dusters]]. Once one of the more prosperous (for [[Dusters]]) tribes, they controlled a large portion of the east-west trade route through the [[Great Eastern Dustlands]]. When trade between [[Quan Pei]] and the west became moribund, they started on a decline. By 200 AC, they had suffered under weak leadership for several generations. The [[Bashkai]] split off in 210, taking most of the more forward-looking members. Tribes under [[Peharzh]] started raiding them, and with the resurgence in the [[Dead Walkers]] over the last 30 years, things have become quite dire for the Dugai. Only two of the tribes remain, and they only retain two strongholds. The first is the [[Dugai Oasis]] in the northern regions and the second is a hidden oasis in the center of their territory.
The northern tribal group is led by [[Azhtar Cai'Valur]], who had married [[Naomi of the Dugai]], the daughter of a Dugai chieftain. After she was slain by [[Dead Walkers]], he left to take his son, [[Ahzekiel Cai'Valur]] to safety. He later returned seeking vengeance against the one who commanded the assault.

revision.comment: Created page with "The counterpart to [[Tibor Imperia]] on the eastern half of [[Noefra]] during the [[Ages of the World|Third Age]]. Unlike that western empire, Quan Pei did not fall until the..."
revision.text:
The counterpart to [[Tibor Imperia]] on the eastern half of [[Noefra]] during the [[Ages of the World|Third Age]]. Unlike that western empire, Quan Pei did not fall until the [[Cataclysm]] ripped their god-kings out from under them. And even then, the [[Jinse Empire]] has good claim to be the successor to that great empire.
Ruled by a succession of gods-made-flesh (actually mortals worshiped as deities) who claimed to speak for the [[Golden Aspects]], Quan Pei was both aristocracy and theocracy. Divided into a multitude of provinces ruled by bureaucrats and relatives of the god-emperors, it muddled along for millennia without serious incident. After initial unsuccessful attempts to expand into the [[Dragonreach]], a treaty was formed between the flights of that area and the god-emperors.
The capital was always at [[Jinse City|the Golden City]], now known as [[Jinse City]].
[[Category: Nations]] [[Category: Noefra]]

revision.comment: Created page with "One-in-four and four-in-one, the Aspects were among the [[Old Gods]]. Worshiped as the "only true gods" by [[Quan Pei]] and its god-emperors, they represented creation, Fate,..."
revision.text:
One-in-four and four-in-one, the Aspects were among the [[Old Gods]]. Worshiped as the "only true gods" by [[Quan Pei]] and its god-emperors, they represented creation, Fate, Preservation, and Destruction as aspects of one being while simultaneously having multiple forms. Unlike the other [[Old Gods]], they were not completely absorbed by the [[Great Mechanism]] at the [[Cataclysm]]. Instead, they merged with that mechanism, becoming the [[Voice of the Great Mechanism]], the one responsible for choosing the [[Congregation]] and assigning them their tasks as well as promulgating the new rules of existence.
[[Category: Gods]]

revision.comment: Created page with "A fey formed by the union of a [[Byssia]]n girl who was murdered by drowning out of jealousy and a river [[kami]]. Spent decades tempting men in and drowning them, then fell i..."
revision.text:
A fey formed by the union of a [[Byssia]]n girl who was murdered by drowning out of jealousy and a river [[kami]]. Spent decades tempting men in and drowning them, then fell in love with [[Dhu'gula]], mainly because he was interested in her, not in anything sexual. In fact, he was utterly blind to any advances. Followed him across the land, and was eventually entombed in one of the inner barrows of the [[Pactum Battlefield]] in an enchanted sleep. Awakened by true-love's kiss (well...sort of), delivered by [[Walker]] who was possessed by [[Dhu'gula]] at that point.
She currently wanders with the lich and [[soul-forged]], channeling nature's power to keep [[Dhu'gula]] fed without him having to eat souls. She only cares for him.
==Personality== Obsessive stalker. Eyes only for her beloved. ; Bond: [[Dhu'gula]]. ; Ideal: Love ; Flaw: Incapable of seeing anything but [[Dhu'gula]]'s happiness. And he's incapable of truly loving her back. ; Alignment: N

The successor to [[Quan Pei]]. Centered around [[Jinse City]] on the eastern edge of the [[Noefra]]n continent. Ancient, enormous, corrupt, and degenerate. The empire is mostly notional at this point (250 AC), with the outer provinces using the name but only paying token tribute and attention to the center. Worship of and pacts with devils are very common; the empire is ruled by half-devils and fiend-born humans.
==Provinces== * [[Shu Province]] -- far western edge near [[Shaadval]]. [[Category:Jinse Empire]]

[[File:Tal-elamor.webp|frameless|1024x1024px]]
The city of magic. The home of the [[Eternal Library]]. Oldest city on the planet. Myth. Legend. Does it still exist? Sages believe that it can never be truly destroyed. But no one from the west has been there (or at least has returned from there) since the [[Cataclysm]].
== Locations Ca 252 AC ==
# Mekanix Workshop. Does it need to be mechanical? They make it. Including a bunch of things that probably shouldn't be mechanical. # Kaz Rodan Smithery. All things hammered. # Arin Kao Telecommunications and Transportation. We can get it there or tell you about it. As long as you don't ''really'' need it to be in one piece... # Assisted Thaumaturgics. For all your will-probably-blow-up experimentation needs, at least the ones made out of metal, crystal, or wood. # Corpus Sanum. True power comes from within, mostly by lifting weights. # Pan-aetheric Unity. All things are one thing, except when they're different things. # Mentis. True power comes from within, mostly by thinking about moving things. # Dualistics. All things are different things, except when they're the same things. # Temple of Self. True divinity lies within, we just haven't managed to dig it out yet. # Temple of Fur. True divinity lies within cats, and we can prove it. Formerly sponsored by Absurdism, Inc, until it turned out to be more true than an absurd hypothesis. # Top Alembic Recreational. Duuuuuuuude. # Warin's Mutagenics. Don't like how you look? We can help. May take several tries, side effects may apply. # Alia's Medicinals. We fix you up after you blew yourself up. # Parin Chemical Supply. For all your will-probably-blow-up experimentation needs, at least the ones made out of liquids, gasses, or violently-bubbling concoctions. # Annex. Everyone who wishes entry to the [[Eternal Library]] must check in here and meet the Caretaker of that place.
== Population == Inside the city: ~3k
Outwall Farms: ~5k
== Notable People ==
# The Caretaker. An amalgam of the people who have gained borrowing privileges (and thus left a copy of their personalities and memories at the library). Not a real ensouled person, but is the personification of the [[Eternal Library]]. Considered to be as unkillable as the library itself. Pissing him off is a bad idea. # Arni Black-egg. Ancient black [[Dragons|dragon]], nearly 500 years old. Has been resident in Tal Elamor most of that time. Prefers the shape of a 5'2", 100 lb black-haired woman who rules Corpus Sanum with an iron fist. Also a proficient mage, but prefers to lift weights. # [[Rhys]]. [[Undead|Lich]] and elemental mage. Unaligned, he doesn't belong to any of the factions. # Gorgias Empiricus. Human male, 40s. Near archmage, leads Mentis. Strongly dislikes Arni. # Haile Rastafa. Human female, 30s. Head of Tope Alembic Recreational.

It collapsed in 250 AC after [[Juubokai]] was destroyed.

revision.text:
First and current queen of [[Crisial Kingdom]]. An [[aelvar]] noble born before [[Moon's Vengeance]], she was trapped out of time by a [[concept bombs|concept bomb]] until rescued by [[Dimwit Syndicate]] in 211 AC. She then became a notable adventurer and one of the group that cleared the grounds of the [[Crystal Spire]].
Physically, she's still very young (only in her 50s) and appears to be about 18. Considered extremely beautiful by the [[gwerin]], she is a wizard of some repute as well. She has not married, although pressure on her to do so is extreme.
Politically, she's just and fair, if sometimes a bit naïve. She's trying to make [[Crisial Kingdom]] a place of acceptance and peace for all, while favoring trade. She strongly believes in equal rights for all (even [[gwerin]] females and [[halfling]] males). She is '''highly''' opposed to necromancy, demon worship, or anything that smacks of magical oppression.
;Bond: The kingdom is mine, I will do what I can to protect and guide it. ;Ideal: Freedom and tolerance. ;Flaw: Tends to be too trusting. ;Alignment: LG
[[Category: Notable People]] [[Category: Crisial Kingdom]]

The event that ended the [[Ages of the World|Second Age]] and shattered the [[aelvar]] empire. Druids, working under the influence of the [[Awakener]], cajoled the Third Moon into leaving its orbit and coming crashing down onto the [[aelvar]] capital. The resulting devastation carved out mountain ranges and trenches in a huge circle around it, which still exist to this day.
;Date: Roughly 3750 BC.
[[Category: Historical Interest]]

An angel of the [[Angels|Second Host, Third Legion]], planetar rank. She was delegated to the [[Pactum Battlefield]] containment project and assigned to guard the phylactery holding [[Atijok]]'s soul. Assigned the code name "Titziba", meaning "Faithful"--she was noted for her absolute dedication to the cause of the Host and the extirpation of evil. Over the two centuries of isolation in the constructed demiplane, this dedication turned to obsession and madness and she began to blame [[Atijok]] for everything.
Her isolation was broken by the [[Heroes of Pactum]], who entered the demiplane and managed to trick her into letting them grab the phylactery. They escaped with her hot on their heels; her attempted revenge was brought to an abrupt stop by the intervention of [[Melara]] and [[Ytra]], who claimed domain rights. When Titziba's madness was revealed, she was cast out of the Host. She then vanished into the mortal world.
The next year, she was encountered by the [[Wild Cards]] at the [[Dead Halls]], an ancient mausoleum high in the [[Giant Spine Mountains]] housing the cursed-into-stone bodies of [[Perkunos]] and [[Tatsuryuu]], where she was employing a form of necromancy to raise an undead army to destroy all life, because out of life comes evil, and evil must be stopped. The heroes put an end to that. In extremis, she called out to [[Oro-laen]], claiming to have been doing "his work." He briefly appeared, only to decry her as having abandoned her duty. This confluence of events was the trigger to awaken the cursed ancients. She died, and her sword (now known as [[Duty Denied]]) became the property of the [[Wild Cards]].
[[Category: Angels]]

A realm of arcane, semi-living machinery, factories, and foundries in the [[Celestial City]]. To some degree, it serves as the heart of the [[Great Mechanism]]--from here the devils of family [[Malphas]] (and much of Territory [[Thoraz]]) and their helpers carry out maintenance across the [[Astral]] Plane. Here as well are the forges and armories of the [[Angels|Angelic Host]], presided over by the 4th Legion of the 1st Host. It is said that there are direct portals from here to angelic outposts throughout the Dream.
Mortal visitors to the [[Machinarium]] are warned that the layout of the streets and buildings is not constant. Those who live here are sensitive to the changes (which follow their own logic and order), but visitors are often lost...or worse when things shift.
;Aspect: Order ;Divine Realms: None
[[Category: Astral]]

This vast wilderness of strange plants and animals is the home to [[Pinwheel]], [[Korokonolkom]], [[Selesurala]], and [[Lae-loara]]. Gigantic seas churning with predators and prey dot the landscape, each many thousands of times the whole surface of Quartus. This is the ur-home of the [[lucian]]s of the [[Astral]]--those that die without enough of a tie to one of the realms reform here, bereft of all but a scrap of memory or personality and take the shape of beasts or strange creatures.
The largest of the domains, Naga Padoha is nearly 250 million times the surface area of [[Quartus]]. It is also the home to most of the [[Ascended heroes]] and also to the strange beasts that prowl the [[astral]] plane. It is the Territory of [[Ka-Kola]].
;Aspect: Nature, Life ;Divine Realms: * [[Pinwheel]]'s [[Carnival of Souls]], a mobile realm. * [[Korokonolkom]]'s mountain fastness of [[Deep Holm]] * [[Selesurala]]'s lair, [[Storm's Reach]] * [[Lae-loara]] prowls this realm, never staying long in one place. ;[[Ascended heroes]]: Most of the [[Honored Ancestors]] of [[Byssia]]'s highland [[ihmisi]] dwell here, among many others.
[[Category: Astral]]

One of the [[Wild Cards]]. Trained by an outlawed assassin cult in the former [[Council Lands]], he abandoned his family to take up adventuring. Now serves as the president of the [[Bank of Zhapai Karmap]], the premier (and only) international banking organization. During [[Finding a Home (Campaign)]], he sat on a chair in [[Creche Skeud]] and had the soul of the long-dead [[chaudeekar]] assassin/spy [[Oulum Meteri]] injected into his. Technically they share the body, but she tends to let him drive. Their personalities are surprisingly compatible, both liking money and having few scruples.
Now in his prime, he travels throughout the [[Federated Nations]] overseeing the bank (but mostly looking for things to "acquire".
;Bond: Gimme all the shinies. ;Ideal: Don't touch me. ;Flaw: Would abandon anyone if threatened or paid. ;Alignment: NE ;Power ranking: Formerly S-class (~level 15 rogue)
[[Category: Zhapai Karmap]] [[Category: Notable People]]

revision.comment: Created page with "A Grand Sapientum of the [[Imperial Sons]]. Obsessed with "bringing the world order" via opening the [[Vault of Kings]] and unleashing the [[Golden Army]] under his control. P..."
revision.text:
A Grand Sapientum of the [[Imperial Sons]]. Obsessed with "bringing the world order" via opening the [[Vault of Kings]] and unleashing the [[Golden Army]] under his control. Posed (successfully) for many years as a sage of the [[Guardians of the Forgotten]], working to dig out information about the location of the [[mysterium magicii]]. Tricked the [[Vault Seekers]] into searching for the artifacts; this backfired when they became suspicious of him and discovered his nefarious ties. He was killed when a blood-soaked ritual he was conducting backfired due to counterfeits of the orbs, turning him into an undead/demon hybrid creature that was then slain by the [[Vault Seekers]].
[[Category: Historical Interest]]

revision.comment: Created page with "A demi-plane/automated factory designed by [[Wayland Smith]] for the early [[aelvar]] emperors. Housed, supported, and maintained the [[Golden Army]]. Labor and maintenance pr..."
revision.text:
A demi-plane/automated factory designed by [[Wayland Smith]] for the early [[aelvar]] emperors. Housed, supported, and maintained the [[Golden Army]]. Labor and maintenance provided by the [[peiriant gnomes]]. Control required a particular bloodline, now extinct with the [[Warden of Talvi]]. Limited access available through the [[Bloodstone Ring]], a failsafe designed to allow someone to shut it down. When the Vault was opened by an unauthorized person, the [[Golden Army]] would rampage, destroying all intelligent life and civilization within 20-30 miles of the location. This was not the original designed behavior, but one of the early effects of contamination by [[Awakener]] influence. It is unknown when this started, but certainly by the dawn of the Third Age.
The last authorized access to the [[Vault of Kings]] was during the mid-[[Ages of the World|Third Age]], when the last of the designated bloodline used the army to chase [[Juubokai]] into the prison known as [[Talvi]] so that he could be imprisoned there. Sometime during the later centuries (likely after the fall of [[Tibor Imperia]]), the vault was re-opened and a massacre ensued. In the aftermath, the [[mysterium magicii]], which served as portal keys to the vault, were split up so that no one else could try.
In 250 AC, the vault was opened via the collected orbs and access granted via the ring to the [[Vault Seekers]], working with Queen [[Raanee]] of [[Crisial Kingdom]] (who provided magical support via her court mages). The party entered the vault, made a deal with the remaining [[peiriant gnomes]] to lead them to safety, penetrated into the core of the vault, destroyed the [[Awakener]], and caused the vault to self destruct. The only member of the [[Golden Army]] to escape was Unit #8675309, who had become self-aware at some point. The uncorrupted gnomes and [[Adam of the Golden Army]], along with the party, managed to escape the destruction.
[[Category: Places]]

revision.comment: Created page with "A army of roughly 100,000 constructs (made of celestite, the same golden-colored "metal" used in the construction of the [[Celestial City]]) created, maintained, and directed..."
revision.text:
A army of roughly 100,000 constructs (made of celestite, the same golden-colored "metal" used in the construction of the [[Celestial City]]) created, maintained, and directed by the [[Vault of Kings]]. Known for being relentless combatants and only obeying members of a particular (now-extinct) bloodline. The appearance of endless numbers comes from the way that the [[Vault of Kings]] replaced lost members almost immediately via portal.
With the destruction of the [[Vault of Kings]] in 250 AC, only one surviving member remains, [[Adam of the Golden Army]], a unit that became self aware and was befriended by the [[Vault Seekers]]. He currently is living in [[Crisial City]], learning everything he can about everything he can.
[[Category: Organizations]]

revision.comment: Redirected page to [[Crisial of the Four Towers]]
revision.text: #REDIRECT [[Crisial of the Four Towers]]

A former unit of the [[Golden Army]]. Became self-aware in 250 AC and escaped the destruction of the [[Vault of Kings]] with the help of the [[Vault Seekers]]. Currently resides in [[Crisial City]] with the [[Sages]], engaging in research of all types.
Visually, he's approximately 6' tall and obviously a construct. He appears to be wearing plate armor, although that's really just his frame. Despite having been a soldier, he abhors violence.
==Personality== Incredibly naive and philosophical. ; Ideal: Knowledge. I must learn everything I can so I can understand my purpose. ; Bond: The [[Vault Seekers]] are my friends, and I like the [[Sages]] and will do anything (except fight) for them. ; Flaw: Extremely trusting. ; Alignment: Naive Good
[[Category: Notable People]] [[Category: Crisial Kingdom]]

revision.comment: Created page with "An artifact tied to the [[Vault of Kings]]. In appearance, a simple golden ring with a blood-red stone. Actually made of [[celestite]]. The stone, when inserted into the centr..."
revision.text:
An artifact tied to the [[Vault of Kings]]. In appearance, a simple golden ring with a blood-red stone. Actually made of [[celestite]]. The stone, when inserted into the central core command console, allowed the user to issue the self-destruct command to the vault. Its bearer was also afforded limited access rights to the [[Vault of Kings]] without triggering the retaliation mechanism, but could not command the [[Golden Army]].
The ring was worn by [[Aiden ko'Syra]], one of the [[Vault Seekers]] and was destroyed when it was used for its intended purpose.
[[Category: Artifacts]]

[[Ihmisi]] ranger. Prefers the bow to the sword, and mainly prefers to be ''way over there''. Dislikes being up close and personal with anything hostile. Known for extreme dead-eye accuracy. And trying to flee into a bag of holding whenever danger loomed (which his friends had to usually talk him out of).
Currently the leader of the [[Sons of Air]]. Operates out of [[Godsfall]], where his friend [[Scarface]] and his wife have a farm.
==Personality== A bit of a coward, but will fight very effectively. ; Ideal : Personal safety. ; Bond : The [[Vault Seekers]] and hunting down [[Imperial Sons]] ; Flaw : Personal safety > almost everything else. ; Alignment: Chaotic Neutral.
[[Category: Vault Seekers]] [[Category: Godsfall]]

A middle-aged dwarven barbarian. Wields a giant enchanted wrench as a maul. Prone to saying "dorf smash!" when he gets angry. Which is...quite frequently. He and his wife (and their two kids) were exiled from their clan due to his temper issues, but have settled in [[Godsfall]] along with a couple-dozen human and [[gwerin]] children rescued from stasis under [[Novaestium]].
Physically, he's...a mountain dwarf. Notable for having bright-blue hair (not dyed) and (shockingly) a scar on his face (from headbutting an armored guard).
==Personality== Temper, but loves his kids and his wife. More cautious than he looks. ; Bond: His wife and children (including adopted kids). ; Ideal: Loyalty. ; Flaw: Temper issues. ; Alignment: Neutral Good.
[[Category: Godsfall]] [[Category: Vault Seekers]]

A black dragonborn of clan [[Syra]]. Quiet, except when it's time to ''fireball'' all the things. Currently a founding member of the [[Sons of Air]].
==Personality== Reserved, but loves fire. ;Ideal: Setting things on fire. ;Bond: The [[Vault Seekers]] ;Flaw: setting things on fire. ;Alignment: Chaotic flammable.
[[Category: Vault Seekers]] [[Category: Godsfall]]

revision.comment: /* Personality */
revision.text:
An [[half-elves|earthblood]] druid, Faqul mainly likes magic items. ''Loves'' magic items. Has insatiable curiosity for any information that might lead him to ancient lore...but mainly magic items. Always the first through the door. Currently tags along with the [[Sons of Air]] when there's the prospect of treasure or new things to learn, but also lives out in the forest near [[Godsfall]] conducting research.
==Personality== Will always open any door and press any button or switch. Just to see what it does. ;Ideal: Knowledge. ;Bond: Friends...and knowledge. ;Flaw: Will do almost anything for knowledge. ;Alignment: Chaotic Neutral
[[Category: Vault Seekers]] [[Category: Godsfall]]

revision.comment: Created page with "A small organization, founded in 250 AC by the [[Vault Seekers]], dedicated to hunting down members of the [[Imperial Sons]] wherever they're found and killing them, no matter..."
revision.text:
A small organization, founded in 250 AC by the [[Vault Seekers]], dedicated to hunting down members of the [[Imperial Sons]] wherever they're found and killing them, no matter the diplomatic or legal consequences. Not a sanctioned group. Known for all being able to fly by various means. Headquartered in [[Godsfall]].
[[Category: Organizations]] [[Category: Godsfall]]

A small village about 3 days NW of [[Godsfall]]. While technically part of the [[Duarchy]], they are mostly independent. Notable for three things-- * It was the first place the [[Vault Seekers]] made their names * It's mostly peaceful. * The population is mixed [[ihmisi]] and [[orcs]], including many [[Player Option--Variant Races|wood orc]] (half-orc/half-elf).
==People==
* N'ric ilvo Englathyn ** Occupation/history: Son of Englathyn shaman. Hunter and scout ** Appearance: He has both the orcish arm tattoos and elven facial tattoos. ** High: Dexterity ; Low: Strength ** Talent: sketches beautifully ** Mannerism: Stares into the distance while talking ** Interactions: Irritable ** Ideal: No limits ** Bond: Protective of his younger siblings ** Flaw: gets angry easily ** Alignment: Neutral Good ** Stat block: Scout (MM)
[[Category: Cities]] [[Category: Duarchy]]

An [[ihmisi]] alchemist and druid hired by the [[Imperial Sons]] to harass the people of [[Englathyn]] so that they'd not stumble in to IS operations nearby at the [[Markov Crypt|Markov Estate]]. He did this by creating parasitic mites that would burrow into and control wildlife, making them unusually aggressive against targets of Saerev's choosing. Killed by the [[Vault Seekers]] in 250 AC.
[[Category: Historical Interest]]

revision.text:
A subrace of gnomes originating from the [[Vault of Kings]]. A group of them escaped the destruction of that demiplane and are now living near [[Bor's Sacrifice]]. AKA "mechagnomes"--this name stems from the bio-mechanical augmentations characteristic of these people.

revision.text:
A village in southern [[Crisial Kingdom]], grown up around a pre-[[Cataclysm]] mithral mine rediscovered and cleansed of [[Twisted]] influence in 205AC as one of the first acts of the [[Catalysts]]. Named after an adventurer who gave his life in the fight against the demonic inhabitants.
Now the center of dwarven settlement in the [[Crisial Kingdom]].
[[Category: Villages]] [[Category: Crisial Kingdom]]

revision.comment: Created page with "The original capital of [[Wyrmhold]], located at the north-eastern edge of the [[Nocthian Caldera]]. It was founded during the [[War of Souls]] that ended [[Tibor Imperia]] an..."
revision.text:
The original capital of [[Wyrmhold]], located at the north-eastern edge of the [[Nocthian Caldera]]. It was founded during the [[War of Souls]] that ended [[Tibor Imperia]] and was abandoned during the rise of the [[Hungering Frost]] after the [[Cataclysm]]. As of 250 AC, the remaining undead and other forces that occupied it have been mostly cleaned out, but the city still remains in ruins. There is significant debate in [[Wyrmhold]] about what should be done, while the more expansionist parts of [[Byssia]] want it returned to [[Byssia]]n control along with the rest of the caldera.
[[Category: Cities]] [[Category: Nocthian Caldera]]

revision.comment: Created page with "Located in the Diamond region of the [[Plane of Stone]], the All-Things Bazaar lives up to its name. If it could conceivably be bought at sold, this market has it somewhere...."
revision.text:
Located in the Diamond region of the [[Plane of Stone]], the All-Things Bazaar lives up to its name. If it could conceivably be bought at sold, this market has it somewhere. Or has people who can be hired to retrieve it. The prices vary, however.
The [[angels]] of the Third Host have a strong detachment here to intercept any [[Awakener]] related merchandise, but otherwise they do not intervene. The market itself is overseen by [[Kela-Loran]]'s priesthood in the [[Plane of Stone]], made up mostly of gnomes, dwarves, and dao. The goddess herself has been known to frequent the market in disguise. The ostensible planar ruler, the god [[Korokonolkom]], does not patronize the market whatsoever.
Unlike the [[Utility Market]] of the [[Plane of Coal]], the Bazaar does little trade in intelligent slaves, although certificates of indenture and other instruments of servitude, as well as hiring contracts for more voluntary labor are quite commonly bought and sold.
[[Category: Plane of Stone]]

revision.comment: Created page with "Located in the [[Plane of Coal]], the Utility Market is the central hub of the planar slave trade (ahem '''involuntary labor market'''). Beings from all over the planes are bo..."
revision.text:
Located in the [[Plane of Coal]], the Utility Market is the central hub of the planar slave trade (ahem '''involuntary labor market'''). Beings from all over the planes are bought and sold here. Exotics fetch higher prices. Split between the open auction floors and the private flesh markets, all tastes and needs are supplied here. Buyer beware--if you can't pay up, you yourself might become merchandise.
[[Category: Plane of Coal]]

An insane dwarf, driven by the compulsion to replace his fleshy body with a "perfect" one made of metal. Originally from [[Shinevog]], he uncovered records pointing to [[Tsagaz]]. In 247 AC, he made the trip there and, using a hidden entrance, snuck into the lower levels where he began experimenting on the Unawoken, sending them to collect parts from the [[Yavakh]] and mostly the [[Uldekh]]. When he was slain by the [[Vault Seekers]] in 250 AC, he had replaced everything but his head, which was placed in a jar inside the body of a misshapen construct. His insane ravings and mathemagical calculations covered most of the interior wall space of the northern side of the second level.
[[Category: Historical Interest]] [[Category: Dwarves]]

revision.comment: Created page with "A redoubt in the [[Waste]] operated by the [[Blightguard]]. Built in the outer ruins of [[Lyo Duo]], it is one of the few safe spots (for non-demons) in the [[Waste]]. The inn..."
revision.text:
A redoubt in the [[Waste]] operated by the [[Blightguard]]. Built in the outer ruins of [[Lyo Duo]], it is one of the few safe spots (for non-demons) in the [[Waste]]. The inner sections were inaccessible due to the contamination of the [[Heart of Iska kel Pana]]. After the cleansing of the heart by [[Enigma]] in 250 AC, the inner portion of the keep completely collapsed, as the planar forces holding it in non-Euclidean configuration were removed.
[[Category: Waste]]

The Waste is a layer of [[Shadow]] that should not exist. The Waste is formed when the other layers (the [[Border Shadow]], [[Mirrorhaven]], and [[Beastholme]]) get compressed into one by the passage of significant [[demons|abyssal]] influence. Usually, an area of the Mortal plane experiences a proliferation of demon summoning, [[blood magic]], [[undead|necromancy]] (specifically the creation of undead), or other massive trauma. This trauma and the passage of so many [[jotnar]] erodes the barriers between the layers and between the Mortal and [[Shadow]], resulting in a contamination.
In an area of the Waste, entry from the [[Abyss]] is facilitated and [[jotnar]] can leak through un-prompted. This often results in the contamination of spirits who dwell there after death, converting them into [[demons]]. [[Demons]] prowl, consuming souls. The land itself is twisted and barren, with hostile shadow creations springing up to plague those who dwell there.
Before the breaking of the [[Pact with Death]], it was the responsibility of the [[cysgoroesi]] to work to heal these areas, using the [[Ebony Rod]] and harp. They were assisted by devils, paid as mercenaries to fight the inner fight (much like the [[angels]] fight the eternal war on the outer boundaries of the Dream). Since then, only the efforts of the devils and the [[Blightguard]] have kept the waste somewhat in check.
The most frequent demonic troops seen in the waste belong to the [[Twisted]] and the [[Red Fang]]. The Jester, as well as [[Oro-laen]] and [[Lloitira]] have much less impact. In fact, the latter two have been known to surreptitiously aid in efforts to contain the worst areas of the Waste.
==Significant Wasted Areas== ; The Blight : Located correspondingly to the [[Great Eastern Dustlands]] of [[Noefra]], this is the biggest hot spot in all of [[Shadow]]. The [[Red Fang]]'s presence is strong here. ; The Ashlands : Located opposite of [[Moon's Fall Vengeance]], this area seethes with angry arcane-tinged demons. ; The Gnashing Fangs : Located opposite of the [[Blood-thirst Wildlands]], this area is still contaminated with [[Twisted]] forces. ; Thorn and Claw : Located opposite of North [[Ithemba]] in [[Soefra]], this is the (healing) remnant of the mark left by [[Lloitira]] and the [[Red Fang]]'s attempt to break through into the Mortal in 212 AC.
[[Category: Shadow]]

revision.comment: Created page with "An artifact dating to the [[Dawn War]]. Visually a large (over 10' across) crystal in the shape of a dragon's heart, it was the crystallized remains of the [[Watcher]]'s mate,..."
revision.text:
An artifact dating to the [[Dawn War]]. Visually a large (over 10' across) crystal in the shape of a dragon's heart, it was the crystallized remains of the [[Watcher]]'s mate, who perished in that primal conflict. Still bearing a trace of her soul in the form of a large cat-like being, the Heart was granted to the [[Cysgor]] as part of their [[Pact with Death]]. It resided at [[Lyo Duo]], where it formed the link between the [[Watcher]] (and his [[Gleaner]]s and their cat network) and the [[cysgor]] caretakers. In the days leading up to the fall of [[Lyo Duo]], it was contaminated with both [[jotnar]] and [[awakener]] influence. While the cat-spirit fought to contain the influence, preventing its spread, this was the catalyst for the breaking of that Pact and the abandonment of [[Lyo Duo]] to the waste.
For over four millennia, the three forces warred for dominance. On 9 Autumn Dawning, 250 AC, [[Enigma]] arrived and, wielding angel-made technology, entered the mindscape inside the gem and defeated both demon and [[awakener]] influence, freeing the Heart. It returned to the [[Watcher]]'s side.
[[Category: Artifacts]]

revision.comment: Created page with "An ancestral crypt underneath the estate of the (fallen) Markov family. Located near [[Englathyn]], it contained undead guardians set to guard one of the [[mysterium magicii]]..."
revision.text:
An ancestral crypt underneath the estate of the (fallen) Markov family. Located near [[Englathyn]], it contained undead guardians set to guard one of the [[mysterium magicii]]. While the [[Imperial Sons]] ransacked the estate proper, the [[Vault Seekers]] entered the crypt, defeated the guardians, and acquired the artifact it contained, along with the [[Bloodstone Ring]].
[[Category: Historical Interest]] [[Category: Godsfall]]

Bloodstorm was [[Red Fang|Gromach]]'s prized axe while he was alive. In his transformation into the [[Red Fang]], Gromach threw it into the throne at the keep on [[Mt. Fearg]] and left a portion of his soul (accidentally) in the axe. This transformed it from a magical axe of no particular rarity into an artifact-caliber weapon, possessed of his grief, hatred (for the ones that slew his sister [[Serak]] as well as most living things), and nihilism, as well as most of his memories. It lay in slumber there for millennia, lacking a wielder.
When [[Torvald'vel'Orobas]] and his son [[Azhtar Cai'Valur]] entered the fortress in search of [[Awakener]] traces in ~220 AC, the demonic axe awakened (causing them to flee its wrath). Stretching forth its power in the wasteland that the area had become, it found like souls in the [[Dead Walkers]]. Manifesting a fragment of itself in front of likely candidates, it possessed them, transforming them into pale echoes of Gromach in his (mortal) prime. It used these leaders to gather armies; among which were the forces that nearly destroyed the [[Dugai]].
[[Enigma]] confronted the axe in its stronghold, battled through its illusions and "history lessons" and somehow evoked a fragment of [[Serak]]'s memory also embedded in the throne room where she was slaughtered by the [[First Heroes]]. Together, they banished an avatar of the [[Red Fang]] and shattered the axe, removing its malign influence forever and weakening the [[Red Fang]].
[[Category: Artifacts]] [[Category: Historical Interest]]

Father of [[Azhtar Cai'Valur]] and grandfather of [[Ahzekiel Cai'Valur]]. Originally a deva of the [[angels|Angelic Host]] specializing in understanding the [[awakener]], he fell due to his love for a mortal (Azhtar's mother). He since joined House [[Orobas]] and has the rank of specialist within that house.
==Dealings with Mortals== * He assisted the [[Dimwit Syndicate]] in freeing his beloved from [[Awakener]] possession as well as provided the angel-made weapon that allowed them to free the shard of the Third Moon from [[Awakener]] influence. * He and his son attempted to penetrate [[Mt. Fearg]] into [[Lyo Duo]] in search of [[Awakener]] presence, but fled from the awakened [[Bloodstorm]]. * He gave [[Tsun Azur]] a tour of Shadow, showing her the conditions in the "afterlife". His reasons for doing this are unclear, but it is believed that he was working under divine orders of some sort. * He "happened" to be nearby when [[Enigma]] fell into Shadow after defeating the [[Sleeper]] and guided them out. * He has acted as [[Sakara]]'s agent in providing material support (in the form of divinely-marked gold coins) to the reconstruction effort at the [[Cherry Blossom Temple]] * He delivered another angelic weapon to [[Enigma]] to allow them to enter the Gemheart mindspace inside of the [[Heart of Iska kel Pana]]. * He led a contingent of angels to rescue [[Enigma]] as they fell after the collapse of [[Lyo Duo]].
[[Category: Angels]] [[Category: Devils]]

A single-mast ship operating in the [[Serpent Sea]]. [[Dilligas Husty]] served aboard her before she was taken by betrayal and murder at the hands of Captain [[Jahat Khema]] of the [[Scarlet Pearl]]. Later used by the [[Gor'ka]] pirate group under the control of Captain [[Idris]] (the former bosun and traitor) as a front ship, purchasing supplies for the main group.
[[Idris]] and the crew were brought back into the light by [[Enigma]] and, after the events of [[Sleeper's End]], has become a legitimate trader owned by [[Dilligas Husty]].
==Crew== ; Captain: [[Idris]] ; Ship's Mage: [[Quelanna]]
[[Category: Ships]] [[Category:Pearl Fleet]]

A two-masted [[Ship Folk]] raider and pirate ship. Flagship of the [[Gor'ka]] fleet under the [[sena'ka]] captain [[Jahat Khema]]. After the events of [[Sleeper's End]], it was cleansed by miracle and renamed the Golden Pearl. Now operating under Captain Ehnoze (Ay-Nose) of [[Tarad'am]] and owned by [[Dilligas Husty]]. It's primary area of operation is the eastern [[Serpent Sea]], reaching as far as [[Moon's Fall Vengeance]] and the newly founded colony of [[Unshackled]].
[[Category: Ships]] [[Category:Pearl Fleet]]

[[Sena'ka]] of the [[Ship Folk]]. Turned rogue and took the [[Scarlet Pearl]] into piracy in 246 AC. Founded the [[Gor'ka]] pirate gang and was deeply involved in the atrocities associated with the [[Sleeper]].
Was recruited/rescued by [[Gozh]] from the final battle at the [[Sleeper]]'s prison and became one of his lieutenants. He was tasked with leading a band of mercenaries to [[Mt. Fearg]] to recover the [[Heart of Iska kel Pana]]. When his band got caught in pitched battle with the [[Dead Walkers]], he was ambushed and slain by [[Enigma]]. His body was burned and his head crushed, making resurrection extremely unlikely. His enchanted scimitars were given to the captains of the [[Windbreaker]] and [[Golden Pearl]] as reminders and symbols of authority.
[[Category: Sena'ka]]
