revision.comment: /* Summary */
revision.text:
==Summary== Landing on the western shores of [[Noefra]], the party is captured and sentenced to the arena. From there, they are recruited by the imperial mage, later to become [[Kul'Asad]], for a suicide mission to recover the "Book of Demons", an artifact said to contain the true names of many demons, currently being held by the people of [[Nocthis]]. They are teleported to a smaller city, recently captured by the forces of [[Imperial Meztli]], where they help the fugitive prince escape to the north. They travel with him, slaying a dragon on the way (which act lays the groundwork for [[Xol'cerd]]'s hatred of the [[dragonborn]], as the young dragon was her brother). They also meet a mage whose tower returned after the [[War of Souls]]. He later went on to free the [[Nameless]] and become that being's host during the [[Cataclysm War]].
Arriving in [[Hammerhead]], they make their way toward the [[Nocthean Caldera]], where they are captured and the truth is revealed--the "Book of Demons" is an unholy writ, being held safe from [[Kul'Asad]] and his demon-summoning ways by the wardens of [[Nocthis]]. They are exiled through a portal to [[Tal Elamor]].
[[Category: Campaigns]]

revision.comment: Created page with "==Summary== The party, exiled through a portal from the [[Nocthean Caldera]], end up in [[Tal Elamor]]. There they take up adventuring, but are forced to withdraw from a crypt..."
revision.text:
==Summary== The party, exiled through a portal from the [[Nocthean Caldera]], end up in [[Tal Elamor]]. There they take up adventuring, but are forced to withdraw from a crypt underneath the city populated by undead. Before they can retry, however, news reaches the city about the oncoming [[Cataclysm War]]. The party, along with many other novice adventurers, are sent on errands. These errands are, in large part, designed to keep them away from the armies as reserves.
Their particular errand was to search a lost temple dedicated to a forgotten goddess of luck and trickery for the fabled [[Eyes of Qa'desh|Right Eye of Qa'desh]], with the instruction to bring it back if they found it. They were never intended to actually find it--it was regarded as a snipe hunt. But find it they did, after navigating traps and defeating a rival group of the [[Nameless]]'s followers. Of course, they decided, once they'd gotten it outside and found out what it could do, to use it themselves instead of bringing it back to the Army of Order.
Each one of them made a request of it:
Those wishes were (in order of success): # to become gods # for the eye to self-destruct # for there to be less magic in the world
Faced with those imperatives, this artifact of creation began to draw in [[anima]] from the entire world. So much so that it shut down all active magic (including magically-assisted flight) across the hemisphere. It then tried to implode (as required), but since it had drawn in a large amount of heavily-tainted anima from the [[Nameless]] and his Army of Chaos, that backfired, misaligning the elemental planes and threatening to send the entire [[Great Mechanism]] into ruin. Thus began the [[Cataclysm]].
The party? They got their wish to become gods. Their souls, stripped from their bodies, were chosen as three of the newly-called [[Congregation]], more for penance than for reward. They are [[Yogg-Maggus]], the [[Hollow King]], and [[Pinwheel]] (the latter being the one who wished for the destruction of the eye).
[[Category: Campaigns]]

==Beginnings, and Rats== The party began in the Four-peaks Adventuring Academy, located near the dwarven lands at the eastern edge of the [[Flower Kingdom]]. Their first quest was to clear out the basement of a local farm, overrun by rats. As it happened, those rats were Of Unusual Size, and were being led by a mad druid, corrupted by the [[Twisted]]. Here, they learned of a threat in a nearby crypt, overrun with undead...and worse. There they found a group of necromantic demon cultists, working to summon Broken Hunger into the world. Their malign plot was stilled, forever.
==Crystal Stasis== From there, they moved west toward the capital until they encountered a crystalline fortress, surrounded by crystalized soldiers, positioned as if attacking. This strange sight was surrounded by farmland, but hadn't been there a week ago (according to the locals). Investigating, they found it was a relic of the [[War of Souls]], taken out of time by a [[concept bomb]]. The heart was caught in a loop, with the inhabitants doomed to replay each day, dying over and over...and still remembering every blow of their thousand-year exile. The crystalized solders were still alive and thoroughly insane. Against these forces, the party struggled, but eventually was victorious, bringing an end to the curse.
==Capital Woes== Heading to the capital of [[Lasiriand]] for some R&R. Once there, the [[Shirtless Dwarf]] wanted to buy some of the drugs that he'd heard about. Accompanied by a few of the others, they made the purchase (which turned out to be powdered sugar, sold to rubes from the sticks). On their return, they encountered a trio of drunken nobles harassing (and more) a pair of serving women in an alley. At first they tried to dissuade them with words, when that failed, they turned to their swords. Unfortunately, one of the nobles killed was the king's youngest son, a noted wastrel. The party was arrested the next morning. Their trial was cut short by news of the [[Cataclysm War]] and the Army of Chaos bearing down on them.
==Gathering Allies== The party was set free and assigned the task of seeking out the unicorn grove to the south and bringing those majestic beasts to the battle. This they did, despite having to destroy a dragon who threatened them. In its hoard, they discovered one of the [[Fangs of Resolution]]. On the way back, they traded that artifact to an old lady, who turned out to be an avatar of Primordial Life, the world itself. This being granted them blessings (described on the individual character pages).
==Battle and Aftermath== The party, returning with the unicorn herd, participated in the [[Battle of Acceptance]]. In the aftermath, they (except the [[Shirtless Dwarf]], who wandered off after the chaos) were among the only remaining powers. As such, they led the refugees of the [[Cataclysm]] south, gathering more on the way. They founded [[Kaelthia]], and two of them still protect that land.
[[Category: Campaigns]] [[Category:Refuge Seekers]]

revision.text:
A human wizard. Born about 180 BC in the [[Flower Kingdom]] of a low-noble house, she enrolled at the Four-Peaks Adventuring Academy to escape her family and seek adventure. Joining the [[Refuge Seekers]], she was one of the centering influences in that band.
After the [[Cataclysm]], she was a major player in the founding of the [[Granite-Flame Academy]]. As she aged, she used arcane technologies, scavenged from before the [[Cataclysm]] (the same ones used to create [[Hound's Rest]], as well as [[IULIA]], but voluntary), to embed her consciousness in the building itself, becoming its guiding spirit.
With the new order (post [[Treaty of Rauviz]]), she has appeared less and less frequently.
[[Category: Adventurers]] [[Category: Refuge Seekers]]

revision.text:
A [[jazuu]] barbarian, he was a staunch, although quiet, member of the [[Refuge Seekers]]. And a lover of squirrels.
His boon was to grow hard as stone, which he did in the final battle to protect his allies from harm. After the founding of the [[Granite-Flame Academy]], he settled down in its courtyard with his pets and completed the transformation, becoming the statue that still stands to this day. There are rumors that, if threats to the academy arise, he will stand up and take up his axe once more.
[[Category: Adventurers]] [[Category: Refuge Seekers]]

A doughty dwarf, of a lost clan. Loved drinking, fighting, and taking off his shirt at inappropriate times.
His boon was to become tough as an old oak, which he did during the final battle, shrugging off the axes and swords of the Army of Chaos. Unlike the rest, he wandered off shortly thereafter and took root on the banks of a river; to this day, it's said that if you sit under a particular oak, you can hear him whispering dirty words in your ear. Especially if you're a pretty girl.
[[Category: Adventurers]] [[Category:Refuge Seekers]]

revision.comment: Created page with "A human cleric, bearing the mark of one of the [[Old Gods]], she served alongside the [[Refuge Seekers]]. After the battles, she was instrumental in establishing the Temple..."
revision.text:
A human cleric, bearing the mark of one of the [[Old Gods]], she served alongside the [[Refuge Seekers]].
After the battles, she was instrumental in establishing the [[Temple of the Four]] in [[Kaelthia]], and after her death was caught up to serve as a demigoddess at the side of [[Melara]].
Her domain now is anti-undead operations, being the patron of the militant orders of the Lady of Mercy's clergy and service.
[[Category: Adventurers]] [[Category: Demigods]] [[Category: Refuge Seekers]]

A name for a hypothetical (based on current flows and aether topology tracking) continent located near [[Aenimos]] in the south-western hemisphere of [[Quartus]]. All attempts to go there (as far as [[Noefra]] is concerned) have failed with the loss of all hands.
Still a mystery. No one knows what's here.
[[Category: Geography]]

== Kalesin == As one of the Catalysts, she helped found the Federated Nations. She is also a hero of [[Wyrmhold]] for her efforts in the Winter War of 205 AC (see [[Catalyst Side Stories]]); as a result of the forces she led the Wall was completed, greatly lessening the threat of the [[Hungering Frost|Frost]]. In the final battle of that campaign she led a strike force against one of the frost giant leaders; his death was a turning point that led to the rout of the forces of Frost. Cheerful and calm, she is loved by the common people.
From then until 211 AC, she primarily spent her time founding the [[Quietus]] monastic school, training commoners and nobles alike in the way of meditation and unarmed martial arts. By 250 AC, she has retired as the active head of the school but remains the guiding master. She is not directly involved in politics, but is an honorary member of Clan [[Anu]]. She is still unmarried, despite significant courting from various noble families. She also serves as the local head of the Adventurer’s Guild.
;Demographic Information: Kalesin is a silver dragonborn female in her late 60s. She wears simple clothing and goes nowhere without her famous staff, [[Noggin-flogger]]. She also wields a returning lightning javelin. She prefers to hit things with her staff [[Noggin-flogger]].
;Personality Trait: I have a strong sense of fair play and always try to find the most equitable solution to arguments. ;Ideal: Respect. People deserve to be treated with dignity and respect. ;Bond: Those who fight beside me are those worth dying for. ;Flaw: If there's a plan, I'll forget it. If I don't forget it, I'll ignore it. ;Alignment: Lawful Good
[[Category: Adventurers]] [[Category: Catalysts]]

revision.comment: /* Vassarian Kabir */
revision.text:
== Vassarian Kabir == Since helping to found the [[Federated Nations]] as one of the Catalysts, he has been attempting to discover secrets of the [[Dark Beyond]] in the research of the ancient empires. When he is not off on one of his many excursions to ancient ruins, he also the final arbiter of who will be allowed to become part of the [[Adventurer’s Guild]] in cases of uncertainty due to morality. He is known to be ruthless when it comes to eliminating candidates who do not showcase the requisite moral fiber and attitudes. Tentacles are a significant theme. He heads the [[Order of the Seeking Tentacle]], an organization devoted to uncovering secrets and defending the world from aberrations and those from Beyond.
After the [[Crystal Spire War]] in 217 and the attendant attack on [[Hound's Rest]], Vassarian decided to take a more direct hand in the politics of the [[Federated Nations]] by taking personal and direct control over the [[Adventurer’s Guild]]. Over the next decade, and as a result of the [[Caldera Conflict]] of 220 AC, he turned its efforts more toward policing and maintaining order between the FNC members and less toward generalized adventuring. He has transformed it into an elite cadre of enforcers and agents riding herd over the [[Registered Companies]].
;Demographic Information: Vassarian is a handsome half-elf of indeterminate age with long dark curly hair and a matching beard. He wears a black cloak made of a dead cloaker which engulfs most of him. He also carries the Rod of Cancellation, a simple silver metal rod about two feet long. His constant companion is a small floating golem, known as [[Crit Bot]], a small ball of metal with a glowing blue eye. Mechanically he is a level 10 warlock, Pacted to a being from the [[Dark Beyond]]. He favors telekinesis as his answer to most issues.
;Personality Trait: Flippant and lippy. ;Ideal: Strength should only be acquired to defend those who cannot defend themselves. ;Bond: Crit-bot, the Federated Nations, returning to the Dark Beyond. ;Flaw: Uniformly disrespectful of those in power who do not serve the best interests of everyone. ;Alignment: NG
[[Category: Adventurers]] [[Category: Catalysts]]

revision.comment: /* Safrir Tree-Friend */
revision.text:
== Safrir Tree-Friend == The least politically involved of the Catalysts, Safrir co-founded the [[Lady%27s Grove|Lady's Grove]], the newest druidic circle (in the Ladyforest near [[Crisial of the Four Towers]]) with the ancient oak nymph Sara (see [[Tree and Child]]). Together they watch over the area, training new druids and woodsmen and educating the locals on the proper care of the land. The Lady's Grove specializes in weather magic and other plant-oriented spells. Rumors that he and Sara are involved are rampant.
While he still corresponds and assists the Adventurer’s Guild and the other Catalysts as needed, he mostly stays at home and trains his neophytes. His grove accepts all who wish to learn the ways of the spirits.
Personally, he’s kind and generous. He’ll help out with anything he sees as needs doing--he’s gotten his hands dirty with the harvest for peasants, participated in search parties for lost children and goats, and is generally loved by the people of the [[Crisial Kingdom]].
Demographic Information: a slow-aging (due to druidic power and Sara's influence) human male, he has dark brown hair, now shot with grey. His green eyes still twinkle, especially when around children.
;Personality Trait: I can find common ground between the fiercest enemies, empathizing with them and always working toward peace. ;Ideal: Generosity. My talents were given to me so that I could use them to benefit the world. ;Bond: I will do anything to protect the [[Lady%27s Grove|Lady's Grove]] and my students. ;Flaw: I’m naive and trusting, willing to always believe the best of everyone, even if they’ve showed otherwise. ;Alignment: Neutral Good
[[Category: Adventurers]] [[Category: Catalysts]]

revision.comment: /* Paresten sur Tai Nwyedd */
revision.text:
== Paresten sur Tai Nwyedd == Paresten is the most politically active of the Catalysts. He is deeply involved in the day-to-day operations of the [[Federated Nations]] as the Counselor who oversees the [[Adventurer’s Guild]], as well as the council’s Treasurer. He makes no bones about his desire to increase his own wealth and prestige; he just does this by making his operations successful. After the attack on [[Hound's Rest]], he stayed in the newly-formed Holy Kaelthian Republic, where he has significant political influence. He travels through the portal network on a constant basis raising funds and handling issues with suppliers for the Guild.
He also founded House [[Tai Nwyedd]] (which translates to “New Blood”). The least conventional House, it is a matter of some contention among the other gwerin. It draws from the young, the disaffected, and the passed-over. It grants rank based on merit alone, not bloodlines. But it considers more than just arcane power. Unlike other houses that arrange mating contracts, Tai Nwyedd allows the members to act freely. Tai Nwyedd is also heavily involved in international trade; rumors paint them as also being tied to the [[Mockers]].
Personally, he’s arrogant and contemptuous of his lessers. He treats the rest of the Catalysts as his servants in public; they mostly just roll their eyes and play along. Earlier he fought duels frequently (due to offending lots of people), but the trail of bleeding courtiers he left behind put an end to that.
Demographic Information: A middle-aged (mid 70s) [[gwerin]] with golden-blond hair and fair features. He still wears armor (which scandalizes many matrons of high society). Unmarried (despite many attempts), he’s popular with the ladies. He dual-wields rapiers (one of which is blessed by holy fire; the other is enchanted against giants) and is a lethal swordsman as well as a mage. He doesn’t fight fair, though.
;Personality Trait: Arrogant, elitist. ;Ideal: Greed. I'm only in it for the money. ;Bond: The Federated Nations Council is my work and I will protect it at any cost. ;Flaw: I'm too greedy for my own good. I can't resist taking a risk if there's money involved. ;Alignment: Chaotic Neutral
[[Category: Adventurers]] [[Category: Catalysts]]

== Saeth Saren == Born in a small village of [[Usko Ffyd]], this [[gwerin]] woman suffered the tragic loss of her parents and her entire village in 206 AC to the [[Imperial Sons]] and their twisted research goals. Four years later, she joined the ranks of the Sanctioned Adventurers and together with Mope investigated and ended the threat from [[Imperial Research Alpha]] and its twisted, dragon-obsessed master. Later that year, the pair of them joined Quickleaf and Iseis at [[Godsfall]], where they proceeded to make history.
After the liberation, she studied at the [[Granite-Flame Academy]] in [[Kaelthia]] as a visiting scholar, she has begun to gather a band of fellow afficionados who yearn to discover the ultimate secrets of the universe and make them accessible to the common man. Her motives are rather different than most--she wants recognition and celebrity (and wealth). This band calls themselves [[DISCOVERY]] (Dedicated Investigatory Society Centered on Vastly Energetic Research—Yonwach branch), and has published their inaugural broadsheet. Her own specialty is the nature of life and death; she is affiliated with the College of Necromancy (despite not sullying her pretty hands with the actual raising of undead).
After the collapse of the [[Council Lands]], she moved her operations to [[Crisial of the Four Towers]], where she and [[DISCOVERY]] are currently headquartered.
;Demographic Information: At 6'5", she's tall for a gwerin woman but nonetheless beautiful. Still relatively young (in her mid 60s) and wealthy as a result of her adventures, she is a prime target for all the noble Gwerin houses. A consummate flirt, she leads many of them on but refuses to commit to anything. As a divine boon, she can absorb one spell per day.
;Personality trait: Compulsive kleptomaniac and swindler. ;Ideal: Celebrity. She wants to be recognized for her power and glamour. ;Bond: Fair treatment of women. ;Flaw: Impulsive and distracted by glitz and glamour. Loves the high life. ;Alignment: Chaotic Neutral
[[Category: Godsfall Champions]] [[Category: Adventurers]]

== Quickleaf == Also born in [[Usko Ffyd]], Quickleaf learned both respect for the [[Kami|kami]] and a smattering of arcane magic (unusual for an [[Puun Ihmisia|ihmisi]]). Although the tragedy that befell the town was not aimed as personally at him, he was still caught up in it and orphaned. He joined the [[Mockers]] in [[Kaelthia]] soon thereafter and made a name for himself as a capable sneak-thief until he was recruited for the Sanctioned Adventurers program in 209 AC. He and Iseis were the first SA's into [[Godsfall]] and were instrumental in the events there.
Armed with his skills, a bracelet that granted him invisibility and fireballs, and a strong sense of justice, Quickleaf then returned to [[Kaelthia]] and joined with a fellow adventurer (nicknamed [[Windshadow]]) to create the [[Sheltering Hands]], a loose organization dedicated to feeding and assisting the poor, orphans, and other unfortunates throughout the [[Federated Nations]]. Disdaining public recognition, they have quietly acquired contributions from some of the wealthier residents (whether they knew they were contributing or not is a different question) and move wherever they see a need. This work continues to this day, although as he's aged, both he and Windshadow have stepped back from the more physical parts of the job into more administrative roles.
;Demographic Information: Quickleaf is an older (60s) [[Puun Ihmisia|puun ihmisia]] male. Of middling height and build, with no notable features other than a metal bracer he wears on his left wrist, he blends in easily and prefers it that way. Mechanically, he favors two-weapon fighting.
;Personality Trait: Goes invisible at the first opportunity, but will charge into the middle of a pack of bad guys in the name of justice. ;Ideal: Charity. Help others, even at a cost to yourself. ;Bond: No one else will have to suffer as I did if I can help it. ;Flaw: Stubborn to a fault. ;Alignment: Neutral Good
[[Category: Adventurers]] [[Category: Godsfall Champions]]

== Iseis pe Kel'al'ar == Iseis was born a commoner in the Southern District capital of [[Kel'al'ar]]. He joined the city watch in the upheaval following the [[Dark Lady]]'s demise in 205 AC and quickly rose to the rank of Lieutenant Investigator. Growing restless with the political infighting and becoming frustrated with noble interference in his duties, he left the force when he was recruited by the [[Adventurer's Guild]] in 209. He and Quickleaf were assigned to handle the [[Godsfall]] matter. His knowledge of politics and diplomacy served him well there--he was instrumental in the formation of the [[Godsfall Alliance]] and personally conducted many of the negotiations required to get that fractious bunch to cooperate.
He gained the ability to slip through solid matter (a Boon of Questionable Solidity), the trust of all of the local groups, and the Divine Champion armor set that predates the Cataclysm. After the death of [[Kul'Asad]] and the ascension of the [[Archon of Time]], he spent the winter in [[Godsfall]] helping to coordinate and stabilize the nascent government. In early spring of 211, he left [[Godsfall]] for parts unknown. Years later, right near the founding of the [[Duarchy]], he returned and was (unwillingly) crowned one of the rulers of that new-born nation.
;Demographic Information: Iseis is a 60-ish [[Humans|human]] (fang-kin) male. Thoroughly average in appearance, other than his alabaster-and-gold armor and glowing sword (all it does is glow), he prefers to find alternate routes and makes elaborate plans. Actually hitting things with his sword is rather secondary.
; Personality Trait: I never think in straight lines. ; Ideal: Diplomacy is a first, second, and preferred approach to every problem. ; Bond: I solve problems. Don't get in my way. ; Flaw: Twisty thoughts often cause needless complications. ; Alignment: Chaotic Good
[[Category: Adventurers]] [[Category: Godsfall Champions]]

== Mope and Private Eyeguana == Not much is known of the backstory of this most enigmatic of the four heroes. Preferring to spend her time in the shape of a huge bear, she can be counted on to take the most random approach to any possible situation. How an [[tiefling|infernal plane-touched]] picked up druidic ways is unknown. And everyone who asks her gets a different answer.
She worked with Saeth to solve the [[Imperial Research Alpha]] issue in the spring of 210, and then joined forces with those at [[Godsfall]]. Her erratic ways left her somewhat out of the picture for most of that campaign, although she gained the trust of the Kindred and spent some time with them. After that, she characteristically departed suddenly, saying "I want to go find something to eat," and never returned. Accompanied by her pet/companion/kindred soul, a giant lizard that bonded with her in the jungle and served as her stalwart friend and fellow connoisseur of interesting and questionable foods, she's probably still out wandering, munching on creatures that annoy her (with two, four, or any number of legs, to be quite honest). Or has died. No one's quite sure.
;Demographic Information: Mope is a infernal plane-touched in her 60s (if she's still alive), with characteristic horns, tail, red skin, etc. Private Eyeguana is a large, strangely over-developed, green-scaled giant lizard who wears custom plate barding and is prone to flying into blood-rages. Armed with her spells, her forms and an array of mysterious mushrooms that have rather random effects, she is liable to turn up whenever situations need to be more...random.
;Personality Trait: Can be counted on to take the most unexpected path through any situation. ;Ideal: Freedom. Chaos, in fact. Do the unexpected. ;Bond: Private Eyeguana. The two are inseparable. ;Flaw: Totally unreliable. In fact, reliable at being unreliable. ;Alignment: Chaotic Chaotic. Not even neutral (good vs evil). Chaotic. She makes denizens of pure chaos look predictable and ordered.
[[Category: Adventurers]] [[Category: Godsfall Champions]]

A reclusive [[ihmisi]] assassin and thief, Windshadow (not his real name) grew up scrounging for food in the streets of [[Kaelthia]]. When he was captured by the [[Council Lands]] authorities and sentenced to death (for disrupting the social order), he gained the chance for a reprieve if he promised to dedicate his life to helping the small town of [[Yuuras Zaali|Yuuras Zali]] (now [[Crisial of the Four Towers]]) along with the other members of [[Fire, Stone, and Cold]]. He complied. After the group won their freedom as part of [[Family Pain (Campaign)]], he dedicated his life to feeding the poor and hungry. He and [[Quickleaf]] of the [[Godsfall Champions]] formed the [[Sheltering Hands]]. They travel incognito around the [[Federated Nations]], taking donations (not always willingly given) to help the lot of the poor (usually in secret).
[[Category:Adventurers]] [[Category:Fire, Stone, and Cold]]

revision.comment: Created page with "Built pre-[[Cataclysm]] to be the residence of High Mage Doethian sur Paendrag, who owned and administered the lands where [[Kaelthia]] was founded, it was relegated to obscur..."
revision.text:
Built pre-[[Cataclysm]] to be the residence of High Mage Doethian sur Paendrag, who owned and administered the lands where [[Kaelthia]] was founded, it was relegated to obscurity after the founding of the city. Doethian died about 100 years after the [[Cataclysm]] and the house stayed empty (nominally owned by various individuals but never inhabited) until the [[Catalysts]] received it as payment for their deeds in 205 AC. The reason for the long emptyness as well as the state of repair (which was abnormally good) turned out to be that the house was haunted--the High Mage had been experimenting with [[Blood Magic|soul pinning]], attempting to anchor ''willing'' souls into structures to serve as a guiding intelligence. His work was used by [[Katheryn Archmagus]] to pin her own soul into the [[Granite-Flame Academy]], but he himself was only able to embed the awakened soul of his favorite pet into the house.
Currently, the house serves as the residence of [[Vassarian Kabir]] as well as an administrative center for Guildtown (the [[Adventurer's Guild]] outpost that has swallowed the small suburb outside [[Kaelthia]]).
[[Category: Adventurer's Guild]] [[Category: Catalysts]]

Father of [[Ahzekiel Cai'Valur]] and son of [[Sat'psa Vanna]] and a fallen angel, now a devil of [[Diabolical Families|Family Orobas]]. He was adopted into the [[Cai'Valur]] family in [[Asai'ka]] at age 5 and was officially married to [[Cai'Valur|Tuyaen Cai'Valur]], but has spent most of his life among the [[Dugai]], where he currently acts as their warlord. He had married a daughter of the tribe, who gave birth to [[Ahzekiel Cai'Valur]], but she was killed during the wars with the [[Dead Walkers]].
[[Category: Notable People]] [[Category: Dugai]]

revision.comment: Created page with "A minor isal (khun) family in [[Asai'ka]], they are influential beyond their status as the orchestrators of the western trade route to [[Fort Hope]]. ==Kanin and Spouses== ;..."
revision.text:
A minor isal (khun) family in [[Asai'ka]], they are influential beyond their status as the orchestrators of the western trade route to [[Fort Hope]].
==Kanin and Spouses== ; Family Head : Kanin. An elderly man, he has been sickly for several years. Married to Chaman . ; Wife : Chaman ne' Dahal. Retiring and elderly, she has little influence in the family affairs. Mother of Pran and Akkanee, adopted mother of [[Azhtar Cai'Valur]]. ; Concubine : Minkuna ne' Rana. Much younger and aggressively ambitious. Mother of Nada and Praman.
==Children== ; Pran (48) : Eldest son, but estranged. Gay, living with his dwarf lover (Khael) in [[Sha'slar Autonomous Zone]] as a weaver. Has renounced his name and title. Personality: camp. ; Tuyaen ne' Kelap(39): [[Azhtar Cai'Valur|Azhtar]]'s "widow". Despises him secretly, but conflicted toward Ahzekiel. Addicted to snakeweed (pot, basically, except not so mellow). Follows Mikuna's lead but tries to undercut her. Praman's lover for many years, but now they're separated (after Praman cooperated and prompted Azhekiel's enslavement) and she's got a string of boys (her "servants"). Clingy. Mikuna is trying to get her married off again. ; Nada (38) : Married to a much older Serpent Dominion noble (Isal Sat'psa Turan, a relative of the Sat'psa clan). Glad to be out of the poisonous Rana family. ; Praman (34): Handsome, noble, the face of the family. A shrewd businessman, he organized the opening of trade across the Northern Wilds. Father of Vou & Chesdan. He and Mikuna work together. Connected to the Organization, ambition is to rise to the Board. Heavily courting a wide array of noble women. Unofficially the acting heir as far as anyone else is concerned, very dedicated to making that status formal. ; Akkanee (30): Beauty, partially trained as Temple Dancer (but kicked out for an act of jealousy). Widow of a much older noble. Had a child by an ophidian servant (Jara, a boy of 12). Was left only a pittance in the will when he died about 6 years ago. Still bitter about that. Dabbles in magic (divination). Has a parade of lovers of both sexes. Prefers ophidians. According to rumors, she especially prefers the [[Ophidians||Isal'psa]], the less humanoid the better. ; Vou (20): Child of Praman and Tuyaen, although officially Zeke's younger sister. Self-centered, spoiled, hedonistic. Engaged to be a concubine to Phra Phel Solkan's eldest son, Phel Melan (age about 45). ; Chesdan (16): Child of Praman and Tuyaen. Naïve, enjoys power and prestige but doesn't know the details. Currently being shopped as a concubine of Lai So Lender's daughter (Lai Pe Lender, age 50). Not entirely happy with that. Somewhat idolizes Zeke, very secretly.

[[Enigma]] campaign arc in late 2020/early 2021.
==Events== * Party is notified that [[Phoenix Princess Leina]] has gone missing in the [[Serpent Dominion]]. * Party arrives in [[Tarad'am]] and begins search. They encounter the Broken Chain group as well as have a run-in with the Sealion gang. * Party confronts captain [[Idris]] of the [[Windbreaker]], along with their "old friend" [[Quelanna]] and convinces them to assist in taking down [[Gor'ka]] * They sail around the bay, meeting a bronze dragon (named [[Kortel]]) and being eaten by an ancient ghost ship. * They defeat the ghost ship, breaking a mirror and freeing some souls in the process. Some of those souls take refuge in Dil and Crow. * Landing on [[Moon's Fall Vengeance]], they encounter the [[Yondar]] * They take on the [[Tower of Trials]], earning rewards. * They raid the [[Gor'ka]] base, rescuing the prisoners (including Leina and [[Ahzekiel Cai'Valur]]). * They enter the prison of the [[Sleeper]] and make a deal with [[Oro-laen]] for the [[Sleeper]]'s true name. * They destroy the [[Sleeper]] and are rescued from shadow by a mysterious figure. * On their way back aboard the [[Scarlet Pearl]] (now cleansed by the grace of [[Tor-Elan]] and renamed the Golden Pearl), they encounter the "spike" causing the shadow storm/frozen glass storm in the middle of the bay. They destroy it. * The princess returns home. [[Crow]] remains in [[Tarad'am]] as her local agent. * [[Sargas of Tor-Elan]] is called home to be guardian and teacher of the new twin princes.
[[Category: Campaigns]] [[Category: Enigma]]

[[Enigma]] campaign through most of 2021.
==Initial Events== * [[Ahzekiel Cai'Valur]] joins the party after the departure of [[Sargas of Tor-Elan]] and [[Crow]]. * The party visits [[Zhapai Karmap]] and then [[Creche Skeud]], where they learn the truth about the events there and learn more about the fall of the [[Cysgoroesi]] and about [[Rune]]'s father. * The party returns to [[Fort Hope]], where they're instrumental in breaking up a [[Twisted]]-influenced slave ring involving animal/humanoid chimera children. The rescued children (about 20) are taken to [[Cherry Blossom Temple|Heroes' Rest]], where [[Tson Azur]] is rebuilding. * They confront Ahzekiel's family, leading to improved relations... * Unofficially acting for the [[Adventurer's Guild]] and in search of personal knowledge, they head east to [[Shaadval]] * To open up trade after the idiotic actions of the [[Dragonbotherers]], they head into [[Shaera]]. * En route to [[Erathi Village]], they encounter challenges such as ** They are ambushed by a mercenary force sent by [[Jahat Khema]]. This force is humiliated and the assassin's head is sent back as a friendly warning. ** Their help is requested by a djinn of the [[Plane of Wind]] to track down a behir before his rival, a slave-trading dao, can. They find the dao outside the behir's cave and proceed to humiliate him (including having him polymorphed and placed in a fishbowl for dolphins in the [[Plane of Ocean]] to play with), making an enemy. They proceed to slaughter the behir, learning the truth of their increased power. And the benefits of climbing on big things (starting the pattern of the Orbital Halfling Drop). ** Later on, they encounter a group of Erathi villagers trapped by a nest of acid-spewing giant ants. They solve it in their usual violent fashion, with much exploding bug guts. * They befriend the dragon [[Erai]], mainly by plying her with copious quantities of very strong liquor. Don't worry, she's a consenting adult. * Seizing the opportunity to assist [[Ki-larn]] and gain her trust, they head west into the [[Ladyfrost Mountains]], where her son, [[Miloci]] has gone missing.
==Ladyfrost Mountains== * Here they encounter "shrouds", areas that have been pushed halfway into [[Shadow]] by rogue [[cysgoroesi]] serving former abbot [[Arnyek]]. * They rescue [[Miloci]] from pursuers. * They sneak into [[Arnyek]]'s stronghold in one shroud and parlay with him, regaining some of [[Rune]]'s memories * They then meet the [[Immortal Bard]] and the sleeping [[Marcia (Dragon)]]. * With their assistance, they (temporarily) defeat the lich [[Xel'na]] and gain significant power, as well as ending [[Ahzekiel Cai'Valur]]'s contract with [[Oro-laen]]. * They then slay [[Arnyek]]. * The shrouds collapse.
==Interlude== * The party has to deal with threats to [[Cherry Blossom Temple]] and manages to defuse a war, seemingly being promulgated by the [[Holy Hands]].
==Mt Fearg== * They take their (interrupted) journey from [[Shaadval]] toward [[Mt. Fearg]] via [[Dugai]] territory. * They break the siege of [[Dugai Oasis]] and encounter [[Azhtar Cai'Valur]]. * They (again) defeat [[Xel'na]] while she guides an army under the command of [[Jahat Khema]] toward [[Mt. Fearg]]. Jahat is utterly destroyed. * Entering [[Mt. Fearg]] from the catacombs, they defeat an eldritch abomination of an undead eye tyrant with the assistance of [[Ios al'Tor]] and [[Porala al'Tor]]. * They are forced to endure historical visions of [[Bloodstorm]], a fragment of the [[Red Fang]]'s pre-ascension soul now housed in an axe. * They defeat phantasms of the [[First Heroes]] and destroy [[Bloodstorm]]. * Entering [[Shadow]], Dil sings for devils, one of whom records the performance and sells it to the devils of [[Diabolical Families|Beleth]]. * Wandering through the non-Euclidean space of [[Lyo Duo]], they recover a piece of the [[Ebony Rod]] as well as tokens of the original seven [[cysgoroesi]] septs. * They cleanse the [[Heart of Iska kel Pana]]. * [[Mt. Fearg]] and [[Lyo Duo]] collapse entirely, leading to earthquakes that last for a while.
==Interlude== * Dil performs in [[Crisial of the Four Towers]], drawing significant attention and revenue. * The party goes shopping in the [[All-Things Bazaar]], where they learn that Dil's songs have been ripped off by house Beleth. * Dil and Tsun confront [[Bela'ka'Beleth]] and win contractual rights and residuals. * Azhekiel learns a bit more about his grandmother and the meaning of the green eyes.
==Dealing with Family/Southern Excursion== * With draconic assistance, they head off [[Nyx Astra]] and [[Tsen Azur]], along with their compatriots, at the entrance to the [[Gardens of the Fallen]]. Nyx and Tsen are slain. Iruk informs them of [[Gozh]]'s secret southern lair. * Rune meets [[Selai]], an elderly [[cysgor]] who seems to have a lot of knowledge about his past. * They arrive in the secret lair, where they are honey-trapped by [[Gozh]] and parlay with him. * They meet the [[Qu-ti]] [[zandolit]], where they learn of a group of green-eyed [[ophidian]]s who worship the [[Coiled Ones]]. * They try to parlay with the Speaker for the Cold Mother, but hostilities break out when the party is asked to partake in a ritual feast featuring the flesh of enslaved [[zandolit]] and other sophonts. * After defeating the Speaker, they venture into the ancient temple dedicated to the [[Coiled Ones]], where they gain the blessing of the spirits of the original builders (who were not worshipers of the [[Coiled Ones]]) and defeat the avatars of the [[Coiled Ones]]. * They parley with a summoned devil, who tells them that it has been conducting research into optimizing the output of worship. [[Gozh]], it seems, has been participating in this research. * Returning to the [[Qu-ti]], they engage in a verbal joust with [[Gozh]] himself, attempting to convince the leader of the tribe to abandon [[Gozh]].
==Interlude 2: Astral Boogaloo== * Dil and Tsun spend the next few weeks crafting scrolls. * Zeke travels south to visit the [[Lower-city Clinic]] in [[Kel'al'ar]], where he learns that the clinic was raided by a green-eyed follower of the [[Coiled Ones]], confirming that the beings are watching through his eyes. He also receives an invitation to visit with a "friend" of the [[Old Gods|Rainbow Serpent]] in the [[Astral]], which he does. There he receives a talisman that will temporarily keep the [[Coiled Ones]] out of his head, while he considers the offer of devoting himself to the [[Old Gods|Rainbow Serpent]] for permanent relief. * Rune gets gifts for the party and has a lyre crafted. * He also scries on [[Leah of the Orsa|a cysgor woman he knew]], and is surprised to see her alive and conducting an operation in (as it turns out) [[Toryuu City]]. * Tsun and Zeke meet [[Betsy Farthingale]], [[Tson]]'s fiancée and the grand-daughter of the former yarl of [[Bradford]]. They deed most of [[Hero's Rest]] to [[Tson]] as an early wedding gift, making him a major land-owner.
==The Dragon Congress== * The party arrives on [[Toryuu Island]] and is immediately overcharged for everything and condescended to. * Dil puts on a rocking concert, during which Rune sees (and chases down in the stree) one of the [[cysgor]] women that Leah was talking to. They seem to be watching [[Selai]], who has wrangled a place in a dragon delegation. And [[Erai]] gets really really drunk. Not that that's too unusual. * The party, with help from dragons, finds out that there's a "venting ritual" planned for the exact wrong time, and head out to find a way into the lava tunnels under the volcanic lair by investigating a sinkhole seemingly caused by separatist/rebel dwarves in the slums of [[Toryuu City]].

One of the three artifacts given to the ancient [[cysgor]] to seal the [[Pact with Death]]. Said to have great power over [[Shadow]]. Currently in three pieces. One of those pieces is held by [[Enigma]]; the whereabouts of the other two are uncertain, but it is believed that the heads of the Raven and Magpie Septs each have one.
Edit: as of 1 Winter Dying 250 AC, the rod has been reunited. Until a new cysgor Prime is chosen, it has chosen to adventure alongside [[Rune]].
== Personality == Quiet, no nonsense. Strongly dislikes [[Awakener]] and all related entities. Takes action first and asks questions...never?
== Powers == The ebony rod is a morphing weapon, capable of taking on the shape of a +3 quarterstaff (the default) or a +3 longsword whose blade is edged in force (dealing +2d6 force damage on a hit). In either form, it has the following abilities in [[Rune]]'s hand (each wielder gets slightly different properties):
* Two "floating" warlock invocations, switchable at the end of a long rest. Rune counts as having all his class levels in warlock for prerequisites for these invocations. * A flying speed equal to his walking speed, as the rod creates footholds made of force under his feet. * As an action, close any portals within 30' OR as a reaction, keep any portals (such as due to a teleport effect) open for 1 minute. * 7 charges, which can be used in the following fashion (regaining 1d6+1 at dawn) ** 3 charges: regain a warlock spell slot as a bonus action ** 4 charges: heal HP equal to the damage dealt during this turn, with extra becoming temporary HP ** 2 charges: All creatures within 5 feet must make a Dexterity saving throw against the Spell Save DC. On a failure, they take 4d12 force damage and their speed is reduced to 0 until the end of their next turn. ** 1 charge: Ranged spell attack (120 ft), one creature. Hit: 4d10+5 force damage and the creature is teleported to a point of Rune's choosing that he can see within 120 feet of him.

A group of entities. Only known information * they like snakes * worshipped/feared by [[ophidian]]s * have some connection to the [[Jungle of Fangs]], especially isal families. * connected with "green eyes" and sociopathic behavior. They supposedly "watch" from behind green eyes.
==Known Names== ; Cold Mother : Symbol is Oroborus encircling a pyramid of circles. ; Night Hunter : Symbol is Oroborus encircling stylized fangs. ; Face-stealer : Symbol is Oroborus encircling a blank oval.
==Antagonist== ; The Rainbow Serpent : Said to be a heretic/under-cutting force.
== Discoveries (250 AC by Enigma) == The Coiled Ones (and the Rainbow Serpent) are all that remains of the nobles of the [[Fanged Kingdom]], who cut a deal with the [[White Skull]] for the secret to apotheosis, to ascension to godhood. But the ritual failed (in part because they didn't read the deal closely and didn't realize something was missing). Instead, all the [[gwerin]] ended up in a lightless oubliette of a demi-plane, a prison in the [[Astral]]. There they subsisted on each other's Names (which had replaced their souls), merging until only four remained. Three desired power and dominance, the last wanted freedom and independence.
The baleful trio emerged about 200 years ago, in the aftermath of the [[Cataclysm]], but kept their presence secret. They started to build a worship base among their creations, the [[ophidian]]<nowiki/>s of the [[Jungle of Fangs]] as well as among others in the mountains to the north of the [[Great Rift]]. They also delt with [[Awakener]], channeling the energy from the planes themselves, granting them much more power than their relatively meagre, unenthusiastic worship base would suggest. This was destroyed, and their power substantially weakened, by [[Enigma]] in late 250 AC. The Rainbow Serpent operates in secret from [[Aaru]], although she has joined forces recently with the [[Queen Ascendant]] and come out of the shadows since the weakening of her arch-rivals (who sought to destroy her). AKA lizardfolk. One of the earliest creations of the [[Phoenix Empire]], possibly even pre-dating [[Moon's Fall]]. Only found in the [[Great Rift]] area of [[Soefra]].
As gleaned from reports from North Ithemba (as close as any scholar of the Sages has ever been), the zandolit have the following characteristics: * They're cold blooded, both physically and emotionally. They tend to think rationally or at least dispassionately. They sort-of understand emotions, but those don't have much influence over their actions, with a few exceptions. * Tribe and territory means a lot to them. "Us" vs "outsider" is a major concept; the word for "threat" and "stranger" are strongly related. Tribes tend to be smallish, a few hundred at most (including children). Gender is relatively irrelevant. Tribes are lead by a warleader advised by a shaman. * Most zandolit are content to deal with primitive technology (effectively stone age). Very few farm, although they are omnivorous. They tend to wander and/or live in crude huts. * Zandolit tend to propitiate/placate the kami; they only worship gods (or other ascendants) as "I'll pay you, but you better help me." They're not considered very devout. * Zandolit magic tends to the shamanistic (spirits, kami, and nature). * Zandolit are rarely subtle or deceptive. And strongly dislike those who are.
==Notable tribes== ;The [[Qu-Ti]] : An anomaly, living in a secreted valley under the protection of [[Gozh]], these zandolit are civilized and farm and have technology.

The ancient first servant of Primordial Death, an immense wyrm. Reclusive. Lair is the Infinity Gate. Guardian of said gate.
In ages past, he made a pact with the [[cysgor]] (the infamous [[Pact with Death]]), whereby the [[cysgor]] would watch over [[Shadow]], keeping it clean and moderating the factions of the dead. He also empowered the [[Gleaner]]s to serve as his agents in the mortal plane, communicating with them via a network of cats who serve as psychopomps and relays and partners for the [[gleaner]]s.
Around the start of the Third Age, the cysgor broke their pact and most of the gleaners were killed in an influx of demons.
Patron of [[Rune]] al'Tor.

revision.comment: /* Current (ca 250 AC) organization */
revision.text:
An organization started in the old [[Council Lands]] to coordinate the personnel and policy needs of that nation. Now serves a similar purpose in the [[Holy Kaelthian Republic]].
==Council Lands History== During the [[Council Lands]] era, wall-builders did not choose their own occupations or those of their children. Many don't even choose their spouses or their places of residence. So who does? The Oracles of the Oracle's Circle, that's who.
Acting like the Human Resources department of the guild-centric Council system, the Oracles coordinate manpower and assign apprentices within crafts and guilds. Of all the organizations of the Council government, they are the smallest and most highly-regarded (at least by the traditionalists). Radicals claim that they have become corrupt and that the entire scheme is nothing more than a way to keep the rich and powerful in their lofty, comfortable seats at the expense of the lower classes. It is certainly true that in recent decades the Oracles have become a major political force despite being theoretically a-political. Many of the highest-ranked oracles live comfortable lives in their cloisters through donations from the powers that be. And strangely, the sons and daughters of the rich and powerful tend to get chosen for prestigious and safe apprenticeships in the heartlands, not sent to the frontier. That being said, most of the Oracles are dedicated men1 who take their oaths very seriously and work in what they believe to be the best interests of the people and the nation.
The bulk of the organization are the Eyes, those oracles who travel between villages carrying out the day-to-day choosings and resolving disputes where they arise. They walk a circuit of 10-20 villages, trying to get to each village every other month (less in the winter when travel is hard). Dressed in simple grey, hooded robes and plain brown half-masks, they carry simple staffs and satchels said to be magically sealed against intrusion. Much of their time is spent gathering information, which they transcribe and pass up the chain. Without this core, the decision-makers higher up the chain would not be able to keep the system running. In truth, there are many more sources of information than just the obvious ones--most of the tavern-keeps and priests report to the Eyes.
The Hands are the enforcement arm. Trained as monks, they handle those changes where resistance is expected or act as bodyguards for the other members. Their staffs are wrapped in red leather bands and their masks are black. They travel in teams of 4 or 8, some of which might be capable of casting spells.
In each of the larger towns (a total of 20 or so) are the Local Oracles--one per town. These are the practical training grounds for new oracles after they leave the Cloister--each of the Locals has 3-5 trainees to act as runners, apprentices, and general helpers. They supervise the Eyes and call for the Hands to be dispatched where needed. A given town might have one Local and a squad of Hands, plus whatever Eyes are passing through right then. If needed, they can call on the local Temple guards and town militia for help. A Local Oracle wears a grey robe trimmed in fox fur and carries a staff with metal-shod ends. Their masks are grey edged in white.
In each of the regional capitals ([[Baile Craan]], [[Rauviz]], [[Yuuras Zaali]], and [[Fuar Uulan]]) are stationed the Regional Circles in addition to the Locals, each composed of four senior oracles with their staff (mainly trainees). They are responsible for the affairs of the region as a whole and are the primary power-brokers of the regions. Of the four, Rauviz's Circle is the most prestigious, with Fuar Uulan's being the weakest (since few wall-builders live there and the dwarves mainly ignore the oracles). Members of the Regional Circles wear white robes and carry white-wrapped staves. Their masks are white.
In Kaelthia proper are the First Circle, the Cloister, and the Minds. Technically only first among equals, the First Circle is the de facto leadership of the entire organization. Being asked to fill a spot on that circle is being promoted to the highest levels. It is also intensely political and connected. They spend their days mostly dealing with the movers and shakers of the Council and live lavish lives. They dress like those of the Regional Circles, except that their robes are of the finest materials and their masks often are jeweled.
The Cloister is the training facility and heart of the Circle. Carved into the eastern wall of the canyon, it overlooks the rest of the city but is inaccessible. Only the Oracles and their avowed servants can enter--not even the Guildmasters are allowed in. No women are allowed within, under any circumstances.
The Minds are the analytical engine that makes the whole system work. Approximately fifty men (plus trainees), chosen from the brightest candidates, they live full-time in the Cloisters and churn through rolls of parchment. It is they who collate all the data and decide which town gets which of their requests and how many of each guild there must be. While the commoners believe that they do so with mystical powers, they mainly employ sophisticated records and statistical means. They have records of every registered child born for the last 150 years (since the founding of the Oracle's Circle) and statistics about each legitimate town and village.
The High Oracle is chosen by the First Circle as an honorary leadership position. He is the face of the Circle, but certainly not a real power. His pronouncements are carefully written and monitored by the First Circle, and he cannot take any action without their approval.
Starting in late 210 AC, a rumor has spread that some of the oracles are experiencing prophetic dreams--becoming oracles in truth. It seems that the [[Archon of Time]], Mother of Visions, has taken an interest in them as they call themselves Oracles but do not work by Her aid.
==Current (ca 250 AC) organization== Much of the organizational structure remains, but the force is much reduced and the hierarchy is subordinate to the Temple. There are movements afoot to require them to accept women into their ranks, but they are the most conservative element and are very resistant to change.

A cliff-side mausoleum and cemetery complex in the [[Giant Spine Mountains]] between the [[Abandoned Clans]], [[Tuura Adam]] and [[Zhapai Karmap]]. Used for ages to bury important dead. Dominated by the Great Mausoleum where a statue of a seated titan with a wyrm coiled around the throne oversaw the entire complex since the First Age. In reality, those "statues" were [[Perkunos]] and [[Tatsuryuu]], frozen in stasis by an ancient curse. The complex was the site of a major disturbance as [[Tzeru]], driven insane by loss of duty, tried to raise an army of stolen souls in 212 AC. This was ended by the [[Wild Cards]] and the two prisoners were freed. Since then, the site has been monitored by forces from each nation, seeking to prevent another such event. [[File:Dead-halls-small.webp|thumb|Dead Halls, ca 250 AC]] Buried here are the heroes and villains of countless civilizations; not just the [[jazuu]] and [[dwarves]]--there are aelvar, orcs, and humans in their number. The last burial here dates to the late 3rd age, near the time of the Cataclysm, when the [[Flower Kingdom]] buried the one known as Kinslayer in the outermost tier. All other information about this individual was erased--only the name and the bizarre standing coffin remain.
The area itself still feels the residue of both the age-old binding curse that imprisoned the two Ascendants as well as the aetheric devastation caused by the fallen archangel in her mad attempt to breach the veil between worlds and call the dead back to life. As a result, the mausoleum decays very slowly--there are still skeletons and corpses from the Second Age. However, the feelings of the dead and the mourners and burial parties are etched into the stone itself, like the blast shadows of people erased by a catastrophic detonation. They are not ''undead''--there is no [[Jotnar|jotnari]] influence. But in such a solemn, broken place, even echoes can take physical form...and these ghosts are not happy.
As a result, the duty to tend this place has fallen to the [[Tattered]] and their Hands. These souls, as broken as the echoes they comfort, are among the few that can walk unmolested...for the most part. The Hands deal with the corporeal ghosts who refuse comfort, although their destruction does not last. The only peace comes from the Tattered themselves, as they accept the pain of ages, taking on themselves the burdens of the dead. Many only want to have their names said one more time...but many of the names have been lost. Erased from history intentionally or by centuries of weathering.

For all the blood and horror, they're also some of the most stable, well-meaning, ''chillest'' folk in [[Shadow]].

The fey spirit of the Mothertree, an ancient magical tree located in the north-west end of the [[Sea of Grass]], at the site of the [[Battle of Acceptance]] (and later the [[Pactum Battlefield]]). Fell in love with [[Archdruid Kantorell]], who served as the tree's guardian for decades before the war. After he was killed in that climactic battle, she preserved his body and drew inward, becoming hostile to all things and shifting from the Court of Autumn to the Court of Winter, becoming an icy being.
After his resurrection by the mercy of [[Melara]] and the choice of the [[Heroes of Pactum]], she and he founded the [[Pactum Grove]] and now administer that forest and druid circle. She still doesn't like most people or civilization, other than him of course.

revision.text:
Also known as the fishfolk, the god-makers, and "those annoying slimy folk", depending on location. One of the oldest people, these appear to be short (~4'-5' tall), purple-skinned (with slimy skin) humanoids with webbed feet and hands and fish-head-like faces featuring bulbous, wide-set eyes and pointy peg-like teeth. Despite their appearance, they are amphibious, although they require water to keep their skins moist and reproduce underwater (via laying clutches of eggs).
The ika-ika are one of the older races, dating back to sometime in the [[Ages of the World|2nd Age]]. Their origin is uncertain, but it is believed that [[Leviathan]] or its agents created them out of [[goblins]], hybridizing them with fish. They lack the shared-memory-space of the goblinfolk, and instead have an unnaturally-large ability to believe. Given enough concentrated belief, the thing believed in can become real, at least to some degree. This happens primarily with "gods", where a group of ika-ika find some shiny idol-object and venerate it, creating an astral reflection of that thing that then empowers them (as pact-bound). None of these are very strong, since most ika-ika are also relatively easily distracted to the new shiny. When faith collapses, so does the believed-in creation, at least if it doesn't have an external source of support.
It is believed that this trait was observed and used as the basis for the [[Ages of the World|Third Wish]], allowing the faith of other creatures to have a similar (if more muted but more permanent) effect.

A race of aquatic humanoids found throughout the seas of Quartus. Of all the children of [[Leviathan]], the kalasaa are the closest to surface-dwellers in shape and appearance. Ironically, they're also one of the less frequent of the sea-dwellers to interact with surfacers.
==Physical Appearance== Visually, kalasaa are human, except with non-human skin and hair tones, usually blues and greens. Their feet and hands are slightly webbed, and some have small fins on their lower arms and legs. Their eyes tend to be deep green. They average slightly shorter than most humans, with both males and females standing around 5' tall, although with significant variation. Sexual dimorphism is similar to that of humans, although females are just as large as males (on average). Kalasaa are stockier and hardier than most humans, and are fully amphibious and capable of swimming and living in the depths.
==Cultures== Many, if not most, kalasaa believe themselves to be the chosen servants of [[Leviathan]] and, in alliance with the other sea races, form war bands to hunt the servants of the [[Twisted]], especially [[mkhulu]] and [[comiedai]] who serve that demonic beast. They also consider themselves the keepers of the artifacts of civilizations lost under the sea. As a result, kalasaa society is martial, with strong emphasis on righteousness and order.
Most kalasaa settlements are in the deeper areas of the continental shelves, located hundreds of feet under the water, and they rarely approach the surface except on the hunt for thieves from their protected areas.
===Ikelan Kalasaa=== One exception to this are the kalasaa of [[Ikela]], a nation on the north-eastern coast of [[Soefra]]. Living in abnormally shallow waters (for kalasaa), the cities of [[Ikel'Mer]], [[Pel'Mer]], and [[Kal'Mer]] are shallow enough that the tops of the towers are exposed at low tide. They once were deeper until the [[Cataclysm]] reshaped the land. Adapting ably, they formed an alliance with the local human communities and ever since have conducted the business of a hybrid human/kalasaa kingdom. Unlike most kalasaa, they no longer worship [[Leviathan]]; instead they revere the Sea Mother, an aspect of [[Selesurala]] as well as a coterie of [[ascended heroes]], the [[Wave-minder]], the [[Walker of the Middle Path]], and the [[Eightfold Eye]].
[[Category: Races]]

Formerly known as [[Cherry Blossom Temple]], this temple (and now village) was renamed after it was reconstructed by [[Tson]] and company in 250 AC. By the end of that year, it had been fortified with a wall and a tower, and a village is beginning to grow around it. The walled area is roughly 2 acres (about 300'x300').
==Depiction== [[File:heroes_rest_built.jpg|800px|Hero's Rest, walled area ca spring 251 AC]]

Son of [[Tsun Azur]] (?) and [[Nyx Astra]]. Currently overseeing [[Hero's Rest]] and dating [[Betsy Farthingale]]. A practicing bard.
[[Category: Notable People]] [[Category: Duarchy]]

Grand-daughter of [[Lillian Farthingale]], the former yarl of [[Bradford]]. Engaged to [[Tson]] Azur, with a wedding scheduled for the end of winter 250 AC. Not incredibly traditional for a halfling woman, she's fine with men's liberation. As long as [[Tson]] is hers and no one else touches.
== Personality == She's picked up a strong snarky side, especially having dealt with [[Enigma]] and [[Ahzekiel Cai'Valur]]. Hiding underneath that is a young woman who cares about the people she feels responsibility for and a strong sense of justice.
'''Bond''': [[Tson Azur]]. Secondary: [[Bradford]] and [[Hero's Rest]].
'''Ideal:''' Justice. All should be treated as they deserve...or a little better. Especially those who can't help themselves very well.
'''Flaw''': She doesn't fit incredibly well with the rest of halfling society because she struggles to keep her mouth shut when someone pushes her buttons. [[Category: Notable People]] [[Category: Duarchy]]

Yarl of [[Bradford]] from the founding of the [[Duarchy of Kotimaa]] until 250 AC, when she was killed by raiders while they were desecrating [[Cherry Blossom Temple]].
==Family of note== * Rachael Bradford Farthingale, daughter, 40, currently acting yarl. Ineligible for permanent occupancy due to undisclosed health reasons. * Elspeth Bradford Farthingale, daughter, 26. Disavowed the position in favor of the priesthood of [[Peor-fala]]. ** [[Betsy Farthingale]], grand-daughter, 12. Dating [[Tson]] Azur. A contender for the position of yarl, but considered too young and untried.
[[Category: Notable People]] [[Category: Duarchy]]

Twin brother (except evil) of [[Tsun Azur]].
==Life Events== * Married off at age 10 to a small village in the [[Holy Kaelthian Republic]] * Exiled and embittered at the gods after killing a priest (for molesting a child). * Met [[Nyx Astra]] on the eastern frontier where he served as a cook in a bandit group. * Gathered followers and started raiding in the east * Coopted by [[Gozh]] * Raided [[Cherry Blossom Temple]] looking for [[Tson]] (who he believed was his son) as well as trying to express hatred of the gods. * Escaped with [[Nyx Astra]] to the [[Ladyfrost Mountains]], where he (hating being short) was taught demonic secrets of the [[Twisted]] by [[Xel'na]]. * He and Nyx trained an elite group for a raid on the [[Gardens of the Fallen]], a dragon graveyard * Killed by [[Enigma]] in 250 AC outside the [[Gardens of the Fallen]]. Went splat after being dropped from 90+ ft in the air, then stabbed by [[Tsun Azur]].
[[Category: Notable People]]

revision.text:
Some dragons become “changed” after the First Molt. These drakkons, as the “normal” dragons call them, lack some part of the draconic soul and do not progress through the usual age/molt cycle; instead they ''stagnate'', remaining in a perpetual adolescence of sorts. Drakkons are intelligent creatures, attuned to elements just like "proper" dragons, but two significant differences remain. First, they will never undergo the [[Dragons|Third Molt]] into proper adulthood. Their Second Molt is abbreviated, usually only a few days. The creature that emerges, although it is the size of a regular young dragon, is physiologically adult and capable of breeding. Second, drakkons never develop a proper sense of '''hoard'''. This means that they must draw their energy from the food that they eat; many dragons believe that this is the critical difference that prevents the proper Third Molt. This leaves drakkons feeling perpetually hungry, at least unless they can bond with a mortal partner (as described below).
==Frequency== Roughly 1% of hatchlings become drakkons (of the total 70% that fail their First Molt), although there is substantial variation in this rate. Currently, the flights of northern [[Soefra]] are experiencing a large upswing in the number of "failed" First Molts that result in drakkon. This has been on the increase for the last 100 years or so, but with a substantial increase in the last 5 years. Drakkons now make up the majority of failed First Molts, and failures are up to 80% of all hatchings. Some of the elder dragons there believe that this is a curse or effect imposed by some hostile party; others believe it is a natural birth defect.
Children of drakkon parents are always drakkons themselves. These "born" drakkons keep the elemental attunement of their parents (with random choice between the two if the two were of different colors) and are wyrmling-sized once they come out of the egg. They never go through a First Molt.
==Relationships with regular dragons== Throughout most of the world, drakkons are looked at as lesser. They are not counted as part of the flight and are generally driven out once their condition is known. Coupled with their driving hunger, most of the "rampaging dragons" throughout the world are actually drakkons, driven to desperation by the yawning void within.
With the substantial increase in drakkon population of [[Soefra]] has come a sort of societal acceptance within the flights there. A concerted effort to seek out bond-mates for the drakkons has led to the formation of organized [[dragon knight]] groups associated with each of the major flights. The drakkons of [[Soefra]] are desperate to prove themselves more than talking animals.
==Relationships with mortals== Mortals rarely can tell the difference. To mortals, drakkons are [[dragons]]. And their hunger gives [[dragons]] a bad name.
==Physical Description==
Drakkons are distinguished by slightly blunted features and muddier colors. They are physically slower, clumsier, and more vulnerable than regular dragons; immature drakkons are incapable of sustained flight (hopping in bounding glides instead) and mature ones are much slower than the young dragons they resemble.
==The Dragon Knight Bond== The only known way for a drakkon to fill the void within is to bond to a mortal partner in a mystic ritual involving mingling their blood and souls. The mortal gains power; the drakkon shares his soul, filling the missing pieces. Effectively, the drakkon’s hoard is their partner. Bonded drakkons grow swiftly based on the growth of their partner. The bond means that they will age and die with their partner as well, although that lifespan is greatly extended should the pair gain enough strength. The two gain an empathic link. This connection has its drawbacks, however, and should the knight fall in battle, the dragon too will die, as the dragon's spirit can't live without the knight. Should the dragon fall in battle, the knight can restore its body with a costly ritual. This makes the mortal partner the "senior" companion in the bond in most cases, a humiliation that regular dragons find somewhat shameful.
[[Category: Dragons]]
