A flight of dragons that, unlike most, maintains open political relationships with mortals and can be said to be a nation. Located north west of [[Ikela]], the two have been allies of convenience for generations, but relationships are somewhat strained right now (251 AC). By treaty, the flight controls all outside access to their lands.
== Organization == The flight proper consists of 2 ancient dragons, 6 adults, and a dozen young. Attached to the flight are three orders of [[Dragon knight|dragon knights]], bonded to [[drakkons]]. These latter serve as the local leadership in the villages of mortals that make up the bulk of the population. [[Category:Dragons]] [[Category:Ikela]] [[Category:Soefra]] [[Category:Nations]]

revision.comment: Created page with "The bright mirror of the Mortal, Mirrorhaven is influenced by and partakes in the flow of energy from the Astral plane. Its nature is of bright colors, constant movement, and..."
revision.text:
The bright mirror of the Mortal, Mirrorhaven is influenced by and partakes in the flow of energy from the Astral plane. Its nature is of bright colors, constant movement, and frenetic interplay of light and color. It is home to the Spring and Summer Court of the Fey, the assembly of spirits attuned to the “positive” emotions such as love, joy, devotion, pleasure, and the like. Do not be fooled by the names, however. Also associated with this layer is mania and illusion; nothing here is as it seems. Delusion is rampant; everything wears multiple faces. Decadence and lavish excess hide a hollow, insatiable hunger that cannot be filled—the shadow-stuff of which this is made is not stable or real enough to satisfy. The inhabitants continually search for greater and greater sensation to fill this numbness. The majority of the populace is the spirits of those departed mortal souls that were attuned toward the Astral, either as a life of devotion to the Gods or for personal reasons. Here they live a distorted reflection of their lives until either they lose track of who they are and dissolve into shadow-stuff, until they are devoured by one of the denizens, or until they press through to the [[Astral]] plane itself and carve out a residence there through transcendence.
The hub of Mirrorhaven is [[Centrum]]. This city once was the capital of the Western Empire of [[Noefra]] (known then as [[Imperial Center]]) until a tremendous magical explosion threw it into [[Shadow]] about 800 years ago. The inhabitants have become shadow-kin, beings made of shadow-stuff. All the decadence, excess, and mania of the layer are most concentrated here—the entire city is one continual, frantic, eternal festival. Souls drift in and are caught up in the celebration. The weak burn out quickly; the strong prey on the weak for survival.
Many of the gods and ascendants maintain enclaves here. [[Category:Shadow]]

revision.comment: Created page with "The capital of [[Tibor Imperia]] through most of the [[Ages of the World|Third Age]]. Located on an artificial island in the middle of [[Lake Coy'in]] (which was much smaller..."
revision.text:
The capital of [[Tibor Imperia]] through most of the [[Ages of the World|Third Age]]. Located on an artificial island in the middle of [[Lake Coy'in]] (which was much smaller before the [[Cataclysm]]) and connected to the mainland by 16 bridges, it showcased the power and magico-technological might of the empire. Full of gleaming spires and magical lights, it was a wonderland...if you were rich. Hidden underneath (literally, buried in the foundations and piles that held it up) was an undercity of despair and filth, a breeding ground for the living fuel for the empire's insatiable hunger.
It was destroyed in the opening act of the [[War of Souls]], when a band of rebels, sickened by the corruption and evil acts of the empire's mage cadres (especially the creation of the [[Dragonborn]] at [[Imperial Research Alpha]]) sacrificed themselves to throw the city and its inhabitants into [[Shadow]] during a meeting of the Imperial Senate and Court.
Now known as [[Centrum]], it is the home of delusions and dreams, of bright color and predators, at the center of [[Mirrorhaven]]. [[Category:Cities]] [[Category:Tibor Imperia]]

revision.comment: Created page with "Formerly the city known as [[Imperial Center]], it is the diseased jewel, the pretty poison at the center of [[Mirrorhaven]], the deceptive hub around which that realm spins...."
revision.text:
Formerly the city known as [[Imperial Center]], it is the diseased jewel, the pretty poison at the center of [[Mirrorhaven]], the deceptive hub around which that realm spins. All roads lead there...and none lead out. At least for the weak. The inhabitants of the mortal city it once was still prowl the streets a thousand years later, condemned to a shadowy existence, preying on the souls of the dead. The Spring and Summer Courts hunt there, bewitching mortal souls for their revels.
[[Category:Shadow]]

revision.text: Occupying roughly 1/4 of the entire volume of the [[Plane of Lightning]] (or about 1/48th of the entire volume of the universe), the Eternal Storm has been spinning since the planes were formed. An immense volume of cloud, lightning, sentient lightning, elementals, and strange beings, to enter it is to become lost. Very few that do enter it leave; of those, a few have reported seeing an eye, a calm spot that seems to drift around unpredictably. In that eye...a titanic fortress/city/''construct''. revision.text:
Running from the mountains north of [[Baile Craan]] and swallowing the [[Westwalk River]] and the [[Eastwalk River]] near [[Bradavon]] and falling into the <> River near [[Bradford]], the Craan River is the commercial lifeline of eastern [[Dreamshore]]. It also forms the border between the [[Farthingale Duchy]] and the [[Eastwalk Dutchy]] (with the headwaters of the [[Eastwalk River]] lying in the latter and [[Baile Craan]] officially lying in the former).
The Craan is navigable for most of its length, although in 237 AC a system of locks were completed near the capital to allow upriver traffic (where before they'd had to switch to land-bound transport about 10 miles downriver). It ranges from between 80 and 150 feet wide, with most of its length being ~20 feet deep. Fed by snowpack, it floods occasionally during the spring, but generally not badly or destructively. [[Category:Duarchy of Kotimaa]] [[Category:Rivers]]

revision.comment: Created page with "A short segment of river rising out of springs and snowpack in the [[Westmountain Dutchy]] and merging with the [[Craan River]] about 10 miles north-east of [[Bradavon]]. The..."
revision.text: A short segment of river rising out of springs and snowpack in the [[Westmountain Dutchy]] and merging with the [[Craan River]] about 10 miles north-east of [[Bradavon]]. The city of [[Montavon]] lies on its banks near the headwaters. Unlike the [[Craan River]], the [[Westwalk River]] is only navigable for the lower 1/3 due to large numbers of rocks and rapids. The [[Farthingale Duchy]] has talked about doing something about that, but no moves have been made as of 251 AC. [[Category:Rivers]] [[Category:Duarchy of Kotimaa]] [[Category:Dreamshore]]

Much broader and flatter than the [[Westwalk River]], the Eastwalk River arises in the [[Eastmountain Duchy]] of the [[Duarchy of Kotimaa]] and joins the [[Craan River]] at [[Bradavon]]. It is navigable for almost the entire length, and the city of [[Eastavon]] takes great pride in that and in the large barges full of grain and wool that traverse its length. [[Category:Dreamshore]] [[Category:Rivers]] [[Category:Duarchy of Kotimaa]]

Starting in early spring 251 AC, this party is exploring the lands of [[Ikela]] and the surrounding area.
== People ==
* [[Vijil the Watcher]] * [[Fai]] * [[Erland Nygaard]] and his companion Aegon the [[drakkon]]. * [[Jo'Vasha]]
== Adventures ==
* Meeting up in [[Surat]], they took a quest to handle issues with bugs and rats in the sewers there. They discovered active manipulation by forces later discovered to be in the pay of a member of the [[Sura family]], as well as a (false flag) attempt to sabotage the magical purification center for the sewers (with possibly catastrophic results). * [[Into the Nightmare Scar]] : A trip across the river led to the discovery of corrupted elemental nodes, some elucidation of [[Fai|Fai's]] memories, and making some friends. And discovering the influence of [[Korv'al'zagan]]. As well as some weird timey-wimey stuff. * Coming back into [[Surat]], they uncovered a devil-run plot to assassinate the [[Sura family]] head and blame it on the [[Jalshea Trading Company]]. This was stopped. [[Jo'Vasha]] also made friends with a pretty kitty. And the party killed the 3rd son of a noble of [[Sheopur]]. He had it coming, but... * [[Cleansing Greenwood Reach]] From there, they headed south to a place known as [[Greenwood Reach]], where Fai made a fiendish friend and time got really really complicated. *The trip to Fatehpur resulted in meeting powerful elven wizards and JoVasha's mom, who does ''not'' have it going on. Traveled south to investigate the magical storms that rage in this area. Met the Two Moons half-elves. Investigated the silver dragon in stasis and eventually freed her as well as restoring the song. *Varanasi was the next stop, and there's an infestation of demonic influence (Korv'al'Zagan yet again) they had to deal with. Ambushed, followed up and eliminated the cell. Jo'Vasha's sweetie Katya is starring in a musical being put on the the old school which horrifically mangles the adventures and accomplishments of Tempus Machina, all in service of promoting Jo'Vasha as The Prophet. The dream nodes arise as another possible quest soon. *In Varanasi, they destroyed a dream node...which made a mess and knocked them into the [[Astral]]. They fled via self-banishment, but ended up in the [[Phoenix Empire]], interrupting [[Phoenix Princess Leina]]'s party. *While in the Empire, they were accused of violating sacred law. While awaiting trial, Vasha had a direct encounter with the [[Archon of Time]] in a semi-dream state and...asked her out. *The day of the trial came in the imperial palace. Cats and machinations ahoy. And meteors. Big mess happened, ending with the death of several members of the [[Archmagistrate of Kel'tan]] as well as the Eternal Emperor himself. Party fled back to Varanasi and then to the capital. *There, they conspired and finally took down the dream nodes and the cult. Including blowing up the astral storage mechanism for all the siphoned power. And freeing the king from his imprisonment by the cult. The cult got outlawed. *Party was made minor nobles **Vijil got Morton's Thumb. **Fai got <the hospital place> **Erland got <TODO> **Vasha got the post of Knight of Redwing, an island on the route from Ikel'mer to Fatehpur. *After some downtime, they headed south toward Charn, hoping to find Erland's dad under the mountains. *They discovered an Outsider (the Other) protecting a small village of Adversary-changed creatures, including Fai's uncle Alois. They strengthened the Other, which allowed them to be protected through the Vale of Corruption. They also fought some really nasty things. *They freed some mutated ants. And touched a purple thing. *Going undermountain, they found and allied with the [[Goroesi]] living there. They also found Erland's dad, suffering from amnesia. *Searching for relics, they found the Mad One, a relic of ancient days. He had stolen a reliquary containing a piece of the Adversary's Name...supposedly. And in return, he wanted his own Name repaired, which required a sojourn in the Abyss, as it belonged to a demon called the Puppeteer. *They played games with the Puppeteer, earning his favor as well as the favor of many of the other Demon Princes. Fai got a "card" from the Jester. *Returning, they took a side trip to [[Aenimos]] so the Mad One could put his name back together. There they met and befriended [[Echidra]], rode on an airship, and talked to some people. *Council of War. *Now into the fire. Dropped the Other off to interfere with the surviving Archmagisters' plan to do BAD THINGS with all the death energy released by genocide. *Approaching Charn. *Fought through the outer defenses, broke into the Mindscape of the Adversary. Freed the captive [[Awakener]] elements, battled despair. Aided by gods and friends. Turned back time to smash [[Namebreaker]] into the Name of the Adversary, destroying it without destroying Hope/Despair *Accepted the freed (former) awakener elements.
== Short term consequences (~5 years) ==
* Revolt/slow-motion civil war in the former phoenix empire * Changes in the vale of corruption Becomes overgrown with magical plants, etc. * Wedding bells **Fai + Amare **Vasha x2 **Erland + Elise *Vasha starting teaching the people at Redwing Isle basic magic *Fai starting a fashion line *Ygraine and co unify nightmare scar *New "Progressive" faction of dragons rebuilds Greenwood Reach
== Medium term consequences (~15 years) ==
* Angels become more involved and less...scorched earth. * Political changes ** Becomes more of a parliament ** Constitutional monarchy * Guilds of "troubleshooters" * Torturing Heironymous (Vasha)
== Long term consequences and choices (rest of the lifespan) ==
* Erland is going to live a long time **Helping with Greenwood Reach **Travel **Watch over the area **Dojo for unconventional training * Vasha plans to clone himself and Katya at least once. **Learning runic magic **More kids **Kingdom building (bigger island) **Become a center/beacon of magic **6 kids: first son becomes wizard/cleric **~500 *Fai **Fashion line **Hunters guild: keeping tabs on powerful people, handling nodes **Hospital for aetherically challenged kids **Looking for other Proteans. **First kid: daughter/son named Ren **Normal lifespan *Vijil **Raising a family **Making weed **Training with military and locals + Watcher **4 kids: Goezur (s), Ida (d), Walker (s), Luca (d) **Water polo school **Cloned once

revision.comment: Created page with "Specifically ''living'' (or life-like) animated beings. Categories: == Animatrons and Clockwork == These are the simplest form, either brought to life by spells temporarily o..."
revision.text:
Specifically ''living'' (or life-like) animated beings. Categories:
== Animatrons and Clockwork == These are the simplest form, either brought to life by spells temporarily or constructed around clockwork mechanisms and simple magicite-powered cores. They cannot learn or grow and are extremely restricted in their responses to new information. Clockwork cannot be reprogrammed once constructed. "Bound", long-duration animatrons can be found in ancient ruins, but the secret to constructing such has been lost. Simple clockwork can be constructed, but generally limited to toy uses and simple contraptions.
== Golems == Golems are bodies of unliving matter animated by summoned and bound elemental forces (usually a combination of earth, water, and air; fire is too volatile) in the form of True Words. Unlike animatrons, golems can be given new orders and are generally imprinted with a core set of commands to obey the one holding the control wand or their creator. Suited mostly for brute labor or simple defensive tasks, golems are incredibly expensive.
Two notable sub-types of golems exist in [[Noefra]]--the metal and crystal Labor Constructs of [[Wyrmhold]] and the wood and stone Shrine Guardians of [[Byssia]]. Representing very different approaches to the process.
'''Labor Constructs''' are built in factories, with cores created in a laborious, very carefully-controlled aetheric environment. The True Words are taken from the purest elementals that can be summoned and rebuilt into specific forms. As a result, labor constructs are effectively interchangeable. Their control structures are standardized by model and each model is specialized for a single task.
'''Shrine Guardians''' are carved by the Byssian [[ihmisi]] and ''sung'' into life, inviting primal spirits to inhabit them and leave traceries on their cores. Each one is unique in both form and nature, and their behavior is quite unpredictable. They are set to guard the deepest, most sacred parts of the forests.
From the two of these come the majority of the [[soul-forged]].
Golems can be made in even larger forms, such as [[Ar Dolema]], the walking construct-fortress of the [[Jungle of Fangs]].
== Higher Constructs == The [[shadesteel guardians]] of the [[Cysgoroesi]] are empowered by actual souls which have been [[Blood magic|pinned]] into soul gems. They are effectively mechanical people.
It is rumored that before the [[Cataclysm]], the technomancers of [[Hammerhead]] had discovered how to make advanced golems capable of individual growth and independent operation while not being actually sentient. The methods of constructing these cores is unknown, however. [[Category:Magic]]

One of the largest mobile structures known. This walking fortress is born by four colossal (~100' tall) [[Construct|golems]] and powered by an ancient aether reactor of unknown provenance. During the [[Fanged Kingdom]] it served as the real command center and center for the ruling caste (with [[Ar Salem Dolem]] as the "front" capital). After the masters departed, it walked in an endless circle through the woods 100 miles (ish) NW of [[Asai'ka (City)|Asai'ka]] until it was found and the demonic presence was purged by the [[Catalysts]]. It eventually settled into a stationary state at a "dock" NE of [[Ar Salem Dolem]].
== Origin == The origin of this structure is unknown. Its architecture and means of construction do not match those of any known civilization, and the golem-heart and reactor are of technologies unknown to history. [[Category:Jungle of Fangs]] [[Category:Artifacts]]

A territory captain of [[Zagan]]. Works under Ikal'seka. Epithet is "The Snake in the Grass" His area of responsibility encompasses [[Ikela]] and its surroundings. Some timelines have him strongly connected to the Dragon Tyrant [[Kozhun]]. More subtle than many of his kin. [[File:Korval Symbol.png|left|frameless]]
== Cult == He is known to have created a substantial cult, known as the "Korvite" cult (or just "the cult"), in [[Ikela]] proper. Since the earliest days of the Dragon Tyrant, it has been the secret power behind most of the goings on. Only rarely do cult members take the top role in any public-facing organization, and when they do it's not the leadership of the cults themselves. They prefer to hide behind a façade of legitimate power.
=== History === Founded in ?? by ??, it was responsible for sending the assassins who killed [[Kozhun]]'s mate and children, thus depriving him of his hoard and leaving behind a torque emitting corrupting whispers. After corrupting him for a few decades as he slept on her bones, the cult promised him a replacement hoard via secret ritual involving channeling energy to him from elemental [[Ley Lines|ley lines]] and worship through stolen or extorted dragon eggs (taken from neighboring flights) and up through a sacrificial victim. This progressively made him more and more insane, leading to the hyper-destructive Tyrant known to history. This was really just an experiment in channeling energy, partially superseded by information learned from the [[Stormveil Center]]. What they really wanted was a way to manipulate the anima, especially anima of ''belief'' on a large scale. When the leaders had learned what they needed, they transitioned to the next part of the plan, starting the final war of Kozhun's reign and sending the 8 "founding heroes" (secretly under the command of one of the Cabal) to destroy the ritual and thus make Kozhun vulnerable.
Since the fall of Kozhun, they have burrowed deeper into Ikelan society, infiltrating much of the nobility, organs of commerce, the Church and military. Their current plan involves creating a network of altered aether manipulation nodes around Ikela to redirect all worship to Korv himself, as well as make devil summoning easier and stronger within the area. Unwittingly, their efforts have contributed substantially to the event surrounding the [[Reweaving]], and completing the network is likely to break the seal at [[Charn]] entirely, leading to the end of the world as we know it.
=== Organization === The cult is cell-like in organization, with a strong hierarchy both between cells and between cells.
==== Cell Structure ==== Each cell has a Cell Leader, who commands the Followers, of which there are between 2 and 10. A Follower in one cell might be a Leader of a subordinate cell. Higher-level cells know about their subordinate cells but the reverse is not necessarily true. Followers may or many not know their fellows and generally don't know about cells on their same level, at least officially.
Cell members tend to put a lot of effort into espionage directed at other cells. Backstabbing and infighting are endemic, as betrayal, blackmail, and outright murder are known and accepted means of climbing the status ladder.
==== Hierarchy ==== Most of the hierarchy is between senior cells and subordinate cells. Power is measured by distance from the Cabal, the ruling group. The Cabal always consists of 7 members, themselves broken into three ranks, denoted by the color of their (illusory) masks.
'''Masters''': The two Masters wear white and black masks and know all the details about the Gold and Silver Masks. The White Mask is the High Summoner, the "spiritual" leader of the cult and the direct conduit to the will of Korv himself and is always a powerful mage and summoner. The Black Mask is the High Inquisitor, the mortal arm of Korv. His is the role of enforcer of cult policy, and he is always a warrior of consummate skill. The two of them tend to wander and their own identities are well-kept secrets.
'''Gold Masks''': The 3 Gold Masks are the senior members of the Cabal under the Masters. As of early autumn 251, [[Tempus Machina]] have discovered that one of the privy advisors to King Ikel III is a Gold Mask. The Gold Masks know the identities of the Silver Masks but not the White and Black or each others' (by default anyway).
'''Silver Masks''': The 2 Silver Masks are the junior members of the Cabal. As of early autumn 251, [[Tempus Machina]] have discovered that [[Esla]], head of the South-bay Trading Company in [[Varanasi]], is a Silver Mask. The Silver Masks only know the identities of their own subordinate chains as well as those they've discovered.
The actual mask and attire characteristic of the cabal (a blood-red robe over red-enameled plate armor, with face obscured by a shining, featureless mask of the appropriate color, voice distorted) is generated by their medallions. The actual medallions are powered by unknown forces but contain masking spells so they are magical only on the closest inspection. The medallions can be replaced but only by the White and Black masks acting together. [[Category:Devils]] [[Category:Ikela]]

revision.comment: /* Districts */
revision.text:
Oldest continuously inhabited human city in the [[Great Rift]], it marks the (legendary) first landing point of humans in [[Soefra]]. Called "the City of Nobles" and "the city where history walks the streets." Despite its age, the only district that hasn't been rebuilt since the fall of the Dragon Tyrant (ca 150 YBP) is First Landing, and only the Old Palace itself dates back more than 200 years.
== Architecture == Mirzapor is a city of contrasts. It's full of grand estates and slums, often coexisting in a single district. The architecture is designed to look old, with upswept roof timbers and grey-tiled roofs. Walls are half-timbered at best; many are made of paper and latticework. Stone is rare and reserved for the Families (as well as the foundations for buildings built on the remains of what came before).
== History == Founded by the first settlers in about 1100 BC, it was the last bastion of "civilization" after the northern retreat from [[Soefra]]. The [[Kingdom of Mirzapor]] was founded there in about 600 BC. Under the reign of [[Kozhun]] it was notable for being the most harshly repressed city, ruled by the most cruel of the [[Dragon knight|Dragon knights]], with despotic laws enforced supposedly at the direct command of the Dragon Tyrant himself.
After the fall of [[Kozhun]], [[Ikelan Hero|Arjuna Mirza]]'s wife Apsalar threw her weight behind Rama Ikel, brother to [[Ikelan Hero|Ramajar Ikel]], the leader of the heroes, leading to Rama's ascension as King Ikel I. For that concession, Mirzapor has long considered itself the cultural and religious center of [[Ikela]].
== Demographics == Mirzapor is dominantly human, the least diverse city in [[Ikela]]. The only significant non-human population is in the Seafoam district, a combined land-and-water area for the [[kalasaa]]. A [[dragon knight]] named Roald of Moonshell occupies an estate with his companion in the Academy district and serves as the ambassador for the [[Moonshell Dragon Flight]] in the area.
The population of Mirzapor at the last census was 25430.
== Districts ==
* [[File:Mirzapor.png|thumb]]First Landing: Still surrounded by the remains of the original wall built by the first queen of of the [[Kingdom of Mirzapor]]. Small, cramped, but fabulously expensive houses as well as the main CCU temple. This is where the Mirza family and its close allies live; the Old Palace is also located here. * Cliffside: The noveau riche live here, perched precariously above the river mouth. * Garden: One of the newer districts, this is mostly occupied by the second-tier nobles (Third Houses) and upstart merchants playing petty noble. * Sandor: Just down the hill from the Gardens, this was a nice area. It's now occupied by formerly-successful, but now struggling houses. * Gorai: Mostly commercial, with many of the master crafters. * North Docks: The nicer docks for goods coming from the bay. Carefully patrolled. * Vihar: Home of the third-tier "nobles" and wannabes. Known for being ultra-straitlaced and aggressively socially conscious * Naigon: Not as bad as Mulagon. * Mulagon: The slums. Cramped warrens of rickety shacks. Located right in the main flood plains, it tends to wash away frequently (every few years). Locals say it keeps the stink down. The outer streets bordering it are actually built up 10' or so. * Academy: Home of the [[Royal University of Mirzapor]], preeminent (in their own eyes at least) institution of higher education and learning. Surrounded by larger estates and pocket "farms" (mostly of flowers or other inoffensive, socially acceptable plants. * Rice Docks: One of two main landing sites for traffic coming down (or up) the river. More respectable than South Docks. * South Docks: The other major riverine landing site. Known for having a heavy criminal element. * Panju [Pan-zhu] Island: Home to one of the major "monasteries" and priestly training grounds for the CCU. Also, not coincidentally, home to the red light district. Connected to the North Docks by the White Span, an ancient, magically-enhanced bridge spanning more than 3000 ft of river, high enough for even tall-ships to pass under safely (although most do not). A few smaller islands to the north also are bridged--they contain gardens and green space owned by the Mirza family. * Second Estate: Slums. More spread out than Mulagon, full of dockworkers, warehouses, and teamsters for the South and Rice docks. * Third Estate: Home to large "semi-country" estates for the Second Families. Places away from the prying eyes and wagging tongues of the city proper. * Arjuna Naval Base: One of two major fitting yards for the Ikelan fleet, as well as Central Fleet Command and home of the Naval Archives.
== Government == Ruled by Surya [[Mirza]] who took the throne in 247 AC after the death of her mother, Leyli Mirza. Niece to the mother of the current King of [[Ikela]].
== Other == [[Category:Cities]] [[Category:Ikela]]

revision.text:
A port town and center of commerce, Varanasi considers itself the most "modern" and cosmopolitan city of [[Ikela]]. [[File:Varanasi.png|thumb]]
=== Population === About 45,000 as of 251 AC. Mostly human, but with a significant kalasaa sub-population and a healthy mix of all other Ikelan lineages.
== Government == Ruled by Stepan [[Varana]].
=== Noble Families ===
* [[Varana]] [var-AN-uh]: First Family. Family manor is at location 8. * Varan'a [var-an-AH]: Branch family and significant power. Family manor is at location 8. * Ghadee [GHA-dee]: minor family, but (covertly) the hosts for the [[Watcher's Order]] Headquarters
=== Other Notables ===
* Jo family: a rare notable family of [[sher-ka]]. [[Jo'Ranna]] is one of the foremost wizards of the city, while her husband Jo'Darsha is a widely-traveled merchant in antiquities and curiosities. [[Jo'Vasha]]'s family. * Head Magistrate Gosha [GO-shah]. Head of the Judges for Varanasi and the region. Despite the judicial oaths, he maintains close relationships with many of the luminaries. * South-Shore Trading. Local member of the Iron Rice Bowl, the dominant trade cartel that controls over 80% of the grain flow into and through the three big cities ([[Ikela]], Varanasi, and [[Mirzapor]]). Headed by the bright newcomer [[Esla of Kal'mer|Esla]], a [[kalasaa]] woman in her thirties who rose to prominence suddenly when she became the favored heir to the previous head and then took over when he passed away (of natural causes).
== Other ==
* Home of the [[Sea-Song Academy]] and the [[Sea-Sky School]]. * Home of the headquarters of the [[Watcher's Order]] * Home of the Broadway-equivalent set of theaters. Known for musicals and magic-assisted plays.
== Economy == As the southern port city and gateway to [[Merais]], Varanasi is dominated by shipping and other trade interests. [[Category:Cities]] [[Category:Ikela]]

A [[Plane-touched|infernal plane-touched]] [[dragon knight]], bonded to [[Aegon]], an amethyst [[drakkon]].
Part of [[Nameless Soefra Party]].
Erland grew up in the small town of [[Pasona]] in the north of Ikela and was born to a human woman named Evelyn Nygaard. He never knew his father--Evelyn did tell Erland that his father was important and had people after him. So he left to protect them. On his 12th birthday, his mother gave him a heavy signet ring on a chain that she said had belonged to his father. A few months later, unfortunately, she died under mysterious circumstances. Erland wasn't convinced it was natural as Evelyn was perfectly healthy before. Erland was taken in by Qira Hastra, who was the town blacksmith, and her daughter Daelynn. Qira had been a good friend to Evelyn and Erland had been working with her since he was 10 in an informal apprenticeship.
When he was 13, some people came and told him he was being taken to a school for gifted and talented individuals in Varanasi. He jumped at the chance to see more outside of town, but wasn't sure why he was chosen. While he was there he made some friends (the rest of the group) and, for the most part, enjoyed his time there. He also had a habit of sticking up for others at the school, which earned him both friends and enemies.
He left the school when he was 17, and eventually made his way back to [[Pasona]] and went back to working with Qira. One night a few months later, he was outside and saw something crash to the ground. His curiosity got the better of him and he went to see what it was. What he saw was a small dragon that was the color of amethyst. It was injured and, over the next month, he took care of it, though the relationship was a bit rocky at first. He named the dragon [[Aegon]]. One day, a couple months later when he was checking on Aegon, a group of well armed and armored people surrounded him and Aegon. Their leader, a Triton man named Ralis Moreno, seemed to recognize Erland's necklace and stepped forward. He asked Erland where he got the necklace, and a wicked look spread across his face at the answer. Ralis said that Erland and the "beast" were coming with him. Naturally, Erland refused to back down and it was at this moment the bond between Erland and Aegon solidified. Erland's eye became more draconic and turned the color of amethyst. He and Aegon attempted to fight them off but there were too many and the hunters had actual combat training. Just as Ralis was about to finish Erland, there was a blast of lightning and a blue dragon with a man riding it landed near the hunters, causing them to flee. The man picked up Erland and patched him up. He noticed Aegon then introduced himself as Jon Mallory, a Dragon Knight. He then told Erland that, due to the bond with the [[drakkon]] (as Jon called Aegon) that Erland had the chance to become a Knight. He looked at Aegon then back at Jon and accepted. The strange group then made their way back to town and was subject to many strange looks and whispers. Erland said his goodbye's, gathered his few belongings and left with Jon.
He stayed and trained with the Dragon Knights until he was 19, and made a couple of friends: a half-elven woman named Calia Amann (who bonded to a silver drakkon) and a human man named Jaiden Thatcher (who bonded to a green drakkon). Together, the three of them traveled as their own Free Brotherhood band. It went well for several months. Unfortunately, it didn't last. The group had met up with another Brotherhood band and were camping with them when Jaiden and his drakkon suddenly attacked both groups without any explanation. He managed to kill the other Knights (with skill both he and his drakkon shouldn't have at this level of training) and wounded Erland and Calia before disappearing. Shortly after, Calia left to join the Moonshell flight as a Flightbound. Erland managed to contact Jon a short time later, and it turned out Jaiden had managed to convince a majority of the other Free Brotherhood Knights (though not all, Jon being one of the main ones that didn't believe Jaiden) that Erland was to blame for the death of those Knights and that Erland was to be exiled and a bounty had been placed on his head. Erland had no choice but to stay on the move and turn to basic mercenary work.
Most of the time, his jobs weren't well paying and, due to his nature as a tiefling and [[Dragon knight|Dragon Knight]], he was rarely well received (which made getting work rather difficult). Some jobs were less legal than others. However, his luck seemed to change when he came across a job for a noble family in [[Mirzapur]], the [[D'Arcy]] family. They needed someone to find their daughter and bring her home. Erland met with them and took the job, though he felt like something was off. It took him a few months, but he was finally able to track down their daughter. Their first meeting actually escalated to a fight (despite her seeing the drakkon, which didn't seem to faze her, much to Erland's surprise), one that, surprisingly to Erland, ended in a stalemate. Once they both calmed down, she ended up giving her side of the story: her parents, her father in particular, effectively kept her prisoner (gilded cage sort of thing) because she's "different" (i.e [[Plane-touched|celestial plane-touched]]) and she was worried what they might end up doing. She decided she'd had enough, ran off and had no desire to go back. Her story resonated with Erland, who knew what it was like to be "different" and he, to her surprise, decided to not take her back. They parted ways and Erland went back to Mirzapur and was brutally honest with Elise's parents when they questioned him on where their daughter was, telling them exactly what he thought about their treatment of her. Unsurprisingly, this didn't go over very well and Erland was then attacked by their guards. During the ensuing fight, Elise appeared and helped Erland and Aegon get away. A short time afterwards, Erland questioned Elise on why she came after him, to which she responded that she knew her parents wouldn't have accepted she wasn't coming back. She also said she felt she owed Erland for not just dragging her back when he could've easily done so. Next thing he knows, she kissed him (fade to black). They stuck together for a couple months before the trouble with Elise's parents caught up to them and forced them to part ways. He then travels with Aegon while doing whatever work he could find to keep himself and Aegon fed. Eventually, he found his way to Surat where he found Fai, Jo'Vasha, and Vijil.
== Personality == Sarcastic, reckless, and somewhat arrogant. These are the qualities that Erland presents to the majority of people. But the people he's closer to will see someone who is terrified of his past(his father and the unknowns with that) and the feelings of inadequacy that came from what he considers his "failings." He's also fiercely protective of the people he's close to.
'''Ideals:''' Can't stand bullies, nobility, and people with huge egos. He'll quickly jump to the defense of victims of these types of people (which led to many bruises and broken bones when he was younger).
'''Bonds:''' He'll do whatever he can to keep the people he cares about safe even at the cost of his own health and safety. Despite many in his Order thinking him a traitor, he still considers the Dragon Knights to be his family and wants to find a way to clear his name.
'''Flaws:''' Has a bad habit of rushing in without thinking. He can also be rather greedy and frugal when it comes to money. [[Category:Adventurers]]

A human(?) man(?) with strange body-modification powers. Doesn't remember much of his(?) recent past.
Part of [[Tempus Machina]].
Age: 21-22
'''Backstory''':
Fai had met the party during his early teens. He had been staying with his uncle, Alois, when he had been in the academy for gifted students. After attending the academy for some time, his family had an emergency regarding Reya, his younger sister, who had some physical issues from birth. He had gone back home to be with her. Before he left, he made a promise to the party that he would go adventuring with them when this whole situation was settled.
Before he met the party again, Fai had somehow gained his Protean ability. He has very fragmented memories, to where he mainly remembers brief glimpses of the past. He does remember two distinct things- his promise to meet the party again and Reya calling out to him.
He woke up a couple months before meeting the party, where he travelled on his own. During these travels, he learned of his abilities as a Protean (completely on accident). However, he also found out the hard way that people don’t respond well to his mutations. So he is a bit nervous around people and using his mutations.
'''Goals''': find out what happened to himself and to find Reya
'''Interesting Tidbit''': Fai doesn’t look like the rest of his family. His family is a lot more tan, with dark hair and brown eyes. He has golden eyes, very light tanned skin, and was initially more honey hair, which has now been dyed darker. There were rumors that he may have been an affair child or something. Who knows.
'''Relationships''':
''Father and mother''- he does not remember them, but they may be alive. Or dead. Update: Fai's mother and father are (in the current timeline) alive. Due to memory shenanigans, his mother had been forced to forget him (and Reya).
Reya- younger sister, who is about 18. Fai briefly remembers some memories of her and the two were very close. Most of his memories involved her being in bedrest or using a cane to walk. Fai wants to find her. Update: She's living in a school for those with aether sickness.
Alois- his uncle who worked at the school and was an ex-military agent. Fai wanted to initially join the military and make a name for himself, so he was sent to school at the academy with Alois as his mentor. Update: Alois is alive, but corrupted by the Adversary. Currently living in the village of [[Makari]] near [[Charn]].
Fai was sort of the second priority of the family due to Reya’s condition. Reya’s condition could go from good days [able to move around with a cane] to bad days [complete bed rest, needs constant care]. For this reason, Fai’s family spent more time taking care of Reya. Fai decided to go to live with his uncle temporarily so he could train to be a knight AND so it is easier on his parents [one less kid to worry about]. As a child, he did have some issues with wanting to be the best/trying to get his parents’ approval due to them favoring Reya. Timeline note: in the current (modified) timeline, Fai's parents had retained their noble status and much of their wealth.
== Seeker and Watcher == Fai's mother's family, stretching back to the first humans to settle in [[Soefra]], had become associated with [[Charn]] and its wards. Each generation saw two important figures from the bloodline--the Watcher and the Seeker. The Watcher was always a woman, chosen to keep the book of records and the memory of [[Charn]] (and their connection to it) alive. Each Watcher selected and trained the next Watcher. The Seekers were sent, in company of the previous Seeker (now called the Guide) to [[Charn]] to re-establish the link to the outer warding layer.
Fai is the last Seeker; it was during this trip with Alois (the previous seeker, now the Guide) that the [[Reweaving]] occurred (due to a breach in the outer wards). [[Category:Adventurers]]

revision.comment: Created page with "The first and greatest creation of the [[Prehistory|Dreamer]] before the establishment of the planes. They embodied potentialities and concepts. Although to say that they were..."
revision.text:
The first and greatest creation of the [[Prehistory|Dreamer]] before the establishment of the planes. They embodied potentialities and concepts. Although to say that they were discrete individuals is...difficult. Each of the primordials was separate and distinct from each other, but the primordials themselves could fragment themselves and be in many places at once, sharing the same consciousness. Although to say that there was "place" and "time" at that point is ''also'' difficult. But that's the closest analog for our limited minds.
== Eight and One == There were originally eight-and-one (the number one greater than eight is...ill-omened to this day) primordials The Eight were
* Fire (Energies) * Earth (Solid matter) * Air (Gasses) * Water (Liquids) * Light (Law, Progress) * Darkness (Memory, Stability) * Life (Organization, Creation) * Death (Destruction, Decay)
And the one, later called [[Nameless]], was Change (Mediation, Disorder, Adaptation).
The four elemental ones, in cooperation with Life, created and organized matter. Death broke down that matter, recycling the unneeded parts down into raw dream-stuff for reuse. Light and Darkness managed to constrain progress with a memory of what worked and what shouldn't change; Change mediated between the others, acting as the grease in the cogs. Overall, the Dreamer watched and dreamed the plan.
== Lesser Concepts == The eight-and-one primordials could not do everything, so they petitioned the Dreamer to give life to fragments of themselves, naming them Concepts. Causality, order, vengeance, happiness, peace, discomfort, all these and more were Concepts brought to life by the Dreamer.
Even lesser beings such as elementals and the First Races were created as the Dream progressed, living among the glorious assemblage of matter and energy, all planes mixed into one whole. Each serving a role in creation's design.
== Fall into Conflict == For an unknown reason, [[Nameless|Change]] rebelled. He abandoned his role as buffer and lubricant and mediator, desiring to shape the newly-born creation to his whim. The others, of course, rejected this usurpation. There was war in the Dream; Concepts were weaponized; some Broke and became the [[Broken Concept|Broken Concepts]]; others remained intact but diminished. The [[Nameless]], his name and dominion now stripped, warped many of the lesser races into monsters.
Sometime during this conflict, the [[Oblivion Gate]] was torn open, releasing [[jotnar]] into the Dream. This caused the Dreamer to step in, fearing that the anti-life entities would destroy the dream entire. He cast the [[Nameless]] and the [[Broken Concept|Broken Concepts]] into the [[Abyss]] to serve as the plug to contain the gate. The other primordials, wounded and distorted by the conflict, he turned into the planes themselves. The intelligent followers of each "loyal" Primordial were given the choice to join their prince in the newly-formed plane or descend to the Mortal and take on life there. The [[proteans]], the poor cursed followers of the [[Nameless]], as well as all the living weapons created by that entity, were condemned to the Mortal, to live and die there.
Even with this, the primordials retained some semblance of identity, acting as the will of the planes (to some limited degree).
== Cataclysm War's Ending == At the [[Battle of Acceptance]], the 8 and 1 were reunited--the [[Nameless]] in the hijacked body of an elven magus, the Eight having been invited in by loyal mortals. There, they all enacted a ritual sacrifice, destroying their hosts and their essences to stabilize reality and allow Change its proper place in reality. Many of the [[Broken Concept|Broken Concepts]] were healed at that point as well.
However, as multi-valued entities, it is unknown whether all fragments of the primordials were destroyed. It is believed by some scholars that [[Wayland Smith]] is actually a pre-Dawn War, loyal fragment of Change itself; if this is the case, there might be others as well. [[Category:Metaphysics]] [[Category:Historical Interest]]

revision.comment: /* Fixed Points */
revision.text:
If time is a river, then every action is like throwing a rock into the flow. Most merely cause some splashing; momentary (pun intended) splits that instantly rejoin. If time is a bundle of yarn, knotted and webbed, then most decisions merely fuzz the fibers. But some actions cause divergence. The stream cannot trivially rejoin around the rock, part of it diverted over a cliff (ok, the metaphor is getting out of hand).
== Critical Points == Some decisions occur at critical points, where any change is fraught with consequences. These critical points cause splits in the timeline that last more than momentarily. An example of such a critical point was the instability encountered by the [[Phoenix Empire]] upon the occasion of the first regeneration of the [[Eternal Emperor]]. It was touch and go--in one timeline, he survived and was reborn with increased strength but with a need to consolidate, leading to the empire's withdrawal from the [[Great Rift]]. In another, he died, and with him the empire.
Note that timelines, once split, can rejoin later. But that requires another substantial event in one or both timelines.
== Locality == Timelines are not universal. The effects of decisions tend not to have huge scope--a "froth" decision might only reach as far as one person's life; no splitting occurs for anyone else, not even for an instant. A significant point may cause divergence across a continental scope (such as the above-mentioned elven empire decision).
== Fixed Points == Unlike a critical point, where differences in behavior lead to splits, a fixed point is an event that occurs across a bundle of timelines. The exact details may vary but the core similarity remains. One such event was the [[Cataclysm]] itself; another the ascension of the [[Archon of Time]]. The [[Reweaving]] is another fixed point for the timelines in and around [[Ikela]].
== List of Timelines with critical points == {| class="wikitable" |+ !Timeline Nickname !Area Affected !Critical Point !Decision !Description |- |Prime |Everywhere |N/A |N/A |This is the timeline that all the adventures follow/create by default |- |Fantasy Communism |Sea of Grass |Which party was assigned to Yuuras Zaali |Regime Change |In this timeline, the catalyst-equivalents came back and overthrew the Council Lands government, instituting fantasy communism instead |- |Frost and Fire |Sea of Grass |Which party was assigned to Yuuras Zaali |[[Fire, Stone, and Cold]] |In this timeline, the [[Catalysts]] were elsewhere and the listed party handled the Four Towers. Rejoined Prime soon after. |- |Elven Kingdoms |[[Great Rift]] |Did the [[Phoenix Empire]] fall? |Yes |Gwerin stayed in the great rift, resulting in mixed kingdoms. The home timeline of [[Tor Ysa]]. |- |Diabolical Doom |[[Ikela]] |Was [[Kozhun]]'s mate killed by devil-inspired assassins? |No |Kozhun as peaceful ruler, Greenwood Reach invaded by devils ~100 AC. |} [[Category:Metaphysics]]

revision.text: Once a devil of Family [[Malphas]], Patitziba was the prime architect for the [[Pactum Battlefield]] and volunteered to be sequestered as an anchor for the Inner Barrow in order to watch over and observe its functioning. He interacted with the [[Heroes of Pactum]], granting them back-door access to some of the other Reprobis' domains in exchange for access to study [[Walker]], having never seen a [[soul-forged]] before. After the arcane structure was torn down in the events of [[Redeeming the Lost (Campaign)|Redeeming the Lost]], he returned to his former Family as Pe'vel'Malphas. [[Category:Devils]]

revision.comment: Created page with "Jo'vasha was born in the year 234 AC making him 17 when he left home. When asked, he tells people that he is 19, in order to avoid being viewed as a minor. [[Jo'Raani]], his M..."
revision.text:
Jo'vasha was born in the year 234 AC making him 17 when he left home. When asked, he tells people that he is 19, in order to avoid being viewed as a minor. [[Jo'Raani]], his Mother, a [[sher-ka]] woman, and renowned (but mistrusted) wizard who taught at the [[Sea-Song Academy]] in [[Varanasi]]. [[Jo'darsha]], his father, is a [[sher-ka]] merchant specializing in exotic goods such as spices. His father was distant, teaching him only to speak when spoken to, as his hope was to bring the Sher-ka race the respect and honor that it lacks in the region. Together the two made enough gold to own an upper class estate within the Academy District of Varanasi.
From a young age, he has been kept within his family home by his mother. She was extremely overprotective of him, refusing to allow him outside unless she was with him. She began homeschooling him at 2 years old, teaching him how to read and do basic math. By the time he was 10, she began training him in wizardry. His real passion was in art (specifically drawing), though he lacked the ability to perceive abstract concepts, so his drawing are always extremely realistic portraits and landscapes. It was around this age, that he met his three friends [[Fai]], [[Vijil the Watcher|Vijil]], and [[Erland Nygaard|Erland]]. They would sneak him out (mostly out of pity, or so he believed), to play with them.
At the age of 12, he witnessed the shattering of reality known as the [[Reweaving]] during what seemed to be a dream. Something made him forget most of the event, but what he does remember is the image of a women staring down at him, with eyes that reflect the scene infinitely. After that event, he would spend hours attempting to draw her again. Each image was slightly different (hair style, or color, or nose shape etc.). He was never satisfied, always feeling like something about the picture was off. It was after this time that he dove into his research into the figure, and took his studies as a budding wizard seriously. He learned the figure was the [[Archon of Time]]. Through what he could find on her, he began learning the ways of channeling the magic of time. His eyes turned a deep black, with slowly drifting mist within and giving them incredible depth.
Five years passed, and as the years went on, he made more attempts at leaving. His mother was extremely abusive. From emotionally stunting him by the constant over-protection, to physical abuse or, as she would say "smacking some sense into him" if his assignments weren't up to her expectations. His attempts included trying to learn how to teleport short distances (misty step as it is called), only for his mother to catch him halfway through his spell scribing. As well as midnight dashes over the estate ground walls and into the streets, only for her to somehow find him within minutes. His escape was finally successful one night when he found a letter, instructing him to head southwest, to a far off town called [[Surat]]. He didn't know who sent the letter, but he believes the mysterious sender found a way to get his mother out for a long enough time for him to steal the misty step spell inscription, and escape his family home. He made his way our of town and down south as quickly as he could, hoping his mother wouldn't find him as he reconnected with his childhood friends and began an incredible journey.
== Personality == Timid, with outbursts of strong emotions in times of innocents being in distress. Has a tendency to overthink, leading to him mumbling and rambling quietly. Occasionally enjoys breaking the minds of women with what he has seen or knows, due to his past.
'''Ideals:''' Will do anything he can to pursue his research into the Archon of time, wishing nothing more than to meet her. Also very attached to his art, having originally wanted to become an artist, if not for his mothers forced teaching of the arcane.
'''Bonds''' The few friends he met in his childhood (Fai, Vijil, and Erland). Later adding Aegon and, most importantly, The Archon of Time.
'''Flaws''' Extremely timid around women, often flinching at attempted physical contact between them. Tries to stay as far away as he reasonably can, when in proximity. Abstractions, as well as metaphors, often elude him. Usually takes such things completely literally. [[Category:Adventurers]]

revision.comment: Created page with "An order of Oath-sworn (aka paladins), as well as others dedicated to their cause. Not very organized, it exists throughout [[Noefra]] in small cells, totaling maybe 50 people..."
revision.text:
An order of Oath-sworn (aka paladins), as well as others dedicated to their cause. Not very organized, it exists throughout [[Noefra]] in small cells, totaling maybe 50 people. Each cell is usually a knight and his fellow aspirants and maybe an ally or so. A significant number of pact-bound, often who have pacted with [[Redemption]]. Their oath is * to protect the light from the darkness, * to take on the sins of the world so that innocents don't falter. * to train so that when they're condemned to the Waste for their sins, they can fight the demons there on equal terms from the inside and break the doors of Hell. Despite Hell not really being a thing... == Poem ==
I am the last tear of the sinner I am damned; my sins haunt me. There is no forgiveness for my deeds; When I die, the demons will appear. -- I am the tear of the sinner Shed so that no one else must suffer The way I did. -- I am the gloves that wallow in grime That the hands may remain clean I am the overcoat, battered by filth And discarded lest the frock be spoiled. -- I am the tear of the sinner And when the demons come to drag me down I will fight them on their own turf and break open the gates From within

A small settlement on the western edge of the [[Blood-thirst Wildlands]]. Founded by the [[Freeport Company]] in 249 AC, it hopes to become a gateway for settlement and exploration of the wildlands.
Not technically part of [[Byssia]], the Company acts as the government, in conjunction with a mayor chosen from the settled folk. It's only current trade routes are with [[Byssia]] proper, so its independence is notional unless another route can be found. Currently Byssia has no interest in administering it, although that might change if the port is developed or becomes a threat to their interests. ==Population== Roughly 200 individuals, about half of which are farmers and the rest are either dock workers or would-be adventurers.

A school for exceptional individuals in [[Varanasi]], [[Ikela]]. The Headmaster is a reclusive individual with bardic talents, known for being very well connected to all the rumor networks.
== Student Population == The Academy houses roughly 150 students at a time, of which generally 50 are drawn from the First and Second Families and the rest are from wealthy merchanter families or scholarship students. The scholarship students are chosen by methods and for reasons known only to the Headmaster, but his track record of picking people who will go on to make waves is...impressive.
== Course of Study == Every student takes courses on
* Ikelan and world history * Races and cultures of the region * Basics of magic * Etiquitte * Religion
But those only occupy a fraction of the time. Most of the curriculum is individualized, with faculty (some in-residence, others visiting) teaching an eclectic array of courses to hand-picked students. Those with magical gifts are trained in their talents; those with martial gifts are trained in combat. There are rumors that those with more...larcenous...gifts have training in such things in a hidden part of the campus. Those without particular talents can take classes in the arts, discourse, politics (in which they may intern with members of the Houses), etc.
A full course of study, terminating upon graduation or expulsion, lasts generally about 4 years, although many students follow shorter courses and some linger for nearly a decade. Graduation comes when the student and advisors decide it's time.
== Campus == The campus is a 300 acre collection of buildings, open areas, experimental areas, and even farms located about 1 mile outside the walls of [[Varanasi]] along the Sheo river. Considered a "hard target" for those intent on harm, it is patrolled both by guards loyal to the Headmaster and...stranger things.... [[Category:Ikela]] [[Category:Places]]

So-called "sea elves". Extremely rarely seen by the surface folks of [[Noefra]], they are most common in the outer islands of the southern [[Primal Sea]] and south-western [[Oelfra]]. Small colonies exist elsewhere as part of the sea-borne alliances.
== Physical Appearance == Notable for pale blue-green skin, sea-weed green hair, and short stature. Weilgoroesi rarely stand more than 5'2". Their feet and hands are slightly webbed and clawed (more like long nails) and 2" or so fins ride the forearms and lower legs. [[Category:Races]] [[Category:Unfinished]]

A [[Dwarves|dwarven]] clan-group living in the mountains to the east of [[Merais]]. While not xenophobic, they do not interact much with outsiders except selected trading companies from [[Fatehpur]].
== Physiology == Dwarves of Sunud are physically distinct from most other [[Soefra|Soefran]] [[dwarves]] (although some of the groups living in the central escarpment are similar in skin color). Slightly more slender than most dwarves, their skins are various shades of grey, with most being ashen. Their eyes are dramatically varied, ranging from black orbs without iris, distinct pupil, or white, to all gleaming white except for a bright, glowing gold ring (again without distinct pupil). Their eyes (especially those of the Keepers) are sensitive to light; a Sunud dwarf on the surface is almost always seen with their eyes shaded by clever lenses (if not a full mask). But the biggest single difference is the hair--Sunud dwarves are hairless except for a single patch near the crowns of their head (on the females, males are entirely bald). This patch is generally grown very long and pulled up into a tail. In color, it is almost always very dark (shades of brown into black).
== Society == Clan Sunud, over the last 5 generations or so, has split into two factions. The central mountains are home to the Keepers of Silence, the ultra-traditional group that holds to their founding myth (see below). They believe that to show one's face (especially the eyes) is to uncover the soul; to see another's face is to bear the burden of their soul. Thus, their faces (and whole bodies) are kept covered except among closest kin. They wear elaborate masks that (to a fellow clan member) reveal who they are; the masks are constantly being modified to show the "truth". In the security of the clan hold, buried deep under the mountain, they wear half-masks that cover the upper part of the face. All their masks have crystal lenses that allow vision out, but not in, appearing as faceted gemstones from the outside. The Keepers communicate as much as possible via hand signals in an elaborate sign language; only one member of each group (the lowest-ranking one) is permitted to speak to outsiders. The Speaker to the Faceless's robes are dyed red; all the other robes are grey. Their only ornamentation is on their masks. The Keepers are devoutly religious, devoted to [[Korokonolkom]] in his aspect of Lord of Silence and Lord of Runes. Their only contact with the outside is that they permit a few caravans, run by particular individuals (said to be in payment of a debt) to transit through their highest tunnels (avoiding their clan hold) over into the eastern coastal lands and back. Accompanied by a Speaker and a group of silent, robed Keepers, these caravans are the only safe way to leave the [[Great Rift]] to the east.
The breakaway groups, scattered over the northern and southern flanks of the range, have various names for their groups. Rune-children, the Spoken, Hearers of the Word of Mountains, etc. But they're all united in one thing--they reject the isolationist and silent tendencies of the Keepers. They live in small settlements dug into (or built on) the surface of the mountains, rather than deep inside. Often, they go without masks; instead they tattoo their heads in patterns reminiscent of beasts, insects, or other fearsome creatures. They still cover their eyes, but wear primitive-looking garb. Some reject the use of plants (except in beer...), subsisting on meat and wearing clothes of metal and animal hides and fur exclusively. These groups are dominantly hunter-gatherers, although they do work metal and stone. Their other unifying feature is their obsession with the traces of rune-work left by the ancient [[titans]] which litters the caves in that region. There is a widespread belief that if they can learn to master those runes, the "glory days" will return.
== History...or Myth == It is said among the Keepers of Silence that during the early 3rd age, their ancestors were threatened by some force and they pled with [[Korokonolkom]], then Lord of Elemental Earth, for assistance. He answered, giving them power and etching runic words into their souls (which are visible in the eyes, hence the taboo about showing your face) and changing their appearance as a sign of the covenant; in return, the clan fathers promised to become a separate people and protect the runic remnants from the despoiling hands of outsiders.
The current belief among the scholars of [[Fatehpur]] is that the change is much more recent, being only a few hundred years before the [[Cataclysm]] and mostly due to exposure to sources of eldritch energies radiating from rocks under the mountains. [[Category:Dwarves]] [[Category:Soefra]]

Merais is the name of both a nation and a [[Merais (City)|city]]. This article describes the nation.
== Location == To the east of [[Ikela]], bordered on the east itself by the mountains inhabited by [[Clan Sunud]] and on the south by the [[Ikelan Colony Lands]].
== Cities ==
* [[Merais (City)|Merais City]] is the capital, located in the shallow waters of the bay. A mix of [[kalasaa]], [[ika-ika]], and [[mkhulu]]. * [[Fatehpur]] is the other major city, located near the shore in the central region of the nation. It is known for its friendliness toward arcane magic, something distrusted in [[Ikela]]. Practitioners from [[Ikela]] often move to [[Fatehpur]] due to persecution.
== Government == Merais is ruled by a coalition of [[mkhulu]] adepts, although they do not practice the abhorrent behaviors of many of their cousins. Overall, Merais is a magic-centered technocracy. The Coalition of Adepts confers with the heads of various magical organizations as well as merchant leaders.
== Politics == Merais is neutral ground. It does not interfere or wish to expand, but will resist interference with overwhelming force. [[Category:Merais]]

A human paladin of the Order of the Watching Eye, part of [[Nameless Soefra Party]]. Joined the coastal defense militia/guard once out of school at 18. Spent a few years doing the usual on ships, islands, occasional skirmishes with smugglers and monsters. Became a scout/spy due to a certain natural talent for it. Came up river and met old friends from school based on a recommendation to my superiors by my mentor, [[Nestorius|Nestorious]] ... Married Jenna (who he helped rescue from an alternate timeline) and became Lord of Morton's Thumb and booze dealer. == Personality == I would rather make a new friend than a new enemy. I now always have a plan for what to do when things go wrong. '''Ideals:''' People. I’m loyal to my friends, not to any ideals, and everyone else can take a trip down the Styx for all I care. '''Bonds''': Someone I loved died because of a mistake I made - I trusted a fool. That will never happen again. '''Flaw:''' I sat silent while someone was tried and imprisoned for something I know he did not do. My silence was my form of payback for the decision they made that got a friend of ours killed, and me badly injured, during a scouting mission...even though I also made a judgment error, I blamed him. == Koans == Vijil is known for his cryptic pronouncements relating to their adventures. * How far into a song will you go to bring back a concept? * If an evil one betrays evil allies, is that a good or a double evil? * When you give someone named Mordred their parole, how long will it be before they turn foul again? * When the verdict is known before the court convenes, must the kangaroo leap to conclusions, or simply laugh? * ''If you can become immortal, should you?'' * ''If it has a face that only a mother of monsters could love, can you kill it?'' * When opposing chaotic corruption with an army of monsters, how does one tell the difference? * ''When tempus machina rush in where angels fear to tread, are they fools or heroes?'' (Editor: Yes). * ''By destroying despair, what happens to hope, the other side of the eternal coin?'' *"If you fight with yourself and win, is that victory or defeat?" *Does doing the dirty deed define a deal with a devil? *If you kill the evil shadow of a loved one, should you tell them how it made you feel? *If a fiend offers to help deal against the ultimate being of destructive chaos, should you accept his offer? *The druids' wildwood weed: must one fly to get high, or must one get high to fly? *Is it more important to know where you are or when you are? *"If the only thing we have to fear is fear itself, and dragons, when is the right time to be afraid?" *If fiends' mortal agents are allowed to act, how can fiends be foiled? *How much reflection is needed for a Watcher to watch the Watchers? *When the wytch storm comes, where's your refuge when magic is your essence? *If you give a dragon an egg, when should you give her bacon? *When a birth evokes prophecy, how do you discern its true meaning? *If celestials, fiends and deities toy with mortals, should mortals speak out or submit to manipulation? *If you hate what you have become, are you noble? == Haiku == He's also known for his haikus based on his adventures.

revision.comment: /* Stormqueen's Wake */
revision.text:
[[Ikela]] is not particularly religious of a country. That said, there are several notable organized religious groups in the area.
== Congregation, United == The largest and most "socially approved" (especially among the First and Second Families) organization is the Church of the Congregation, United. Headed by Patriarch Samael [[Ikel]] (brother to King Mazayar [[Ikel]]), it serves all 16 of the [[Congregation]] equally, not favoring any particular one. Each major city has a branch, headed by an Exarch (usually a member of the ruling First Family or a close relative). Smaller towns and villages may have churches headed by a priest or priestess, but they're most concentrated in the larger settlements. The CCU preaches tolerance, respect, and the divinely-granted right to rule of the current noble families. Some accuse the church of being mostly a venue for bribes and a cover for the nobles to do whatever they want.
Founded soon after the [[Ikela History|restoration of Ikela]] in 100 AC.
== Stormqueen's Wake == The other major group is called Stormqueen's Wake. Much newer, but growing fast, it was established in 218 AC. While it worships the [[Congregation]], it is most devoted to [[Tatsuryuu]], calling her the "Stormqueen". Its doctrine is one of liberation from "sin", resistance to oppression, and fairness to your fellows. Opponents call it "radical" and "insurrectionist", claiming that the "spiritual liberation" espoused by the overt side is a front for a more radical leveling of society and destruction of the current order desired by covert factions within the organization.
Unlike the CUU, SW has no official leadership. Each Servant (the title for those called to the ministry) acts independently, although they meet periodically for alignment.
SW is quite popular with the urban poor, with some reach beyond the urban areas. Its support is most concentrated near the coast; Calabar has the least support.
== Listeners == The Listeners are a group of primal practitioners who advocate for and work to appease the [[kami]] and other spiritual entities. They are strongest in [[Surat]] and among the rural poor, but have groups in most areas. They oppose industrialization, colonization, and generally expansion of mortals' incursions on the natural world.
== Other Groups ==
* [[Demon]] cults are extremely rare and are crushed as soon as they are discovered. * Rumors of cults devoted to several of the [[Diabolical Families]]. This worship, unlike demon worship, is tolerated officially, but not welcomed in the public sphere. * Several cults devoted to dragons (including, for some perverse reason, [[Kozhun|the Dragon Tyrant]] himself) exist, mostly in the north and in the very rural areas near [[Jaora]].
[[Category:Religion]] [[Category:Ikela]]

revision.text:
Reclusive, yet notorious master bard and headmaster of the [[Sea-Song Academy]] in [[Varanasi]], [[Ikela]]. No one's quite sure where he came from or how he got to where he is, but it's well known that he has sources of information that most lack. He often travels around in disguise, looking for promising individuals to become pupils at his academy. He retains his place despite not being directly tied to any of the Families for reasons that are hinted to mostly involve massive quantities of blackmail.
== Allies == He's known to be allied with and highly respected by
* The Order of the Watchers * The Weirdling Assembly of [[Merais]] * The [[Moonshell Dragon Flight|Moonshell Flight]] * and even [[Clan Sunud]] * King [[Ikel]] XIV.
== Enemies == Most of the First Families, especially the [[Mirza]] family. [[Category:Ikela]] [[Category:Notable People]]

City of the Sages, the second largest city in the nation of [[Merais]]. Known to house the largest collection of arcanists, magical technologists, researchers, and outright cranks in the [[Great Rift]]. "Ruled" by the [[Weirdling Assembly]], a collection of such individuals; this rule has a very light touch. Not a safe city by any means, but a city of opportunity. [[File:Fatehpur.png|thumb]]
== Demographics ==
* Roughly 13,000 individuals. * Mostly humans, but with a leavening of [[kalasaa]], a significant number of rebel [[sena'ka]], and some of the only [[gwerin]] known to live north of [[Two Moons]] and the [[Phoenix Empire]].
== Economics == Knowledge is power. ''Arcane'' knowledge is ''real'' power. Those without either are servants, seekers, or experimental victims...cough...subjects.
== Departments == The primary "political" divisions among the Fatehans (the demonym for residents and citizens of Fatehpur) are the Departments. Named semi-jocularly after branches of a university, they represent approaches to power and specialties. Being a member of a Department (which about 60% of the citizenry are) grants both resources and protection, but the cost is that your vote is [[Weirdling Assembly|delegated]] to the head of the Department and you can't revoke it without serious drama (and usually switching Departments). This is considered a small loss for the notoriously administration-averse mages. In decreasing order of size and power, the Departments are
# Information Sciences (specializing in divination, illusion, as well as being the home of chronomantic magic), headed by Hieronimous sur Golai (goes by Hiero), a [[gwerin]] archmage of uncertain origin (or at least he's not talking about where he came from about 10 years ago) # Life Sciences (specializing in biological magic and transformations), headed by Brinmar sur Pelam, another [[gwerin]] archmage and ex-wife(ish, it's complicated) of Hiero. The two are neck and neck and frequently feuding. # Physical Sciences (specializing in elemental magic), headed by Raila (no last name), a human woman born to a noble family in [[Ikela]]. She's only a Master mage, but easily the most personally popular of the top 4. # Psychology (specializing in mind magic, psionics, mind control, etc), headed by Mind-Seeker (not his real name, but what he goes by), a [[mkhulu]] archmage and psion. By some accounts he's the most personally powerful individual in the city, but rarely leaves his domed complex on the north side of the city. Psychology is home to most of the [[mkhulu]], [[sena'ka]], and [[kalasaa]] citizens. Mind-Seeker's right-tentacle-mage, Master Kfthis, is the one who represents those votes on the Assembly. # Divinity (specializing in the study of both the gods, ascendants, and other residents of the Astral), headed by Master Apsalan, a human mage. Divinity is also home to most of the non-arcanely-powered citizens, who chafe at being second-class citizens (literally). # Alchemistry (specializing in, well, alchemy), headed by Master Pthai, a rare [[zandolit]] mage. # Labor Relations (specializing in the study of summoning, binding, and necromancy, as well as dabbling in mind-control a little bit), headed by Boss Hogg, a master mage and [[sena'ka]] exile from the Fleet. Very not popular. Own many of the "Property"-class people in the city. # General Studies (specializing in, well, not specializing), headed by Adept Solon, a human woman. GS claims to speak "for the common citizen" and seeks to better their life. Newly started.
== Wytch Storms == One phenomenon in Fatehpur and the eastern [[Ikelan Colony Lands]] is the Wytch Storm. This is a combination of a regular wind/rain/lightning storm and a magical disturbance. They emanate at random from an area of jungle roughly 100 miles south of the city proper, in the [[Stormveil Jungle]], a particularly dangerous and dense jungled area. This magical disturbance disrupts sensitive magical experiments (at weakest) and may disrupt all active magic, causing spells to fail or backfire. The city is warded against the worst of the effects by the efforts of the Stormwards, a group of mages belonging to Physical Sciences. Travelers to Fatehpur should be aware of the warning flag system, however. The towers of Physical Science may fly colored flags warning of incoming storms (as predicted by Information Sciences). These flags are (in order of increasing severity):
* No flag: normal conditions * Green flags: Minor storm. Those participating in sensitive ongoing experiments should take precautions to prevent contaminated results. Active spellcasting outside of the ward zone may induce unintended harmless (mostly) sensory effects. * Yellow flags: Storm Warning. Sensitive experiments should be paused and protected. Unnecessary spellcasting outside of the ward zone should cease and necessary casting should be done only by those trained in storm-time casting. Unpredictable results may occur ranging from minor sensory effects to completely different results than normal. * Red flags. Seek Shelter. All citizens and Property are advised to seek shelter in a designated Wytch Storm Shelter. Stormwards are on full alert. Once the storm strikes, no access through the ward line is allowed. No spellcasting should be performed outside the most strongly-warded areas, and even then precautions must be taken. Those exposed to the storm may experience substantial unwanted effects, including death. * Black flags. No Casting Allowed. Under no conditions should you cast a spell. The effects are...unpredictable but always bad. CF the large crater down the SW road--that was someone casting a cantrip during the last Black Flag storm.
In the last year, only 3 storms have reached Yellow Flag status; in the last two decades, there has only been one Red Flag storm. Green Flag storms are fairly common (monthly or more).
The storms get more frequent, more powerful as you travel south toward the Stormveil. There are reports of null storms, where any organized magic simply stops working until the storm passes. Travelers through the Eastern Gap are encouraged to stick close to the Sunud range and move through the gap as quickly as possible. If caught outside during a storm, take shelter underground if possible and watch out for weirdling beasts seeking prey. [[Category:Cities]] [[Category:Merais]]
