Very little quiet contemplation, unless its of your next victim. Those trained here are often involved deeply in the politics of the former [[Stone Throne]], but usually behind the scenes.
"Monastery" only in the sense of "set apart place from the world". It is religiously devoted to the [[Queen Ascendant]], but very little contemplation or singing praises. [[Category:Places]] [[Category:Jungle of Fangs]] [[Category:Asai'ka]]

revision.comment: Created page with "The vast, nearly unbroken stretch of turbulent ocean separating the eastern edge of [[Noefra]] from the western isles of [[Oelfra]]. Known to be a hotbed of [[comiedai]] and c..."
revision.text:
The vast, nearly unbroken stretch of turbulent ocean separating the eastern edge of [[Noefra]] from the western isles of [[Oelfra]]. Known to be a hotbed of [[comiedai]] and corrupted [[kalasaa]] activity.
No regular trade crosses the Eastward Ocean, unlike the [[Primal Sea]]. A few of the [[Kor Abantu]] ships made the long journey during the late 3rd age and have set up colonies in the islands west of [[Oelfra]], but they are isolated from their homeland and have forgotten they were ever colonists except in legends. [[Category:Geography]]

revision.comment: Created page with "The nation-like alliance of undersea dwellers ([[kalasaa]], [[ika-ika]], [[Mkhulu|kkhulu]], and [[comiedai]], among others) who control the [[Sea of Dreams]] as well as the oc..."
revision.text:
The nation-like alliance of undersea dwellers ([[kalasaa]], [[ika-ika]], [[Mkhulu|kkhulu]], and [[comiedai]], among others) who control the [[Sea of Dreams]] as well as the ocean north of [[Noefra]]. Highly decentralized, but united in that they are fervently devoted to [[Leviathan]] and the [[Allsong]].
== Interactions with Land-dwellers == Before the events of [[Axe and Song]], they had little to no interactions with land-dwellers. In large part because there was only very limited sea traffic in their domain, and that only in the coastal shallows of the southern Sea of Dreams.
Since [[Axe and Song]], they have started interacting with the land-dwellers more substantially and maintain an "embassy" of sorts on an island just north of [[Honedaxe]]. [[Category:Nations]] [[Category:Noefra]]

You've heard of oral history? Well, this takes the proverbial cake. --The [[Immortal Bard]], recorded in "Drunken Sayings of Drunken Men".
The Allsong is the name scholars give to the endless discourse [[Leviathan]] has with itself across its myriad bodies in the depths of the oceans of [[Quartus]]. It is rumored to be, in essence, the truth of [[Leviathan|Leviathan's]] thoughts and memories, the sum-total of its knowledge, in the form of deeply-layered music. Even the lesser noises of storms, earthquakes, and the languages of mortal sea-dwellers, plus their birth cries and death groans form tiny elements of this all-encompassing symphony. And in that music is power--the power to change lesser life and to shape it to its needs, to kill and to give life. Some bards have traced the origins of their musical magic to the Allsong. Druids have tried to take shapes more suited to listen--they quickly learn to tune it out because attempting to comprehend even the slightest piece has driven many of them completely mad; they lose themselves and become nothing more than elements of [[Leviathan]]. The [[Twisted]] and his minions have a perpetual goal of corrupting the Allsong, believing that by doing so they would change the things being sung about...possibly retroactively. But this is just mad speculation of a demented mind... [[Category:Magic]] [[Category:Quartus]]

revision.comment: Created page with "Also called "astral gold" or "heaven's gold", this golden metal is actually harder than dwarven steel and significantly more aetherically-dense. It is very well suited for mag..."
revision.text: Also called "astral gold" or "heaven's gold", this golden metal is actually harder than dwarven steel and significantly more aetherically-dense. It is very well suited for magic items, as it can channel and resist aetheric forces as well as gold while being much more durable. Unfortunately, the secret to making it has either been lost on the Mortal plane or never was known--all known examples are heavily influenced by the [[Astral]] plane or were forged there. [[Category:Magic Items]]

revision.comment: Created page with "An offshoot of the [[Mother Tree]], formed when a [[Hags|hag]] satiates his or herself completely with their obsession and is ready to pass on. Instead, the seed that replaced..."
revision.text:
An offshoot of the [[Mother Tree]], formed when a [[Hags|hag]] satiates his or herself completely with their obsession and is ready to pass on. Instead, the seed that replaced their heart sprouts and roots itself in the ground, trapping the hag's soul in a perpetual mockery of themselves, a living hell that seeks to grow itself a new [[Hagfen]], while the soul remains conscious and (some say) knows the bitterness and futility of its obsession.
While powerful, Daughter Trees are much more vulnerable than their mother.
== Notable Examples == The one notable Daughter Tree so far was encountered and destroyed by [[Ad Elementis]] in the abandoned dwarven city of [[Grimhold]] during the winter of 251 AC. [[Category:Monsters]]

revision.comment: Created page with "A dwarven clan hold buried deep in the westernmost tip of the [[Outer Barrier Range]] south-west (and vertically below) [[Fuar Uulan]], abandoned centuries ago when it fell to..."
revision.text:
A dwarven clan hold buried deep in the westernmost tip of the [[Outer Barrier Range]] south-west (and vertically below) [[Fuar Uulan]], abandoned centuries ago when it fell to a "curse". Experts in runic technology and smelting. Greed and betrayal led to the birth of a [[Hags|hag]] bent on revenge, who drove the residents mad and caused them to kill each other and giving birth to a [[Daughter Tree]]. From there it fell into urban legend and myth, a scary story told to children.
The [[Daughter Tree]] and associated forces were destroyed by [[Ad Elementis]] in winter 251 AC. The [[Uulan Confederacy]] is now undertaking an expedition to see what can be learned from the ruins. [[Category:Cities]] [[Category:Ad Elementis]]

revision.comment: Created page with "The only true airship known to exist as of 250 AC. Built by the [[Airship Pioneers]] in 212 AC, it has been carefully maintained ever since. Due to its miraculous helm (built..."
revision.text:
The only true airship known to exist as of 250 AC. Built by the [[Airship Pioneers]] in 212 AC, it has been carefully maintained ever since. Due to its miraculous helm (built by [[Wayland Smith]] and housing a fey spirit obtained from Queen Morrigan of the Winter Court, it acts as a living being rather than a simple vessel. Piloted by [[Sorath vo'Gal]], it wanders the world and even beyond.
== Description == Built on the hull of a [[Byssia|Byssian]] deep-water ship, modified with ball turrets for [[Wyrmhold|Wyrmhold-designed]] thunder cannons (firing ball lightning) and given flight by wind-elemental essence worked into the keel-plate, the Flying Free is 65 feet long and has a cargo capacity of around 50 tons, although it rarely carries bulk cargo.
It has no masts, and the above-deck superstructure is replaced by a single oval bridge where the living helm is installed.
== Capabilities == The ship has defenses: 4 lightning cannons (2 on each side) in ball turrets, as well as a force arc projector at the prow (capable of sending a lance of hardened air forward a half-mile). It can move in 3 dimensions and hover, traveling as fast as 50 mph for short bursts. At high altitudes, it projects an atmospheric bubble around itself, allowing the crew to breath freely.
Thankfully, the ship only responds to Sorath's direction and refuses to be used for aggressive war. Its only recorded battle was against the dragon [[Xol'cerd]] over the [[Nocthian Caldera]] in 212 AC. It participated in the [[Adventurer’s Guild]] efforts to stop the [[Crystal Spire War]], but that involved no shots fired. [[Category:Magic Items]]

revision.comment: /* Geography */
revision.text:
The elemental plane is really one connected space, but is divided by convention into either 4 or 12 smaller pieces, what are usually thought of as the elemental planes (plural). Here, raw, un-aspected aether is given form and purpose, to be conveyed back to the [[Mortal]] plane to continue the cycles of life. The elemental plane is co-incident with the Mortal in all places, but portals connect areas throughout its volume so most portions of the elemental plane are accessible regardless of where [[Quartus]] is in its orbit. The influence of particular elemental aspects wanes and waxes throughout the year based on orbital position, giving rise to the seasons in the Mortal plane. Conversely, the nearness or farness of the various planets (but mostly Quartus) give rise to the "seasons" of the elements--Conjunction occurs in a particular place when Quartus is "near", and Opposition happens when Quartus is on the other side of Eua. Thus, Conjunction in the [[Plane of Flame]] is Opposition in the [[Plane of Ocean]] and vice versa.
== Geography == Placeholder
=== Radial Variation === The elemental plane experiences substantial variation from the center of Eua outward to the [[Crystal Sphere]], where it ends. While technically it is a smooth gradient (with several different rates of change), most scholars lump it into several major areas, with some mingling in the transition regions.
====Zone of Radiance==== The volume within the orbit of [[Primus]] is composed almost entirely of undifferentiated diffuse luminous aether. Here, the aether emanating from Eua is so intense that elemental variance is muted. The only inhabitants here are the bizarre (by mortal standards) luminous elementals who can rarely be summoned and who cannot survive the much darkened aetheric environment of the outer system. Mortal flesh cannot survive this region without extensive protection--it simply vanishes, dissolved into its base diffuse form.
====Zone of Pure Elements==== From approximately the orbit of [[Primus]] until just beyond the orbit of [[Secundus]] and [[Tertius]] is the zone of pure elements--the four classical elements hold sway as if the [[Planar realignment|Planar Realignment]] had never happened. The only mixing occurs at the borders between the elements and in the wake of the orbiting planets, who drag aether along with them and create a tunnel of elemental chaos in their wake, where any of the elements can be found (although the composition varies throughout the year). The influence of [[Primus]] is limited, only occupying roughly three times its (small) planetary radius (the diameter of the planet plus half a radius on either side). The influence of the twin planets is much larger, occupying roughly 7 times their individual planetary radius (one planetary diameter for each planet, the one-radius separation distance, and one planetary radius on either side) along the primary orbital plane, narrowing slightly (to 5 radii) on the transverse axis. These mixing zones extend into the neighboring zones as well (the Zone of Radiance for Primus and the Life-bearing Zone for Secundus and Tertius).
Here dwell almost entirely pure elementals, although some of the [[Named]] genii watch over the mixing zones. Mortals need some preparations to survive here--to survive the Plane of Air, one must be able to fly, as there is little land, and to survive the Plane of Water one must have a way of breathing water, as there is no air or surface. But survival is possible without exotic preparations, unlike the Zone of Radiance.
====Life-bearing Zone==== The volume from the orbit of the Twin Planets out to slightly beyond the orbit of [[Quartus]] is known as the Life-bearing Zone, for here mortals (more especially the [[Plane-touched]] and [[Plane-bound]] can live fairly normally. The four Pure Elements blend into the 12 "normal" elemental planes. Here, the radiance of Eua is tempered enough that complex, mixed elemental aether can exist normally. Here, in this zone are the civilizations and "hearts" of the planes. Here dwell the [[Elemental lord|Elemental Lords]] and many strange creatures, elemental and mortal. Unlike in the Pure Elemental zone, the influence of Quartus is not nearly as dramatic, although it does create the seasons. Conjunction brings out-of-the-norm weather--rain in the normally arid fire-dominated planes for example, but also creativity and bursts of new life. Opposition is a slower, quieter time.
The influence of Quartus is large, stretching approximately 60 of its planetary radii on either side of the planet's surface and encompasses the two moons. This is also the rough volume of [[Shadow]].
====Umbral Zone==== Beyond the Life-bearing Zone, starting at roughly 1.25x the orbital radius of Quartus, is the Umbral Zone, where the differences in elemental aether fade into darkness and stillness, stirred only by small currents and the battles of the [[Angels|Angelic Hosts]]. At the surface of the [[Crystal Sphere]], all goes dark and still. Here, mortal life requires a steady supply of energy as one radiates away all their aether trying to warm the endless dark. Life of any kind, elemental or mortal, is rare and predatory.
===Azimuthal Variation=== Azimuth is the angle between the orbital plane of the planets and the point in question. As one departs from the orbital plane in either direction along the rotational axis of the planetary system, one finds that the diversity and density of aether fades at first slowly, and then much faster. Most of the aetheric density of the elemental plane is concentrated in a 30-degree-wide cone centered on the orbital plane, falling off faster-than-linearly as one departs from that cone. The same zones apply, but the aether becomes sparser as one goes out--the [[Plane of Stone]]'s endless mountains fade to sandy dunes and eventually to flat wastes of grey ash.
===Circumferential variation=== The "zero-angle"/"x-axis" is defined as the border between the Earth-dominated planes and those dominated by Water, and increases through Earth into Fire, then into Air and finally ending in Water. This variation is what most consider the "important" variation--it defines the different elemental "planes", as well as the seasons of [[Quartus]]. This section will only discuss the variation one would experience if one walked along the orbit of Quartus in the direction of positive angle. '''N.B.''' It should be remembered that the orbital circumference of Quartus is ''huge''--if one walked 30 miles every day, it would take over 50,000 years (more than twice the current lifetime of the planes themselves) to make a complete circuit. Each "plane" is 487.5 ''million'' miles wide along that line.

A rambling complex of private rooms, eateries, drug dens, and treatment rooms. Dedicated to dreams--both becoming lost in them and becoming free of them. This is the center-place of the plane, [[Lamies the Silent|Lamies the Silent's]] court, although that enigmatic figure does not hold court in a normal sense. Mortals and non-mortals alike come here to escape the pain of their lives, either by seeking oblivion (temporary or lasting) in drugs or magicked dreams or by seeking psychic surgery to remove unwanted thoughts, dreams, and personality traits and substitute new ones. It's rumored that one can have their personally completely altered...for a price. The prices are only denominated in coin for the least-consequential services; other ones require payment in the coin of favors and acts. They do not share customer information, but certainly keep it.
Staffed by Lamies's enigmatic, androgenous-looking "elven" relatives, all of whom have at least telepathic powers and prefer silent speech to audible vocalizations. Some have whispered that underneath the facade of neutral "elven-kind" lurks a much more disturbing reality--that they are winged, hunched, oddly-proportioned (almost ''stretched),'' extremely pointed-eared creatures with snake-like slitted eyes and needle-like pointed teeth. But not too loud, of course. [[Category:Places]] [[Category:Plane of Cloud]]

revision.comment: Created page with "At the center of [[Nara Kara]], the largest city of the [[Plane of Lava]], stands the Great Court, an arena devoted to trial by combat. It is the ultimate resort for those bel..."
revision.text:
At the center of [[Nara Kara]], the largest city of the [[Plane of Lava]], stands the Great Court, an arena devoted to trial by combat. It is the ultimate resort for those believing themselves wronged--anyone anywhere, across the planes, can appeal to the Court for redress. Criminal, civil, or personal, it matters not. However, such appeals are not easy or routine--far from it. For here in the realm of [[Alastor, World Judge]], right is proved by strength of arm or magic. The appellant must stake his or her life on their claim, even if a proxy is hired to do the actual fighting. Both sides meet for combat by whatever means they can muster; the side that walks away is declared victor and in the right. The only rules in the arena are that (1) no outside interference, not even that of the gods, is allowed and (2) no [[Awakener]] or [[Jotnar]] influence is allowed (due to the collateral consequences). A side effect of rule #1 is that all combatants are restored to their "peak" condition before the fight begins--exhaustion, ill-nourishment, etc are considered "outside influences".
It's said that the Powers that ward the arena are incorruptible and cannot be cheated. This does not mean that trials here are ''fair'' by standards elsewhere. For example, an artisan, if tricked into challenging the judgements of the [[Cult of Burning Law]], may be forced to fight with unpracticed hands and minimal equipment against an enforcer, which might be a fire giant gladiator or other overwhelming foe. Might is the ''only'' right. [[Category:Places]] [[Category:Plane of Lava]]

revision.comment: Created page with "[[File:Nara-kara.webp|alt=Nara Kara Map|border|frameless|1600x1600px]] == Overview == The city of [[Nara Kara]] is the only substantial settlement in the hostile Plane of L..."
revision.text:
[[File:Nara-kara.webp|alt=Nara Kara Map|border|frameless|1600x1600px]]
== Overview == The city of [[Nara Kara]] is the only substantial settlement in the hostile [[Plane of Lava]]. At about 600k inhabitants, it is a large city by Mortal standards but small compared to many of the other planar cities. About 2/3 of those are [[Plane-bound]] or [[Named]] elementals; the remainder are [[Plane-touched]]. It is the center of the [[Cult of Burning Law]] as well as the seat of power of [[Alastor, World Judge]]. It also contains the [[Grand Court]], where anyone can challenge any judgement...with their lives at stake.
== Sectors == Sectors are numbered seemingly haphazardly, but some patterns apply.
=== Core Sectors === Sectors 0, 6, and 7 (those inside the inner wall) are the Core. Here dwell the powerful, as well as the Cog Priests of the [[Cult of Burning Law|Cult]]. Here is the [[Grand Court]], the [[Cogwheel Palace]], and the Central Administrative offices. Non-citizens must register here if they plan to spend more than 4 days ''in a lifetime'' inside the city walls.
=== Trade Sectors === Sectors 1, 3, and 4 are trade sectors. Here dwell and work the merchants, artisans, and other low-ranking citizens. Sector 4 is the only one where non-citizens are allowed to reside, and only temporarily.
=== Sectors 2 and 5 === Of all the out-wall sectors, sectors 2 and 5 are the least-bad. Built around one of the few nearly-potable natural water sources in the plane, sector 2 is devoted to agriculture and the farmers here have significant autonomy as long as they produce food. Sector 5 is the "resort" sector where the powerful have their estates. Some of these estates are nightmares for the slaves, however.
=== Slum Sectors === Sectors 8-11, south of the city and mostly buried in lava tubes and caves, are the slums. Growing progressively worse from the run-down but safe Sector 8 through the thug-ruled, remote hellhole of sector 11, this is where those who flee from the light of the Law or who have fallen so far as to be below nothing live. Scratching out a precarious existence as servants and slaves, many here wish they were dead...but still struggle for survival. [[Category:Cities]] [[Category:Plane of Lava]]

revision.comment: Created page with "A fragment of the [[Nameless]], broken off as a "backup plan" in case the [[Dawn War]] failed (which it did). Contained much of the [[Awakener]] thought-form that prompted the..."
revision.text:
A fragment of the [[Nameless]], broken off as a "backup plan" in case the [[Dawn War]] failed (which it did). Contained much of the [[Awakener]] thought-form that prompted the war in the first place. Originally summoned back into reality by [[Aelvar]] mages of the mid-Second Age in a (mistaken) attempt to draw power from it, it was imprisoned between the timelines by a concerted (and fatal) sacrifice of aelves, celestials, devils, dragons, and giants. There it sat for millennia, although its influence leaked into reality and twisted many timelines. The seal was broken by an [[Archmagistrate of Kel'tan]] in about 246 AC, causing the [[Reweaving]]. Finally terminally defeated and destroyed by an alliance led by [[Tempus Machina]] in late 251 AC.
Of note, the shell of the entity was the [[Broken Concept]] of Hope, now warped into Despair with the Nameless fragment and Awakener poison locked inside. When Tempus Machina smashed [[Namebreaker]] into that core, Hope was purified and returned to the realm. The Awakener influence was also freed of its bonds to that Outside entity, becoming part of the Dream itself. [[Category:Tempus Machina]] [[Category:Demons]]

revision.comment: Created page with "An ancient artifact in the form of a mace. The most-feared weapon of the [[Astral]], only deployed at greatest need, for it can reduce a [[True Word]] into its constituent ele..."
revision.text:
An ancient artifact in the form of a mace. The most-feared weapon of the [[Astral]], only deployed at greatest need, for it can reduce a [[True Word]] into its constituent elements, effectively destroying it. It is one of the few artifacts capable of ''permanently'' destroying a [[Named]] being with no hope of revival.
Held under close guard in the [[Celestial City]] and only accessible under direct authorization from both the [[Angels|Angelic Legions]] and the [[Congregation]].
== Known Uses ==
* Used by [[Tempus Machina]] on divine authority to destroy Despair, the core of the [[Adversary]].
[[Category:Artifacts]]

The capital city of [[Nocthians|Nocthia]] until the exodus of the Night’s Children in ~50AC. Located between the northern flanks of [[Mount Nyx]] in the central [[Nocthian Caldera]], it has lain in ruins after the hungering frost’s invasion. Currently inhabited by feral, devolved goblinoid creatures. [[File:Nighthold ruins.jpg|center|frame|Ruins of Nighthold ca 250 AC.]]
== Locations ==
# Entrance to the ruins under [[Mount Nyx]]. # Sunrise Tower # Sunset Tower # Red Moon Tower. # Veiled Lady # Central Command. The buried military headquarters of the [[Nocthians|Nocthian]] military. Inhabited by three groups of Awakened constructs: the humanoid Core, the shared-consciousness animal-form Pack, and the reclusive Archivists. # Dusk Tower # White Moon Palace # Dawn Tower
[[Category:Nocthian Caldera]] [[Category:Cities]]

The capital city of the [[Phoenix Empire]] (aka [[Kel'tan]]). Located at the heart of the [[Solar Highlands]], at the (unnatural) fork of two rivers and at the base of the only mountain on those highlands. The city sprawls in the shadow of the mountain, which has been honeycombed and terraced as part of the Immortal Emperor's palace. The top is shaped into a gigantic phoenix sculpture, with the throne room in the creature's head.
== Population == Kel'tana is a mix of densely-populated slums and sprawling estates. Overall, the population was nearly 100,000 as of early 251 AC. This breaks down as follows
* Pureblood [[gwerin]] nobles: Trace amounts (~200) * Pureblood gwerin commoners: 5% * Magebred gwerin: 10% * [[Chaudeekar]] and [[sena'ka]] servants/warriors: 30% (mostly the latter) * Other magebred slaves: 55%
Post the fall of the Immortal Emperor, the overall population has dropped in half, with many slaves and warriors escaping the devastated noble houses. Many of the purebloods have been killed; a few have fled.
== After 251 AC == After the death of the Immortal Emperor [[Hafgan ap Kel'tan]] in the fall of 251 AC, the palace has fallen at least partially to ruins due to the unbinding of his spells and partly due to the civil war that erupted. The city is in the possession of the "loyalist" faction of [[gwerin]] pureblooded nobles, seeking to re-establish the empire. [[Category:Cities]] [[Category:Phoenix Empire]]

revision.comment: Created page with "A martial arts school and mystical training facility located in [[Safehold]], near [[Lyodnoir]]. Founded by [[Kalesin]] of the [[Catalysts]]. Unique among the great "monasteri..."
revision.text: A martial arts school and mystical training facility located in [[Safehold]], near [[Lyodnoir]]. Founded by [[Kalesin]] of the [[Catalysts]]. Unique among the great "monasteries" of western [[Noefra]] in that it accepts all and has much less of a mystical/monastic bent. Focuses primarily on the unarmed combat styles and conditioning. Has grown to 50 instructors and nearly 500 students. Studiously non-political. [[Category:Organizations]] [[Category:Catalysts]] [[Category:Wyrmhold]]

revision.comment: Created page with "''The following are some of the spells created for use during campaigns set in Dreams of Hope. They may be available for the designated classes--each one is marked with a labe..."
revision.text:
''The following are some of the spells created for use during campaigns set in Dreams of Hope. They may be available for the designated classes--each one is marked with a label of either "unrestricted", meaning it can be chosen freely, or "restricted", in which case access requires either GM approval or may require a quest.''
== A-F ==
=== Fire Web (Restricted) === ''4th level evocation (Warmage/Sorcerer)''
'''Cast Time''''':'' 1 action
'''Components''': Verbal, Somatic
'''Range''': 60 ft.
Striking both palms down upon the ground, a web of flame crackles out around the caster and five streaks of fire rapidly snake along the ground toward up to five targets the caster can see within range. The streaks explode into a column of flame upon reaching them. Each target must make a Dexterity saving throw, taking 8d6 fire damage on a failed save or half as much on a success. Multiple streaks may target the same creature or object--the damage dealt increase by 2d6 for each streak that a creature is struck by. Only one saving throw is made. The fire can travel over obstacles up to 5 feet high and can only target creatures on or within 5 feet of the ground. It ignites flammable objects along its path that are not being worn or carried.
'''At Higher Levels'''. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 5th level or higher, you create one additional streak for each spell level above 4th. [[Category:Magic]] [[Category:Homebrew]]

revision.comment: Created page with "'''Date:''' 24 Summer Dying, 212 AC. '''Location''': [[Temple of the Moon]], south-east [[Jungle of Fangs]] (present day [[Serpent Dominion]]), overlooking the West Moon Se..."
revision.text:
'''Date:''' 24 Summer Dying, 212 AC.
'''Location''': [[Temple of the Moon]], south-east [[Jungle of Fangs]] (present day [[Serpent Dominion]]), overlooking the West [[Moon Sea]]
'''Defenders''': [[Awakener]]-corrupted husks of the first druids, aided by awakener-influenced [[ophidian]] tribes.
'''Attackers''': The [[Dimwit Syndicate]] and military units from [[Kel'al'ar]].
This was the culminating event of the liberation of the [[Temple of the Moon]] from [[Awakener]] corruption. The [[Stone Throne]] military units moved into position to the west of the temple, drawing the tribes away. This allowed the adventurers to ascend the shore-side cliffs, landing on the great moon crystal jutting from the temple's dome. There they descended into the temple and defeated the husks of the druid-priests inhabiting the temple, holding them off long enough to deploy an angel-made interference-generator on the crystal. This freed the remaining, lingering spirit of the Green Moon, allowing it to purge the remaining Awakener influence.
== Consequences == With the awakener influence in the Stone Throne mostly removed, the threat from the rogue [[Ophidian]] tribes basically ceased. The temple itself became a place of primal power, extending a calming influence over the west moon sea. [[Category:Battles]] [[Category:Stone Throne]] [[Category:Adventuring]]

revision.comment: Created page with "Also known as the "Green Moon Temple". This small shrine was built soon after the [[Moon's Fall]] during the Interregnum between the Second and Third Age by unknown groups. It..."
revision.text:
Also known as the "Green Moon Temple". This small shrine was built soon after the [[Moon's Fall]] during the Interregnum between the Second and Third Age by unknown groups. It was built around a shard of the emerald Third Moon, which landed there after being shattered during the fall of that moon.
[[File:Green-moon-temple.png|frameless]]
== History == Throughout the Third Age and into the post-[[Cataclysm]] era, the temple was staffed by a small coterie of quiet-spoken, [[ihmisi]]-appearing monks, and visited rarely. The source of the monk's subsistence and replacement monks was unknown. The monks would offer healing, advice, and other services, but never seemed to leave the grounds of the temple with its three rings of 15' hedges.
After the founders of the [[Stone Throne]] disappeared, the monks became one of the spiritual touchpoints for the local [[Ophidian]] tribes, teaching them primal magics and patterns of worship unique to that region.
=== Truth Unveiled === In 212 AC, the [[Dimwit Syndicate]] approached the temple while exploring the region. There they met the monks...and immediately began to distrust them. Later, they discovered that these monks were the nearly-immortal husks of the first group of druids who caused Moons-fall, kept alive by the [[Awakener]] that had manipulated them into causing that event in the first place. The spirit of the Emerald Moon, which still resided indomitably in the shard of crystal, had acted (unwillingly) as a mask for that malign presence.
The awakener-monks had been quietly influencing the local tribes via enchanted drugs to rise up against [[Kel'al'ar]], culminating in the [[Battle of Kel'al'ar]].
Later, the victorious forces swept in and destroyed the [[Awakener]] presence at the temple in the [[Battle of Green Moon Temple]].
== Current State == The Green Moon Temple, now cleansed of malign influence, is a historical shrine staffed by [[Ophidian]] shamans under strict supervision, both of the [[Serpent Dominion]] and of the now-revitalized spirit of the Emerald Moon. Seekers and pilgrims to the temple can experience healing, especially of mental afflictions and sorrows. [[Category:Places]] [[Category:Serpent Dominion]] [[Category:Religion]]

revision.comment: Created page with "A long low mountain range that stretches from most of the way down the western coast of the [[Great Rift]] of [[Soefra]] to the western edge of [[Ikela]], nearly cutting off t..."
revision.text:
A long low mountain range that stretches from most of the way down the western coast of the [[Great Rift]] of [[Soefra]] to the western edge of [[Ikela]], nearly cutting off the Soefran continent from the [[Primal Sea]].
The highest peak in this range, whose name is not known outside that region, stands about 4,000 ft above sea level, but most of the range is under 1000 ft. It is covered by jungle, and inhabited by a variety of tribes, most frequently [[zandolit]].
Cave systems permeate the mountains, and several major rivers seem to entirely disappear on the southern, higher side, only to reappear from caves on the shores of the sea.
Only the [[Hardshell]] and [[Ship Folk]] have significant large-scale permanent settlement on the north side of the range. [[Category:Geography]] [[Category:Soefra]]

revision.comment: Created page with "The Barrier-Tooth Islands are a chain of mixed volcanic and coral islands stretching along the northern coast of [[Soefra]]. There are 6 major islands (ranging from ~3000 sq m..."
revision.text:
The Barrier-Tooth Islands are a chain of mixed volcanic and coral islands stretching along the northern coast of [[Soefra]]. There are 6 major islands (ranging from ~3000 sq mi to 6000 sq mi) and a multitude of small ones, some only a few hundred sq ft in area. The [[Primal Sea]] in this region is shallow and treacherous, with reefs, sand bars, and unexpected currents.
The islands are the home-land of the [[Sena'ka]]-dominated [[Ship Folk]], and contain 3 of their 4 creches (vital to their reproduction, as they do not reproduce without aid). They have enslaved the other residents of these islands, making this the stronghold of those warlike people. Their Home Fleet patrols the waters, presenting a formidable barrier to anyone wishing to circumnavigate the continent or reach it from [[Noefra]]. Their influence extends across the [[Primal Sea]], although as of 251 AC, there are signs of schism between the northern and southern fleets.
== Main Islands ==
=== Vrol'ath === The largest island, as well as the most easterly, is Vrol'ath. Its name means "Dragon's Breath" in the local [[Sena'ka]] dialect. A volcanic island about 6,000 sq mi in extent, it has fertile soil and is one of the primary food production areas for the [[Ship Folk]], with many slaves being worked to death every year to farm for supplies. It's said that a great red dragon slumbers in the volcano, but no one has been brave enough to venture there in recorded memory and no evidence of the dragon has emerged except via local legend.
=== Ap'eleth === Meaning "Shelter" in the Sena'ka dialect, this was the original landing spot of the Sena'ka who fled the [[Phoenix Empire]] and established their creches. This is "home port" for the [[Ship Folk]]. The entire island is off limits to any non-Sena'ka, and even most of them do not receive permission to land. Only the highest ranking or most notable get permission to add their genetic material to the creche there.
=== Kes'al === Northernmost of the large islands, this is the jumping off port for the fleet's northern operations. It bustles with activity and boasts a huge, well-protected deepwater port as well as one of the creches.
=== Pemak === Second largest of the islands, this volcanic island is also a major farming spot and boasts one of the creches.
=== The Twins === Two large islands separated by a shallow gap, the Twins are the westernmost of the large islands. While farming there is meaningful, these have been dedicated to slave breeding. These islands supply many of the trained, loyal slaves to the Ship Folk's insatiable appetite for disposable flesh. [[Category:Geography]] [[Category:Soefra]]

revision.comment: Created page with "The oldest institution of learning and training in [[Ikela]], legendarily founded before the reign of [[Kozhun]], and re-established soon after his defeat. Very much a traditi..."
revision.text: The oldest institution of learning and training in [[Ikela]], legendarily founded before the reign of [[Kozhun]], and re-established soon after his defeat. Very much a traditionalist, hardline conservative institution. Located in [[Mirzapor]]. Attended almost entirely by scions of the First and Second families, with a few bright children of lower families who have been accepted on scholarship. [[Category:Ikela]] [[Category:Organizations]]

revision.comment: Created page with "What do you get when a [[Goblins|goblin]] tribe is heavily influenced by [[Dragons|dragon]]-tied aether for generations (or when a mad scientist such as [[Corran Scalebender]]..."
revision.text:
What do you get when a [[Goblins|goblin]] tribe is heavily influenced by [[Dragons|dragon]]-tied aether for generations (or when a mad scientist such as [[Corran Scalebender]] performs unholy soul-grafting experiments using goblin and dragon souls)? Ryuukin. Smaller than goblins, with dragonesque scales and snouts, these creatures are gregarious and inquisitive. They tend to be good with mechanisms--they're more disciplined than goblins, but tend to get obsessive about particular things. When they occur as the result of serving dragons, they tend to obsessively protect and serve that dragon, revering it as a god. When separated from draconic influence, they tend to regress into goblins over 10s of generations.
== Known Populations ==
* Two tribes live around the central of the [[Southmount|Three Sisters]] in western [[Noefra]]. * One small artificially-created band lives in [[Srassa Saat]], where they run a brewery and distillery. * Other groups live in and among the dragons of [[Dragonreach]] and in northern [[Oelfra]]
[[Category:Races]]

revision.comment: Created page with "An ancient and malign undead entity, once trapped in a [[necrite]] pyramid near [[Freeport]]. Somewhat akin to a vampire, but (by the modern era) reduced to a possessing spiri..."
revision.text:
An ancient and malign undead entity, once trapped in a [[necrite]] pyramid near [[Freeport]]. Somewhat akin to a vampire, but (by the modern era) reduced to a possessing spirit, it was imprisoned during the Second Age, and escaped sometime pre-[[Cataclysm]] when adventurers disturbed the tomb-prison. It migrated east to the [[Place of All Gods]], where it influenced local shifters to create a cult.
Destroyed by [[Ad Elementis]] in early 252 AC when it tried to take possession of them. [[Category:Historical Interest]] [[Category:Undead]] [[Category:Ad Elementis]]

revision.comment: Created page with "A form of [[Abyss|abyssal]]-influenced obsidian formed when regular stone (regular obsidian is easiest, but any stone can be transformed into necrite) is subjected to intense..."
revision.text:
A form of [[Abyss|abyssal]]-influenced obsidian formed when regular stone (regular obsidian is easiest, but any stone can be transformed into necrite) is subjected to intense abyssal presence. It acts as an aether absorber, being especially capable at trapping and imprisoning [[jotnar]] and [[fey]] entities.
Physically, it's shiny black with an oily green sheen and feel. It always feels cold, regardless of the ambient temperature. It requires substantial magic to make it usable for anything, as it shatters easily. [[Category:Magic Items]]

revision.comment: Created page with "Formerly a [[gwerin]] archmage (focused on understanding elemental aether) from the central-western part of [[Noefra]] pre-[[Cataclysm]], his family was proscribed and he beca..."
revision.text:
Formerly a [[gwerin]] archmage (focused on understanding elemental aether) from the central-western part of [[Noefra]] pre-[[Cataclysm]], his family was proscribed and he became a [[Undead|lich]]. A researcher, he has lived in [[Tal Elamor]] ever since.
Current research interests include using elemental aether to "heal" the undead. Or so he says.
Has a reputation of never lying when the truth will due...but also not being entirely honest.
Has employed and still has a relatively positive working relationship with [[Ad Elementis]]. Former colleague of [[Nidus]] and [[Dhu'gula]]. [[Category:Undead]] [[Category:Ad Elementis]]

revision.comment: Created page with "Also called the Three Sisters. Three great mountains that rise up into the clouds from [[Southmount]]. They don't have actual names individually, but from north to south, the..."
revision.text:
Also called the Three Sisters.
Three great mountains that rise up into the clouds from [[Southmount]]. They don't have actual names individually, but from north to south, they are
== Mount Imperial == So named because of an imperial fortress built into the upper part of this mountain. Not much else is known.
== Dragonmount == So named because of the Skydragon, an ancient dragon-turned-great-spirit who bonded with teh soul of the mountain. The dragon is (as of mid-spring 252 AC) deceased, but the mountain is stable. Home to several [[ryuukin]] tribes, as well as now a contingent of [[jazuu]] from [[Oelfra]].
== Stonemount == So named because of a permanent major portal to the [[Plane of Stone]] located in its base. The hub of most earth-elemental operations in western [[Noefra]]. [[Category:Geography]] [[Category:Noefra]]

revision.comment: Created page with "Very little is known about this entity. He lives in the [[Abyss]], but claims not to be a [[demon]], merely one who studies them. His works date back a long time and have sign..."
revision.text:
Very little is known about this entity. He lives in the [[Abyss]], but claims not to be a [[demon]], merely one who studies them. His works date back a long time and have significant power, including a set of obelisks that, when activated, modify the flow of time in a region 4 miles across.
Almost everything he builds involves [[necrite]], and the few records that mention him either claim that he's an "friendly obsidian dwarf" or a "colossal apocalypse clad in obsidian." [[Category:Notable People]] [[Category:Ad Elementis]]

revision.comment: Created page with "A gigantic offshoot of the [[Mother Tree]], rooted partially in the [[Abyss]] (in a lingering fragment of the [[Nameless]]'s corporeal being) but primarily manifesting on the..."
revision.text:
A gigantic offshoot of the [[Mother Tree]], rooted partially in the [[Abyss]] (in a lingering fragment of the [[Nameless]]'s corporeal being) but primarily manifesting on the [[Lost Coast]] near the gates to [[Zhivsen Khot]] and just north of the headwaters of the [[Starvalin River|Starvalin]] River. Almost entirely shrouded from sight in the [[Mortal Plane|Mortal]] plane, it was visible in [[Shadow]] as an enormous (multiple thousands of feet tall) tree seemingly made out of black threads, with threads extending out into the distance as it manipulated entities across the coastal region and into the [[Nocthian Caldera]].
Created when a coven of five hags brought their Hagseeds to fullness by manipulating the [[Khaimal]] into their current paranoid, xenophobic state as payback for stiffing them on payment for soul-manipulation technology right around the time of the [[Cataclysm]]. They took up residence in the tower of the (now forgotten) mage who triggered the [[Cataclysm War]] by summoning the [[Nameless]] from the [[Abyss]], and used his residual portal to create a safe root zone for their conjoined "eternal" essence. They also surrounded the tower with 30+-foot thick thorns stretching the entire height of the tower, preventing any entrance from the [[Mortal Plane]].
== Defeat in 252 AC == The Black Tree was destroyed by [[Ad Elementis]], who were searching for the cause of [[Yonas Akrotiz|Yonas's]] nightmares. As it turned out, the Black Tree was fundamentally responsible for this, and paid the price. After the destruction of the heart of the tree in the Abyss, the tree solidified in the Mortal plane as a tree, now petrified to black stone. [[Category:Demons]] [[Category:Ad Elementis]] [[Category:Noefra]] [[Category:Historical Interest]]

revision.text: A wide (~100+ yards), fast-flowing river located in the northern [[Lost Coast]], just south of the end of the mountain range. In [[Shadow]], it manifests as an endless supply of silver serpents, writhing down towards the sea. Fairly friendly to mortals as shadow-rivers go. [[Category:Noefra]] [[Category:Rivers]]

revision.comment: Created page with "Known as “the head in the jar”, Nikola was a dwarven mage and artificer in pre [[Cataclysm]] [[Godsfall]]. his specialty was the [[Portal Network]], with a side line in ma..."
revision.text:
Known as “the head in the jar”, Nikola was a dwarven mage and artificer in pre [[Cataclysm]] [[Godsfall]]. his specialty was the [[Portal Network]], with a side line in magitech augmentation. When the city fell to demons, he preserved himself by putting his head in a fluid filled jar attached to manipulating appendages. he then, once it was clear it would be a while, put himself into a dream state. He was rediscovered and revived by the [[Godsfall Champions]] and became the primary expert for the [[Federated Nations]] on the portals, mapping out their termini.
He passed away in 238 AC of natural causes. [[Category:Dwarves]] [[Category:Historical Interest]] [[Category:Godsfall]] [[Category:Godsfall Champions]]

revision.comment: Created page with "Silver [[Dragons|Dragon]] and mate to [[Kozhun]]. Known (post rediscovery of [[Greenwood Reach]] by [[Tempus Machina]]) to be a strong moderating influence on the future Tyran..."
revision.text: Silver [[Dragons|Dragon]] and mate to [[Kozhun]]. Known (post rediscovery of [[Greenwood Reach]] by [[Tempus Machina]]) to be a strong moderating influence on the future Tyrant—in the canon timeline, her murder by [[Adversary]] influenced [[Ikela]]<nowiki/>ns operating under cult orders led to his madness and descent into Tyranthood. [[Category:Dragons]] [[Category:Historical Interest]] [[Category:Ikela]]

The Place of All Gods is a multi-century, pan-religious site buried in the jungle of the northern [[Blood-thirst Wildlands]]. Occupied by shifters, re-discovered by [[Ad Elementis]] in 252 AC.
== Map == [[File:Place of all gods.webp|thumb]] 16 known temples, of which 4 are substantially exposed and the rest are buried under the others.
The known temples are
# (Exposed, NW): The temple to [[Ikki-ban/Ban-ikki]] and the [[Carmine Path]] # [[Old Gods|Tree Father]] (NW) # Kami-lioleth (an unknown kami) (NW) # A temple to a [[Twisted]] cult (buried under the others, NW) # [[Old Gods|Marioleth]] (SW, exposed) # [[Nocthis]] (SW, hidden) # [[Old Gods|Serak]] (SW, hidden) # [[Imperial Cult]] (NE, exposed) # [[Kami|Great Spirits]] (NE) # [[Old Gods|Mailek]] (NE) # [[Korokonolkom]] (SE, exposed) # [[Selesurala]] (SE) # [[Fountain of Fiery Renewal]] (qua Eternal Flame, SE) # [[Old Gods|Rainbow Serpent]] (hidden, center) # Wanderer # Aelven Ancestors
[[Category:Places]] [[Category:Religion]] [[Category:Noefra]] [[Category:Ad Elementis]]

revision.text:
Only the home of the most fantastic shows--everyone sees exactly what they ''really, really, deep down'' need to see. It can be quite creepy.
Located in the [[Plane of Smoke]], but its location is not fixed within that plane. Presided over by [[Fecor the Inscrutiable]]. [[Category:Places]] [[Category:Plane of Smoke]]

revision.comment: Created page with "In late 205 AC, the [[Catalysts]] freed the exalted Queen of the [[Stone Throne]] from her demonic bindings. This did have consequences--having been a conduit for many sacrifi..."
revision.text: In late 205 AC, the [[Catalysts]] freed the exalted Queen of the [[Stone Throne]] from her demonic bindings. This did have consequences--having been a conduit for many sacrificed souls and having vastly outlived her normal lifespan, her physical frame and soul became unstable. If this continued, she would have suffered a cataclysmic spontaneous existence failure, probably destroying the entire city of [[Ar Salem Dolem]]. So instead, she decided to use the stored residual aether to ascend, becoming an [[Ascendant]] instead. Short version: she succeeded and is now the [[Queen Ascendant]]. [[Category:Religion]] [[Category:Stone Throne]] [[Category:Historical Interest]]

revision.comment: Created page with "A group of mysterious, ancient entities who built impossible structures that persist to this day. In 252 AC, [[Ad Elementis]] discovered that [[Korokonolkom]], Alastor, Wor..."
revision.text:
A group of mysterious, ancient entities who built impossible structures that persist to this day.
In 252 AC, [[Ad Elementis]] discovered that [[Korokonolkom]], [[Alastor, World Judge|Alastor]], [[Perkunos]], and several other [[titans]] and [[Wyrm|wyrms]] were among that group, along with multiple [[Devil|devils]]. The full set of Builders is unknown.

* The [[Crystal Spire]] of [[Noefra|Western Noefra]]
[[Category:Organizations]] [[Category:Historical Interest]]

revision.comment: Created page with "A young bronze [[Dragons|dragon]]. Son of [[Ki-larn]], blue dragon leader of the [[Shaera]] flight in the [[Dragonreach]]. His horde is religion, and he is a cleric of Sakar..."
revision.text:
A young bronze [[Dragons|dragon]]. Son of [[Ki-larn]], blue dragon leader of the [[Shaera]] flight in the [[Dragonreach]]. His horde is religion, and he is a cleric of [[Sakara]], Lady of the Dawn.
Went west from his homeland and got caught up in the issues with [[Arnyek]] in the [[Ladyfrost Mountains]]. [[Enigma]] saved him from pursuers and befriended him (and kept his mom from going nutso, as she's quite protective).
==Current Location== He currently lives at [[Hero's Rest]] as one of the priests there.
[[Category:Dragons]] [[Category:Enigma]]

A fey-influenced harpy chick, raised by gnomes on the [[Isle of Beasts]]. Matured unnaturally rapidly. Adopted by [[Wan Tian Kuo]] while in the egg after, well, the party (in self defense) destroyed the rest of the nest.
She has trained with [[Dilligas Husty|Dil]] in voice control and has taken after her dad, becoming a non-lethal masked vigilante. Has minor shape-shifting powers, letting her appear as a (sometimes winged) humanoid woman.
She is Batwoman. [[Category:Notable People]] [[Category:Ad Elementis]]

revision.text: [[Ihmisi]] woman of the [[Tuatain]] tribe of the [[Lost Coast]]. Sold into planar slavery by hostile tribes, ending up in the [[Plane of Lava]] where she was rescued by [[Ad Elementis]]. revision.text: A [[Fey courts|Spring Court]] fey of considerable power. Her obsession is "people on the edge"--seeing what people do when they're pushed into extreme conditions. Not actively malevolent, but often causes trouble by putting people in hard positions. Became attracted to [[Ad Elementis]] ([[Pyrrha Kelshanne]] in particular). Helped the party a bit, obliquely. Commonly found in the form of a small child. [[Category:Fey]] [[Category:Ad Elementis]]

revision.comment: Created page with "A demonic weapon designed to neutralize [[Tal Elamor]] in the run-up to the [[Cataclysm War]]. A bunch of [[jotnar]] bound into insectile form, they consumed all the aether (e..."
revision.text:
A demonic weapon designed to neutralize [[Tal Elamor]] in the run-up to the [[Cataclysm War]]. A bunch of [[jotnar]] bound into insectile form, they consumed all the aether (especially active magic) in their vicinity, using that to replicate. Contained by the sacrifice of the last archdruid, [[Archibal Kelshanne|Archibal]] trapping it in his own body in the middle of what became the Primal Forest.
Later cleansed by [[Ad Elementis]], with the jotnar being reborn as [[Bianca Kelshanne]]. [[Category:Magic]] [[Category:Demons]]

revision.comment: Created page with "Shortcuts through [[Shadow]] between fixed locations on the [[Mortal Plane]]. The gates require specific opening conditions (often dawn and dusk), and leaving the path results..."
revision.text:
Shortcuts through [[Shadow]] between fixed locations on the [[Mortal Plane]]. The gates require specific opening conditions (often dawn and dusk), and leaving the path results in you being deposited ''somewhere'' in the Mortal Plane unless you have aid. Traveling between two points always takes one or two days, no matter the distance traveled. Those paths that take two days have a safe place to camp. The path is generally safe against intrusion, as long as it is intact.
Some have been disrupted by the [[Cataclysm]] or other events, usually in the Mortal analogue of the path. [[Category:Shadow]]

revision.comment: Created page with "''Note: This is mechanical homebrew, designed to provide some variety and verisimilitude to monster groups while not requiring tons of custom work or figuring out new niches...."
revision.text:
''Note: This is mechanical homebrew, designed to provide some variety and verisimilitude to monster groups while not requiring tons of custom work or figuring out new niches. An elite monster is a tougher, more resilient, meaner version of a regular monster, but without special traits or features that would define a new stat block.''
== Elite Template -- Basics == When creating an elite monster, make the following adjustments. Those noted with '''(CR)''' factor into possible changes in CR.
* Hit Points '''(CR)''': Use the maximum hit points for the normal monster's hit die. * Ability Scores: Increase one of the monster's non-primary abilities by one, prioritizing Wisdom. Primary abilities are either Strength or Dexterity (for weapon or natural-attack using monsters) or a spell-casting ability for spell-attack/spell-casting monsters. Don't generally increase Dexterity unless the monster has natural armor instead of using a Dexterity-based armor calculation. * Saving Throws: If the monster does not have proficiency in any saving throws, give them proficiency in any of Dexterity, Constitution, or Wisdom saving throws. * Attacks ('''CR)''': Increase the monster's damage output by doing one of the following ** Add one more attack (giving them Multiattack if they didn't have it already). This is generally the easiest thing for most monsters, especially weapon-using ones, but less appropriate for monsters that do one big hit. ** Add some (possibly more) non-physical damage to their existing attacks. The damage type should match the theme of the monster--snakes get more poison, fire elementals get more fire. Or whatever. ** Increase the die size or number of dice. This is really most appropriate for spell-attack monsters.
== Elite Template -- CR Calculation == For monsters with starting CR < 19, do the following. Round down at the end. Units here are ''steps'', so 1/4 -> 1/2 is a change of +1.
* Determine how much extra health the monster got. ** If it is less than 15, CR increases by 0. ** If it is between 15 and 30, the CR increases by 0.5. ** If it is greater than 30, the CR increases by 1 + 0.5 for every 15 extra HP above 30. * Determine the extra damage per round (assuming everything hits, averaged over 3 rounds): ** If it is less than 6, CR increases by 0. ** If it is between 6 and 12, the CR increases by 0.5. ** If it is greater than 12, the CR increases by 1 + 0.5 for every 6 extra damage above 12. * Add the contributions from HP and damage and round down.
== Example 1: Elite Wolf == The basic wolf has 11 (2d8+2) HP, no saving throw proficiencies, and a primary ability score of DEX. It has a single bite attack, dealing 7 (2d4+2) damage and knocking prone on a failed save. Ability scores are 12/15/12/3/12/6.
Elite Wolf:
'''HP''': 18 (+7)
'''Ability Scores''': 12/15/12/3/14/6 (+4 CON save modifier)
'''Attacks''': Multiattack (2 bites). Extra damage: 7.
Changes to CR: 0 from HP ( 7 < 15). +0.5 from offense = +0.5 total. Rounded down means no change in CR. [[Category:Homebrew]] [[Category:Monsters]]

revision.comment: Created page with "Archibal of the Primal Forest was the last archdruid of the Primal Forest of [[Tal Elamor]]. He sacrificed himself to imprison the [[aether plague]] until it could starve to d..."
revision.text:
Archibal of the Primal Forest was the last archdruid of the Primal Forest of [[Tal Elamor]]. He sacrificed himself to imprison the [[aether plague]] until it could starve to death. It didn't; instead, it and he reached a detente of sorts. When [[Ad Elementis]] cleansed the corruption of the plague, the [[Firebird]]'s manifestation brought rebirth to both of them, returning Archibal and the plague (later named [[Bianca Kelshanne]]) to life as infants. They were then adopted by [[Pyrrha Kelshanne]] and [[Eskel]] and raised as their own children in southern [[Auringon]].
== Post-Rebirth == A sturdy human infant, much more mentally and emotionally mature than most. He lacks most of the memories of his prior life...or maybe they're just suppressed. [[Category:Notable People]] [[Category:Ad Elementis]]

revision.comment: /* Physical Appearance and Personality */
revision.text:
A truly unique soul, Bianca gained sentience as the [[jotnar]] collective that formed the [[aether plague]] unleashed upon [[Tal Elamor]] in the days leading up to the [[Cataclysm War]]. When summoned into the [[Mortal Plane]], the jotnar was a mere devouring force, distributed across countless ebony insectoid bodies. Ravenously seeking aether, it was lured into the Primal Forest, where [[Archibal Kelshanne|Archibal]], the last archdruid, imprisoned it within the roots of a tree structure, sacrificing himself to hold it in place. There the two of them rested for 252 years. During this time, the jotnar later named Bianca gained will of her own and grew to love Archibal and vice versa. [[Ad Elementis]] arrived in late 252 AC and used the [[Firebird]]'s power, amplified by elemental bindings, to purge the [[Abyss|Abyssal]] influence. The mercy of the [[Firebird]], understanding the love she had for Archibal, gave both of them rebirth in human form. The two of them were adopted by [[Pyrrha Kelshanne]] and [[Eskel]], to be raised as their own children.
== Physical Appearance and Personality == Bianca is an extremely serious, somewhat odd child. Stark ebony skin and curly black-purple hair, with eyes that seem to have nothing but pupil and only a sliver of white. Currently she is only a few months old physically, but has grown significantly (mentally and emotionally at least) more than expected for a child your age. She does not cry--in fact she only rarely vocalizes at all, and seems to be frustrated by not being able to speak fully. [[Category:Notable People]] [[Category:Ad Elementis]] [[Category:Auringon]]

revision.text:
Located in the [[Dreamwall Mountains]] north east of [[Baile Craan]] and stretching to the foothills of the [[Giant Spine Mountains]], the Eastmountain region is known for its independent spirit and strong dislike for the formality and structure of its plains-dwelling neighbors. Populated by a mix of humans, ihmisi, orcs, dwarves, and others that have leaked through, including a fair number of [[giant-kin]] bands and even a small collection of "intelligent monsters" (including a chimera). Almost entirely self-sufficient, they joined the [[Duarchy of Kotimaa]] mostly as a way to preserve their independence. Unlike the other duchies, they elect their leadership in sprawling, fractious elections. And basically don't listen to them anyway.
== Rulers == Only one of note is "Duke" Katria of Cantebrook. She was chosen by lot (she lost) and has basically no actual authority in the Duchy. Each town mayor, family or clan head, etc. does what they want, as long as it doesn't cause problems outside the Duchy. If it does, all the rest stomp on the offender. They're only united against outsiders.
== Towns (in decreasing order of size) ==
* Cantebrook * Hightowne * Wolflong * Rensdow * Culmoor * Bauerbay (accessible only via pack trail and water)

revision.comment: Created page with "A nation of [[dwarves]] and hell-bred (demon-tainted) [[orcs]] living deep in the NW portion of the mountains surrounding the [[Nocthian Caldera]]. They have one significant s..."
revision.text:
A nation of [[dwarves]] and hell-bred (demon-tainted) [[orcs]] living deep in the NW portion of the mountains surrounding the [[Nocthian Caldera]]. They have one significant settlement inside the Caldera. Suspicious of outsiders, they are starting to warm up after positive contacts with [[Half Measures]] and the destruction of the [[Black Tree]] in 251 AC.
== Demographics == The Sigani number about 25,000, with about 70% orcs and 30% dwarves. Only about 8,000 of those live outside the mountain, dominantly orcs.
== History == The Sigani are a blend of the original dwarven inhabitants of the [[Sunken City]], sister to [[Hammerhead]], and the invading orcs of the Army of Chaos. During the [[Cataclysm War]], traitors allowed the Army inside the lower gates, leading to the dwarves retreating deep into the ancient mine tunnels and the orcs occupying the upper levels. The disruption of the [[Cataclysm]] sparked a rebellion among the orcs, who drove out (or killed) their demon-worshipping leaders. Neither side really wanted to go outside, but supplies were scarse. About 150 years ago, the two sides reconciled and united in an attempt to not starve.
== Culture == Sigani culture is notable for several factors.
* They are extremely suspicious of outsiders, in large measure due to meddling from the [[Black Tree]]. Only those few explicitly permitted by the Council can go past the outer walls of the Sigani Gatetown, and even fewer can enter into the tunnels themselves. * They are highly mechanically-inclined, but more clockwork than magitech. They have developed a workable self-propelled cart and employ mechanical assistance with almost everything they do. * The dwarves do not wear beards, and many of both races wear their hair in mohawks or other "punk" fashions, often dyed bright colors. Piercings and body jewelry are common. * Internally, they use a form of scrip stamped on iron strips rather than precious metals. They reserve precious metals for trade with outsiders.
[[Category:Nocthian Caldera]] [[Category:Dwarves]] [[Category:Orc]] [[Category:Nations]]

A young "kingdom" established in the [[Fiach Wood]] in 247 AC by [[Maerik Mar'osh]], an [[Orcs|orcish]] warlord and one of two survivors of the Mar'osh tribe. Founded to give the tribes (orcish and otherwise) of the [[Fiach Wood]] their own place of security and independence from what Maerik saw as rapacious, greedy "civilized" nations (primarily [[Wyrmhold]], who he blamed for inciting the attack that destroyed his tribe).
== Demographics == About 35,000 adults in the core tribes and associated "supplicant" tribes, and about another 15,000 in allied tribes not formally part of the kingdom (mainly to the east of the Abhainn river). Dominantly orcs, but with a leavening of others, primarily [[ihmisi]].
== Location == The core kingdom is located in the central-southern [[Fiach Wood]] between the Serche (Freedom) river to the west and the Abhainn (Blood) river to the east. Roughly a triangle 100 miles on a side, it has several large towns/small cities:
* Elishar ~8k (located in the north on the shores of Silverscale lake) * Dearg Loch An ~6k (located in the south on the shores of Red Lake, where the Serche and the Abhainn meet. * Northbridge (home of the Witches) ~2k. Home of the Diharac. * Southbridge ~4k. Home of the Borglas.
And a number of smaller settlements.
== Government == Mar'osh is a decentralized kingdom that allows the core tribes significant latitude in self-government as long as they support the king's foreign policy and cooperate well with others.
* King Maerik is also the head of the military, raised as in-kind taxation from the constituent tribes. Each tribe must pay in either food, soldiers, or other goods to support the army, which acts additionally as a police force. * His sister, [[Diedre Mar'osh]] is the head of the Witches, the magical and spiritual core of the nation. Majority female, these are more arcane-focused than most orcish nations, with the tribal shamans and witch doctors acting as backup. Many people fear the Witches of Mar'osh. * The core tribes (numbering 6) represent about 15k people. Each one controls their ancestral territory, with the clan chief as governor. Core tribes have pledged themselves directly to the kingdom and provide the bulk of the soldiers. In return, they have territorial control and permanent voice at court. **Borglas (SW) **Diharac (NW) **Ferrmor **Andia Briste **Fiduv **Carraglor * Supplicant tribes represent another 20k people, scattered among 30+ much smaller tribes. These tribes live in and among the core tribes, intermarrying and (eventually) being absorbed. They also represent those whose tribes were obliterated by infighting, disease, etc. They mostly act as farmers and workers. Some retain more tribal organization than others. * Allied tribes pay some tribute periodically and in return are promised protection against assault from the outside, but don't have a voice other than through ambassadors.
== Policy == Mar'osh has a very firm "no first strikes, but also no leeway for second hits" policy. They do not attack other tribes, but any attack on their territory or allies is met with overwhelming force.
They secretly trade with underground groups out of [[Rauviz]] for needed technological supplies (especially advanced agricultural equipment), but that is kept quiet to avoid complications.
The tribes are under strict orders not to mess with [[Wyrmhold]], their nearest neighbor. [[Category:Orc]] [[Category:Mar'osh]]

All the [[Elemental plane|Elemental planes]] have a physical symbol of their [[True Word]], an artifact that the [[Elemental lord]] of that plane bonds to in a ritual called the Inscription. This bond gives the lord the control to truly become the lord of the plane.
For the [[Plane of Ice]], this artifact is the [[Glacierheart]]. An orb, roughly 30" in diameter, seemingly made of purest ice and etched with [[True Word|True Words]], it radiates deathly cold. Touching it unprepared forces the mortal to endure their own worst memories. [[Isskap]] was known to force mortals she particularly disliked to touch it while she was holding it, forcing them to experience ''her'' memories and letting her trawl through their memories.
Its location is currently (as of 252 AC) unknown, as [[Isskap]] hid it in her last few days of lucidity before [[Broken Order]] drove away conscious thought before her downfall. [[Category:Artifacts]] [[Category:Plane of Ice]]

revision.comment: /* Stone Giants */
revision.text:
True giants are [[jazuu]] individuals who have undergone the Titan Transformation ritual or have been transformed by some other runic power (see Other Methods below). They are sterile, which sets them apart from the [[giant-kin]], but live very long lives (150+ years, with higher giant types reaching 500+ years). Generally, their psychologies get altered by the ritual as well as their bodies, leading to substantial similarity between giants of the same type, but there are exceptions.
== The Titan Transformation == When a jazuu attains high enough status (including having fathered/born multiple children), he or she may be eligible for gigantification. This is the process whereby a set of runic commands and powers is imposed on the individual, transforming them into a true giant. This ritual process has several requirements:
It can only happen at a [[Titanwall]]. These huge, semi-circular arcs of stone are covered in runic writing dating back to the Titans and the First Wish. Very few intact specimens remain--there is only a single complete Titanwall on [[Noefra]] (plus maybe 6-8 incomplete or damaged walls, some of them much too hazardous to use).
The ritual requires the willing participation of four individuals of the same station as the candidate (so jazuu for the first transformation, etc). These candidates are forever ineligible for the transformation ritual, although they can stand as ritualists for future candidates. Doing so increases the risk of a faulty transformation, however. This limit puts strong barriers to the number of true giants that can be created.
The ritual requires extreme endurance, both from the candidate and from the ritualists. This is especially true of the first transformation. Failure to complete the first block of "code" results in a malformed creature (an ogre, a troll, an ettin, or something else) or simply results in the death of the candidate. The code is presented below--text after # marks are comments. **START PHYSICAL BLOCK** GROW IN STRENGTH, SIZE # failure here results in an ogre or ettin. Big, strong, dumb. LIVE FOR LONG DURATION # failure here tends to be fatal HUNGER BE SATISFIED # failure here results in a troll. Big, strong, long-lived, always hungry. BECOME # success here results in an oni **END PHYSICAL BLOCK**
**START IMPERATIVES BLOCK** VALUE WORK BECOME # hill giants CREATE BEAUTY BECOME # Stone giants end here DEFEND KIN BECOME # Frost giants end here **END IMPERATIVES BLOCK**
**START RULING BLOCK** COMMAND UNLIVING ELEMENTS BECOME # Fire giants COMMAND KIN BECOME # Cloud Giants COMMAND EVERYTHING BECOME # no one has succeeded in this stage since the Titans. Storm giants came close and are seriously powerful, but seriously rare **END RULING BLOCK** True giants gain extended life, increased size and strength, and freedom from the hunger/physical drives that would normally accompany such an increase in mass. While they do eat, they don't need much food (only slightly more than a regular jazuu) and mainly do so for taste and pleasure. The higher giants don't eat much at all; they are sustained by the runes and their imperatives. One side effect is that true giants are all sterile and generally (but not always) lack sexual urges. Those that retain such urges are considered strange by their peers. [[Giant-kin]] (the failed ones) are not sterile and breed true (hence the plague of ogres and the like). Those that fail are exiled or killed.
=== Other Methods === Some giants have been observed who could not have undergone this ritual. One known method is for a powerful giant (ie ex-titan) such as [[Isskap]] or [[Korokonolkom]] to invest power directly in them, effectively acting as a Titanwall. This is particularly common in the [[Plane of Ice]], where many more frost giants are found than should normally exist.
== Hierarchy of Giants == True giants all fit into a hierarchy based on how far they got in the Titan Transformation. They can be promoted by undergoing the ritual again, but this is rarely done due to the high risk of death, as well as the effect of the ritual making giants satisfied with where they ended up, even if that wasn't what they wanted ex ante.
=== Hill Giants === Hill giants are the smallest, weakest, and least-enhanced of the giants. Their only Imperative is to "Value Work". Strong and durable, they perform much of the brute labor in their areas, often working alongside other, higher giants. Notoriously averse to anything like study, they have an (not entirely undeserved) reputation for being dumb. This is especially true for those who left their home clans. As the most connected to their mortal roots, hill giants often enjoy eating (vast quantities) of food and drinking rivers of beer and other alcohol, even though they do not need it. This often leads to a...rotund...silhouette.
=== Stone Giants === The antithesis of the hill giant, the stone giant has received one additional Imperative: "Create Beauty". They are the artisans, creatives, scholars, and artists of the true giants--fire giants may be better smiths, but stone giants do most of the design work. Physically they are tall and slender as they pour their heart and soul into their work. Stereotypically, they exhibit traits of hyper-focus on a specific area of work, introversion, and lack of social skills. They prefer to be left alone to do their work, only very rarely accepting leadership positions and only in extreme circumstances.
=== Frost Giants === Frost giants have received the additional Imperative "Defend Kin". This transforms them into the combative, scrap-loving warriors of the true giants. They normally train with martial weapons and respond best to strength. Stereotypically, they are quick to anger and sometimes paranoid, and frequently seek power if they feel that their leaders aren't strong enough. While they will generally be loyal to a strong ruler, they will seek to overthrow a weak one. Stereotypically, if a frost giant is in command, their goals will turn towards conquest. This is less out of a desire to rule than out of a need to be "safe"--the presence of people not under their control is seen as a threat somewhere deep in their core.
=== Fire Giants === Fire giants have received the additional Ruling Command "Command Unliving Elements". Fire giants are elemental masters and smiths, working all kinds of metals into weapons and tools. They are also mages. They rarely seek for command, but are capable of it. They have the same "Defend Kin" Imperative as the frost giants, but tempered. They too, do better under the command of a higher giant.
=== Cloud Giants === Cloud giants, the highest kind of giant normally attainable, have received the Ruling Command "Command Kin". Other giants naturally bend the knee to them--a grasping, ambitious Frost Giant general will naturally defer to and be loyal to a cloud giant, even one with much less experience. This makes them frequently arrogant and "above it all". Very few cloud giants exist, at least in [[Noefra]].
=== Storm Giants === Storm giants are failed titans--they achieved ''some'' but not all of the Command "Command Everything". They are vanishingly rare--no storm giants are known to exist in [[Noefra]] as of 252 AC. [[Category:Races]]

revision.text: Also known as the Moon's Vengeance Wastes. This arc-shaped region of central [[Noefra]] separates the [[Inner Border Range]] from the [[Outer Border Range]] east and south of the [[Uulan Gap]]. Broken, arid terrain characterizes this region--caught between two tall mountain ranges it gets very little precipitation. Populated only by monsters and wandering tribes of [[goblins]] and [[giant-kin]], it is not a place that civilized nations have cared about since the fall of the Third Moon brought it into existence. [[Category:Geography]] [[Category:Noefra]]
